1. Lien: The use tax shall be a first and prior lien on the tangible personal property sold, purchased, stored, used, distributed or consumed,
subject only to valid mortgage or other liens of record on and prior to the recording of notice as required by subsection G6 of this section, and
when such tax is collected by retailers or agents, the sales or use tax imposed by sections under this chapter shall be a first and prior lien
upon the goods and business fixtures of or used by any retailer under lease, title retaining contract or other contract arrangement and shall
take precedence on all such property over other liens or claims of whatever kind or nature.
2. Effect Of Sale Of Business; Purchases Subject To Lien:
a. Sale Of Business: Any person who shall sell out a business or stock of goods or who shall quit business shall be required to make out the
return as provided in this section within ten (10) days after the date the person sold the business or stock of goods or quit business, and
such person's successor in business shall be required to withhold sufficient of the purchase money to cover the amount of taxes due and
unpaid until such time as the former owner shall produce a receipt from the director of finance showing that the taxes have been paid or a
certificate that no taxes are due.
b. Purchases Subject To Lien: If the purchaser of a business or stock or goods shall fail to withhold the purchase money as provided in
subsection G2a of this section and the taxes shall be due and unpaid after the ten (10) day period allowed, the purchaser, as well as the
seller, shall be personally liable for the payment of the taxes unpaid by the former owner. Likewise, anyone who takes any stock of goods
or business fixtures of or used by any person under lease, title retaining contract or other contract arrangement, by purchase, foreclosure
sale or otherwise, takes such subject to the lien for any delinquent sales taxes owed by such person and shall be liable for the payment of
all delinquent sales taxes of such prior owner, not, however, exceeding the value of the property so taken or acquired.
3. Status Of Unpaid Tax In Bankruptcy And Receivership: Whenever the business or property of any taxpayer subject to this section shall be
placed in receivership, bankruptcy or assignment for the benefit of creditors or seized under distraint for property taxes, all taxes, penalties
and interest imposed by this section and for which such retailer is in any way liable under the terms of this section shall be a prior and
preferred lien against all the property of such taxpayer, except as to preexisting claims or liens of a bona fide mortgagee, pledgee, judgment
creditor or purchaser whose rights shall have attached prior to the filing of the notice as provided herein on the property of the taxpayer other
than on the goods, stock in trade and business fixtures of such taxpayer. No law enforcement officer, receiver, assignee or other officer shall
sell the property of any person subject to this section under process or order of any court without first ascertaining from the director of finance
the amount of any taxes due and payable under this section, and if there are any such taxes due, owing or unpaid, it shall be the duty of such
officer to first pay the amount of such taxes out of the proceeds of such sale before making payment of any monies to judgment creditor or
other claims of whatever nature, except that the costs of the proceedings and other preexisting claims or liens as above provided.
4. Construction Improvements:
a. Lien For Unpaid Taxes On Personal Property Affixed To Real Property: The full amount of unpaid taxes arising from and required to be
reported on personal property affixed to real property under this section, together with interest and penalties as provided in this section,
shall be and constitute a first and prior lien, which lien shall have precedence over all other liens of whatever kind and nature, except as to
liens for general taxes created by state law and except as to preexisting claims or liens of a bona fide mortgagee, pledgee, judgment
creditor, or purchaser whose rights shall have attached prior to the filing of the notice of tax lien on the property of the taxpayer other than
on the goods, stock in trade and business fixtures of such taxpayer.
b. Final Inspection Or Certificate Of Occupancy Denied Unless Tax Paid: No final inspection shall be made by the town building inspector or
no certificate of occupancy shall be issued unless all taxes due, as provided in this section, on all lumber, fixtures, and any other building
materials and supplies used in or connected with the construction, reconstruction, alteration, expansion, modification or improvement of
any building, dwelling or other structure or improvement to real property within the town have been paid or arrangements therefor made
with the director of finance.
5. Refusal To File Returns:
a. Assessment Of Taxes: If any person or taxpayer or vendor fails, neglects or refuses to collect the tax or file a return and pay the tax as
required by this section or fails to remit the proper amount of tax or underpays the tax because of negligence, fraud or on a regular basis,
the director of finance shall make an estimate based upon such information as may be available and shall add in addition to the tax,
penalty and interest as set forth herein and promptly thereafter give to the delinquent taxpayer written notice of such estimated taxes,
penalty and interest, which notice of assessment shall be served personally or by certified or registered mail and which notice of final
determination, assessment and demand for payment shall be due and payable twenty (20) days from such service.
6. Notice Of Tax Lien: If any taxes, penalty or interest imposed by this section and shown due by returns filed by the taxpayer or as shown by
assessments duly made as provided in this section are not paid within twenty (20) days after such are due, the town shall issue a notice to
the taxpayer by certified mail, setting forth the name of the taxpayer, the amount of the tax, penalties and interest, the date of the accrual
thereof and that the town claims a first and prior lien therefor on the real and tangible personal property of the taxpayer except as to
preexisting claims or liens of a bona fide mortgagee, pledgee, judgment creditor, or purchaser whose rights shall have attached prior to the
filing of the notice as provided in this subsection on property of the taxpayer other than on the goods, stock in trade and business fixtures of
such taxpayer.
7. Issuance Of Distraint Warrant; Filing Of Lien: Notice of lien shall be on forms prescribed by the director of finance whose duties are the
collection of such tax and may be filed in the office of the clerk and recorder of any county in the state in which the taxpayer owns real or
tangible personal property, and the filing of such notice shall create such lien on such property in that county and constitute notice thereof.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 82/449
The director of finance may issue a distraint warrant as provided in subsection G9 of this section at any time when taxes that are due remain
unpaid, regardless of whether a notice of tax lien has been issued.
8. Jeopardy Assessment And Distraint:
a. Jeopardy Enforcement: If the director of finance finds that collection of the tax will be jeopardized by delay, at the director of finance's
discretion, the director of finance may declare the taxable period immediately terminated, determine the tax and issue notice and demand
for payment thereof, and having done so, the tax shall be due and payable forthwith, and the director of finance may proceed immediately
to collect such tax as provided herein.
b. Immediate Enforcement Action: In any other case wherein it appears that the revenue is in jeopardy, the director of finance may
immediately issue demand for payment; and, regardless of the provisions set forth herein, the tax shall be due and payable forthwith and,
in the director of finance's discretion, the director of finance may proceed immediately to collect the tax as provided herein.
c. Security For Payment: Collection under either subsection G8a or G8b of this section may be stayed if the taxpayer gives such security for
payment as shall be satisfactory to the director of finance.
9. Methods Of Enforcing Collection:
a. Issuance Of Distraint: The director of finance may issue a warrant under the director of finance's own hand directed to any employee,
agent or representative of the finance department, sometimes referred to collectively in this subsection as "agent" or "revenue collector", or
to any law enforcement officer of any county of the state, commanding such person to distrain, seize and sell the personal property of the
taxpayer, except such personal property as is exempt from execution and sale by any statute of this state, for the payment of the tax due
together with penalties and interest accrued thereon and cost of execution:
(1) When any deficiency in tax is not paid within twenty (20) days from the mailing of notice of final determination, assessment and
demand for payment therefor and no hearing has been requested and no appeal from such deficiency assessment has been docketed
with any district court of this state within such period;
(2) When any other amount of tax, penalty or interest is not paid within twenty (20) days from the mailing of assessment and demand for
payment thereof; or
(3) Immediately upon making of a jeopardy assessment or of the issuance of a demand for payment as provided in subsection G8 of this
section.
b. Distraint Seizure; Advertisement Of Sale: The agent charged with the collection shall make or cause to be made an account of the goods
or effects distrained, a copy of which, signed by the agent making such distraint, shall be left with the owner or possessor or at the owner's
or possessor's usual place of abode with some member of the owner's or possessor's family over the age of eighteen (18) years or at the
owner's or possessor's usual place of business with the owner's or possessor's stenographer, bookkeeper or chief clerk or, if the taxpayer
is a corporation, shall be left with any officer, manager, general agent or agent for process, with a note of the sum demanded and the time
and place of sale; and shall forthwith cause to be published a notice of the time and place of sale, together with a description of the
property to be sold in a legal newspaper within the county wherein distraint is made, or, in lieu thereof and in the discretion of the director
of finance, the agent or law enforcement officer shall cause such notice to be publicly posted at the courthouse of the county wherein such
distraint is made, and copies thereof to be posted in at least two (2) other public places within such county. The time fixed for the sale shall
not be less than ten (10) days nor more than sixty (60) days from the date of such notification to the owner or possessor of the property
and the publication or posting of such notices. The sale may be adjourned from time to time by such agent or law enforcement officer if it is
deemed advisable, but not for a time to exceed a total of ninety (90) days from the date first fixed for the sale. When any personal property
is advertised for sale under distraint, the agent or law enforcement officer making the seizure shall proceed to sell such property at public
auction, offering the property at not less than a fair minimum price, including the expenses of making the seizure and of advertising the
sale, and if the amount bid for the property at the sale is not equal to the fair minimum price so fixed, the agent or law enforcement officer
conducting the sale may declare such to be purchased by such agent or law enforcement officer for the town. The property so purchased
may be sold by the agent or the law enforcement officer under such regulations as may be prescribed by the director of finance. In any
case of distraint for the payment of taxes, the goods, chattels or effects so distrained shall be restored to the owner or possessor if, prior to
the sale, the amount due is paid, together with the fees and other charges or may be redeemed by any person holding evidence
satisfactory to the director of finance of right of possession.
c. Certificate Of Sale; Evidence Of Purchase: In all cases of sale, the agent or law enforcement officer making the sale shall issue a
certificate of sale to each purchaser, and such certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the right of the agent or law enforcement officer
to make such sale and the conclusive evidence of the regularity of the agent's or law enforcement officer's proceedings in making the sale
and shall transfer to the purchaser all right, title and interest in, and to the property sold; and where such property consists of certificates of
stock in the possession of the agent or law enforcement officer, the certificate of sale shall be notice, when received, to any corporation,
company or association of the transfer, and the certificate of such sale shall be authority for such corporation, company or association to
record the transfer on its books and records; and where the subject of sale is securities or other evidences of debt in the possession of the
agent or law enforcement officer, the certificate of sale shall be good and valid evidence of title in the person holding such as against any
other person. Any surplus remaining above the taxes, penalties, interest, costs and expenses of making the seizure, and of advertising the
sale shall be returned to the owner or such other person having a legal right thereto, and, on demand, the director of finance shall render
an account in writing of the sale.
d. Filing And Release Of Lien: Any employee, agent or representative of the town administrator to whom a distraint warrant has been
directed may file a notice of lien in such forms as the director of finance may prescribe with the person in possession of any personal
property or right to property belonging to the taxpayer, and if not previously recorded, the filing of such notice of lien shall operate from the
date of such filing. The director of finance may release the lien as to any part or all of the property or rights to property covered by any
such lien upon such terms as the director of finance may deem proper.
e. Lien Released: Any lien for taxes as shown on the records of the county clerk and recorder as provided in this subsection, upon payment
of all taxes, penalties and interest covered thereby, shall be released by the director of finance in the same manner as mortgages and
judgments are released.
10. Recovery Of Unpaid Tax By Action At Law:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 83/449
a. Action At Law: The director of finance may also treat any such taxes, penalties or interest due and unpaid as a debt due the town from the
taxpayer. In case of failure to pay the tax or any portion thereof or any penalty or interest thereon when due, the director of finance may
receive at law the amount of such taxes, penalties and interest in such county or district court of the county wherein the taxpayer resides or
has a principal place of business having jurisdiction of the amounts sought to be collected. The return of the taxpayer or the assessment
made by the director of finance as provided in this section shall be prima facie proof of the amount due.
b. Writs Of Attachment: Such actions may be actions in attachment and writs of attachment may be issued to the law enforcement officer,
and in any such proceedings no bond shall be required of the director of finance nor shall any law enforcement officer require of the
director of finance an indemnifying bond for executing the writ of attachment or writ of execution upon any judgment entered in such
proceedings, and the director of finance may prosecute appeals or writs of error in such cases without the necessity of providing bond
therefor. It shall be the duty of the town attorney, when requested by the director of finance, to commence action for the recovery of taxes
due under this section, and this remedy shall be in addition to all other existing remedies or remedies provided in this section.
c. Civil Action To Enforce Lien: In any case where there has been a refusal or neglect to pay any tax due the town and a statement or notice
shall have been filed which, under law, creates a lien upon any real property for such tax, the director of finance may cause a civil action to
be filed in the district court of the county in which is situated any real property which is subject to such lien to enforce the lien of the town
for such tax upon the real property situated in that county or in any other county in the state which may be subject to such lien or to subject
any real property or any right, title or interest in real property to the payment of such tax. The court shall decree a sale of such real property
and distribute the proceeds of such sale, according to the findings of such court in respect to the interest of the parties and the town the
proceedings in such action, and the manner of sale, the period for and manner of redemption from such sale and the execution of deed of
conveyance shall be in accordance with the law and practice relating to foreclosures of mortgages upon real property. In any such action,
the court may appoint a receiver of the real property involved in such action if equity so requires. (Ord. 821, 11-11-2003)
2-11-3: REVENUES FROM SALES AND USE TAXES:
A. All revenues received from the collection of sales and use taxes shall be deposited to the general fund of the town except that the board of
trustees shall annually determine the amount of such revenues to be pledged to and deposited in the "capital improvement fund" to be used
solely to provide capital improvements for the town or for the repayment of bonds issued for such purpose; provided however, in the event that
there are outstanding bonds of the town payable from the capital improvement fund, the amount of sales and use tax revenues deposited to the
capital improvement fund shall not be less than the amount necessary to pay the principal of, premium if any, and interest on such bonds when
due.
B. There is hereby created, as authorized in Colorado Revised Statutes section 29-2-111, a special fund of the town to be known as the "capital
improvement fund" for the deposit of all or any portion of the revenue from the town sales tax or use tax, or both, and to be used solely to
provide capital improvements for the town or for the repayment of bonds issued for such purpose. (Ord. 607, 9-3-1998, eff. 1-1-1999)
2-11-4: AMENDMENTS TO PROVISIONS:
Except as to the sales tax and use tax rate provided for in this chapter, and the items taxed and exempted from the sales tax and use tax
hereunder, the board of trustees may amend, alter, delete or change the provisions of this chapter by the adoption of an amending ordinance in
accordance with law, and such amendment, alteration, deletion or change need not be submitted to the electors of the town for their approval.
(Ord. 607, 9-3-1998, eff. 1-1-1999)
2-11-5: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) or by imprisonment for not more than one year or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. 607, 9-3-1998, eff. 1-1-1999)
Chapter 12
SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT SERVICE CHARGE
2-12-1: SERVICE CHARGE ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby fixed and established a service charge in the amount of ten percent (10%) to be collected from users of solid waste disposal sites,
facilities and transfer stations within the town for the purpose of financing solid waste management in the town. Said service charge shall be added
to all disposal fees received by any operator operating a solid waste disposal site and facility or transfer station within the town. "Solid waste
disposal site and facility and transfer station" shall mean any facility which is required, pursuant to applicable provisions of state law, to obtain a
certificate of designation or other approval from the town of Erie or approval by a county or state government prior to its operation. (Ord. 14-2006,
5-9-2006)
2-12-2: COLLECTION OF SERVICE CHARGE:
It shall be the duty of the operator of any solid waste disposal site and facility and transfer station in the town to collect said service charge at the
time dumping fees are collected for disposal, and to remit the same to the town director of finance on or before the twentieth day of the month
following the month in which said service charge is collected. Failure to timely pay may result in imposition of a late charge of one and one-half
percent (1.5%) simple interest per month on the late payment amount. In the event that the service charge collected by the operator of a transfer
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 84/449
station already includes the applicable town service charges on the landfill disposal fees as required herein, no additional town service charge
shall be collected for disposal of the waste at a solid wastes disposal site and facility. (Ord. 14-2006, 5-9-2006)
2-12-3: ALTERNATE CHARGE:
Should the solid waste site and facility or transfer station be one at which no disposal fee is collected for the reason that the facility serves an
individual user, the fee shall be computed based upon the cost within the market for similar disposal services. (Ord. 14-2006, 5-9-2006)
2-12-4: USE OF CHARGE FUNDS:
The service charge imposed by this chapter shall be used for the purposes of financing solid waste management in the town including, but not
limited to, costs of health inspections; removal of litter and debris from roadsides; establishment, construction and maintenance of roads providing
access to solid waste sites and facilities and transfer stations; financing the landfill management program; equalizing costs for transfer sites in the
town; capital outlay associated with a transfer site system; insurance costs; town staff support costs; financing the requirements for compliance
with the resource conservation recovery act; costs of designation of future site locations; support of programs that encourage recycling of wastes
and proper handling of hazardous wastes; and addressing environmental issues created by past and future solid waste sites and facilities and
other solid waste disposal sites. (Ord. 14-2006, 5-9-2006)
2-12-5: INSPECTION OF RECORDS:
All operators of solid waste disposal sites and facilities and transfer stations in the town shall, at all times of operation, make available to the town
director of finance all books of account of said operator of solid waste disposal sites and facilities for auditing purposes to ensure compliance by
said operators with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 14-2006, 5-9-2006)
Title 3
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
PLANNING COMMISSION
3-1-1: COMMISSION CREATED; TERMS; REMOVALS AND VACANCIES:
A. Commission Created; Members; Qualifications; Compensation: There is hereby created a planning commission for the town. The planning
commission shall consist of seven (7) members, each of whom shall be appointed by the town board of trustees. All seven (7) members shall
be bona fide residents of the town, and if any member shall cease to reside in the town, his or her membership shall immediately terminate. All
members of the commission shall serve as such without compensation and shall hold no other elective or appointive municipal office. Members
of the commission may be reappointed at the discretion of the board of trustees.
B. Terms Of Office: The initial commission appointed pursuant to this chapter shall hold terms as follows: Four (4) commissioners shall be
appointed for terms expiring at the first meeting of the board of trustees following the general election of the town held in April 2002, and three
(3) commissioners shall be appointed for terms expiring at the first meeting of the board of trustees following the general election of the town
held in April 2000. Thereafter, the members of the commission shall be appointed to serve four (4) year terms. Members shall be appointed by
the town board of trustees within sixty (60) days following a general election of the town. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
C. Removal From Office; Vacancies: The board of trustees may, by a majority vote of those present, remove any member of the planning
commission for the following reasons: a conflict of interest violation; any violation of law, regulation, or policy; nonattendance to duty; failure to
attend three (3) consecutive regularly scheduled meetings without a leave of absence approved by majority of the commission; being a plaintiff
or being actively involved or participating in a lawsuit against the town; or any other cause. Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the
expiration of the terms shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term by the board of trustees. Applicants to fill vacancies on the
commission shall be interviewed. (Ord. 01-2010, 1-12-2010)
3-1-2: MEETINGS, ORGANIZATION AND RULES:
A. Officers: The planning commission shall elect its chairman from among the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it
may determine. The term of the chairman shall be one year, with eligibility for reelection.
B. Meetings: The commission shall hold two (2) regular meetings in each month of each calendar year on the first and third Wednesdays of each
month commencing at a time to be determined by the planning commission in the board of trustees chambers of the Erie town hall, 645
Holbrook Street, Erie, Colorado. The planning commission may, by motion, cancel a meeting or prescribe a different date, time or place for
such regular meetings in any month, but no such motion affects the date, time or place for regularly scheduled meetings of the planning
commission in any other month. The commission shall determine the yearly schedule of meetings and provide such schedule to the town clerk
for publication.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 85/449
C. Rules And Records: Conduct of all meetings shall be pursuant to those rules of conduct as adopted by the board of trustees. The commission
shall keep minutes and a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which minutes and records shall be a public
record. Such minutes and records shall be turned over to the town clerk for keeping.
D. Public Input: The public attending a planning commission meeting shall be allowed to address the commission prior to the commission's
consideration of regular business items. Persons wishing to address the commission shall state their name and address for the record.
E. Ad Hoc Committees: The board of trustees, alone, may appoint ad hoc committees from among the members of the commission.
F. Quorum: A quorum shall be one-half (1/2) of the total number of actual members of the commission, rounded up to the nearest whole. No
meetings shall be held without a quorum.
G. Reports: The planning commission shall biannually prepare a written report which shall then be presented orally to the board of trustees at a
board of trustees meeting, with the first report and presentation occurring after the first of the year and the second prior to the start of the town's
budget consideration for the following year. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
3-1-3: DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS GENERALLY:
The planning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities granted and provided in Colorado Revised Statutes, and shall
follow the procedures therein set forth. In addition, the planning commission shall have the express duties, authority and jurisdiction hereinafter set
out in this chapter and elsewhere in this code. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
3-1-4: ZONING:
The planning commission shall possess all the powers heretofore made and provided in the zoning title and the Colorado Revised Statutes. (Ord.
03-2008, 1-8-2008)
3-1-5: SUBDIVISION OF LAND:
The planning commission shall possess all the powers heretofore made and provided in the subdivision title and the Colorado Revised Statutes.
The territory of jurisdiction of the planning commission over the subdivision of land shall include all land located within the legal boundaries of the
town and, limited only to control with reference to a major street plan and not otherwise, also includes all land lying within three (3) miles of the
boundaries of the town not located in any other municipality; except, that in the case of land lying within five (5) miles of more than one
municipality, the jurisdiction of the planning commission shall terminate at a boundary equidistant from the respective corporate limits of such
municipalities. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
Chapter 2
AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD
(Rep. by Ord. 02-2010, 1-12-2010)
Chapter 3
HISTORIC PRESERVATION ADVISORY BOARD
3-3-1: ADVISORY BOARD CREATED:
There is hereby created the Historic Preservation Advisory Board for the Town. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the Historic Preservation Advisory Board is as follows:
A. To designate, preserve, protect, enhance and perpetuate those sites, structures, and objects which reflect outstanding elements of the Town's
cultural, artistic, social, ethnic, economic, political, architectural, historic, technological, institutional, or other heritage; and to create a method to
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 86/449
draw a reasonable balance between private property rights and the public interest in preserving Erie's unique historic character by creating an
advisory board to review and recommend approval or denial of any proposed demolition of, moving of, or alteration to properties of historic
value.
B. Foster civic pride in the beauty and accomplishments of the past.
C. Stabilize or improve aesthetic and economic vitality and values of such sites, neighborhoods, structures, and objects.
D. Protect and enhance the Town's attraction to tourists and visitors, increase the quality of life for the citizens and enhance future economic
development.
E. Promote the use of outstanding historical or architectural sites, structures, and objects for the education, stimulation and welfare of the people of
the Town.
F. Promote good urban design.
G. Promote and encourage continued private ownership and utilization of such sites, structures, or objects.
H. Integrate historic preservation with the Town comprehensive development plan. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-3: MEMBERSHIP; QUALIFICATIONS; COMPENSATION:
The Historic Preservation Advisory Board shall consist of either five (5) or seven (7) members, each of whom shall be appointed by the Board of
Trustees. The Town shall at least make a good faith effort to recruit and appoint, and, if possible, shall actually recruit and appoint, at least three
(3) board members who are professionals in preservation related disciplines, such as architecture, landscape architecture, architectural history,
archaeology, history, planning, American studies, American civilization, cultural geography or cultural anthropology. All board members shall be
bona fide residents of the Town. If any board member shall cease to reside in the Town, his or her membership on the Historic Preservation
Advisory Board shall immediately terminate. All board members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 26-2018, 8-28-2018)
3-3-4: APPOINTMENTS; TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES; REMOVALS:
A. Appointments: All members of the Historic Preservation Advisory Board shall be appointed as at large members by the Board of Trustees, and
said members may be reappointed. Members shall be appointed at the regular meeting of the Board of Trustees first following the regular Town
election, beginning with the regular Town election held on April 4, 2000 (or as soon after the first regular meeting as may be practicable).
B. Terms Of Office: The term of office for each member appointed shall be as follows:
1. The first four (4) members appointed to serve as initial members of the Historic Preservation Advisory Board shall each be appointed for a
four (4) year term.
2. The next three (3) members appointed to serve as initial members of the Historic Preservation Advisory Board shall each be appointed for a
two (2) year term.
3. Appointments made following the expiration of the initial terms as set forth in subsections B1 and B2 of this section shall each be for a term
of four (4) years.
C. Vacancies: Vacancies occurring other than through the expiration of the term of the member shall be filled for the remainder of that member's
term by appointment by the Board of Trustees.
D. Removal From Office: The Board of Trustees may, by a majority vote of those present, remove any member of the Historic Preservation
Advisory Board for the following reasons: a conflict of interest violation; any violation of law, regulation, or policy; nonattendance to duty; failure
to attend three (3) consecutive regularly scheduled meetings without a leave of absence approved by a majority of the Historic Preservation
Advisory Board; being a plaintiff or being actively involved or participating in a lawsuit against the Town; or any other cause.
E. Reappointment: Members of the Historic Preservation Advisory Board may be reappointed at the discretion of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 28-
2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-5: MEETINGS; ORGANIZATION AND RULES:
A. Meetings:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 87/449
1. Regular Meetings: The Historic Preservation Advisory Board shall hold regularly scheduled monthly meetings on the fourth Monday of each
month at a time to be determined by the Historic Preservation Advisory Board in the Town Hall, unless alternative dates, times, or places are
approved by the Advisory Board. The Advisory Board shall hold a minimum of six (6) meetings per year. The Advisory Board shall determine
the yearly schedule of meetings and provide such schedule to the Town Clerk for publication. (Ord. 32-2014, 9-9-2014)
2. Special Meetings: The Historic Preservation Advisory Board may call for special meetings in accordance with rules adopted.
3. Open To Public: All meetings shall be open to the public.
B. Quorum: A quorum shall be one-half (1/2) of the total number of actual members of the Historic Preservation Advisory Board, rounded up to the
nearest whole. No meetings shall be held without a quorum. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
C. Organization:
1. Officers: The Historic Preservation Advisory Board shall elect a Chairperson, a Vice Chairperson and a Secretary.
2. Bylaws: The Historic Preservation Advisory Board may adopt bylaws or procedures, which must be approved by the Board of Trustees. Such
bylaws or procedures may be amended from time to time by a majority vote of the entire Historic Preservation Advisory Board and a majority
vote of the Town Board of Trustees present at a legally held meeting. (Ord. 15-2011, 8-23-2011)
D. Rules:
1. The public attending a historic preservation advisory board meeting shall be allowed to address the advisory board prior to the advisory
board's consideration of regular business items. Any person wishing to address the advisory board shall state his or her name and address
for the record.
2. The chairperson shall preside at all regular, special or adjourned meetings of the advisory board and shall, subject to the rules of the
advisory board, decide all points of procedure.
3. The vice chairperson shall assume the duties and responsibilities of the chairperson in the event the chairperson is absent or unable to
perform.
4. When both the chairperson and the vice chairperson are absent, those members present shall select a member by majority vote to preside
over the meeting.
5. The historic preservation advisory board shall keep minutes of its meetings and records of its transactions, which shall be publicly available.
Such minutes and records shall be turned over to the town clerk for keeping.
6. A majority vote of the members present is required for all recommendations, determinations, and elections. Such a majority vote shall be
presented to the board of trustees as an advisory opinion of the historic preservation advisory board. A minority opinion may also be
submitted to the board of trustees.
7. All members, inclusive of the chairperson, are eligible to vote on any item.
8. Any historic preservation advisory board member shall request of the chairperson to be excused from any discussion or vote on any matter
in which the member feels there is a personal conflict of interest.
9. Conduct of all meetings shall be pursuant to those rules of conduct as adopted by the board of trustees.
E. Public Input: The public attending a historic preservation advisory board meeting shall be allowed to address the historic preservation advisory
board prior to the historic preservation advisory board's consideration of regular business items. Persons wishing to address the historic
preservation advisory board shall state their name and address for the record. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-6: OFFICERS AND COMMITTEES:
A. Officers:
1. Election Of Officers: The historic preservation advisory board shall elect its chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary from among the full
membership of the advisory board. The election of officers shall be held at the first regular meeting of the advisory board held after
appointment of the members as provided for herein. If no appointments are necessary, then the election shall be held at the first regular
meeting of the advisory board held after one year from the date of the prior election of officers. (Ord. 15-2011, 8-23-2011)
2. Terms Of Office: The terms of the chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary shall be for one year.
3. Vacancies In Office:
a. A vacancy in the office of chairperson shall be filled automatically by the vice chairperson, and a new vice chairperson shall be elected at
the next regular meeting of the advisory board from among the remaining members.
b. A vacancy in the office of vice chairperson or secretary shall be filled at the next regular meeting of the advisory board from among the
remaining members.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 88/449
c. The officer elected to fill an irregular vacancy in the office of chairperson, vice chairperson or secretary shall serve until the next following
election as provided for herein.
B. Committees: The board of trustees, alone, may appoint ad hoc committees. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-7: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The duties and responsibilities of the historic preservation advisory board are as follows:
A. Recommend criteria for approval by the board of trustees by which the advisory board shall conduct their review of historic properties and
review proposals to alter, demolish, or move designated properties. The advisory board shall identify those properties or districts which meet
the applicable criteria to be placed on the local register, and shall make a recommendation to the board of trustees that such properties or
districts be placed on the local register. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
B. Conduct surveys for the purpose of creating a preservation plan of historic properties. Such inventory is for the purpose of informing citizens
who own such properties that the advisory board anticipates these properties may meet the criteria for designation. (Ord. 15-2011, 8-23-2011)
C. Review and make a recommendation to the board of trustees on any application for altering, moving or demolishing any historic properties.
(Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
D. Advise and assist owners of historic properties on physical and financial aspects of preservation, renovation, rehabilitation, and reuse.
E. When appropriate, encourage and assist owners of historic properties to apply for nomination to the national register of historic places and allow
adequate public participation in the advisory board's part in the national register nomination process. If the advisory board lacks at least one
member who is a professional in the discipline of architecture, history, architectural history, or archaeology, the board shall seek additional
expertise in the appropriate discipline when considering national register nominations. (Ord. 15-2011, 8-23-2011)
F. Develop and assist in public education programs including, but not limited to, walking tours, brochures, a marker program for historic properties,
lectures, and conferences.
G. Advise the board of trustees on matters related to preserving the historic character of the town.
H. Assist in pursuing financial assistance for preservation related programs.
I. Establish such rules, regulations and procedures relating to designation, nomination, preservation, relocation, demolition, exemptions, economic
exemptions, economic incentives, appeal of decisions, or other processes relating to the powers and duties of the historic preservation advisory
board.
J. Make a recommendation to the board of trustees for the removal of properties from the register for reasons the historic preservation advisory
board deems appropriate, including, but not limited to, forces of nature. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010; amd. Ord. 15-2011, 8-23-2011)
3-3-8: NOMINATION AND DESIGNATION OF HISTORIC LANDMARKS:
A. Designation Authorized:
1. Pursuant to the procedures hereinafter set forth in this section, the board of trustees may designate as a historic landmark an individual
structure or an integrated group of structures and features on a single site having a special historic or architectural value.
2. Each such designation shall include a description of the historic landmark that justified designation and a description of the particular
features that should be preserved, and shall include a legal description of the location and boundaries of the historic landmark site. The
historic property included in any such designation shall be subject to the criteria for designation set forth in this chapter, and eligible for such
incentive programs as may be approved by the board of trustees.
B. Advisory Board Procedures For Designating Historic Landmarks:
1. Nominations: A nomination for designation may be made only by the owner of record for his or her own structure or property by filing an
application with the community development director. In the case of multiple owners of the same structure or property, all such persons must
consent to the nomination. The community development director shall then forward the application to the advisory board chairperson. At least
one member of the advisory board shall then contact the owner or owners of such proposed historic landmarks, outlining the effects of
designation as a historic property or historic structure.
2. Advisory Board Review: No more than forty five (45) days after the filing of the application, the advisory board shall review the application for
conformance with the established criteria for designation and with the purposes of this chapter. Within fifteen (15) days after the conclusion of
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 89/449
its review, but in no event more than forty five (45) days after the meeting date first set, unless otherwise mutually agreed by the advisory
board and the applicant(s), the advisory board shall adopt written findings and conclusions and recommend that the board of trustees
approve, modify and approve, or deny the application; table the application for further review; or continue the review of the application to a
new date. The advisory board shall then notify the board of trustees of its recommendation along with a copy of the advisory board's report.
(Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
C. Board Of Trustees Procedures For Designating Historic Landmarks For Preservation:
1. Board Of Trustees Review: No more than forty five (45) days after the advisory board makes a recommendation to the board of trustees, the
board of trustees shall hold a public, quasi-judicial hearing on the application to determine conformance with the established criteria for
designation and with the purposes of this chapter.
a. The community development director shall mail written notice of the public hearing to the owner(s) of the structure or property included in
the proposed designation no later than ten (10) days prior to the public, quasi-judicial hearing date. Failure to send notice by mail to any
such owner where the address of such owner is unknown and not a matter of public record shall not invalidate any proceedings in
connection with the proposed designation.
b. The board of trustees shall review the application for conformance of the proposed designation with the established criteria for designation
and the standards of this chapter within thirty (30) days after the conclusion of the public, quasi-judicial hearing, but in no event more than
forty five (45) days after the hearing date first set, unless otherwise mutually agreed by the board of trustees and the applicant(s). The
board of trustees shall adopt written findings and conclusions and either approve, modify and approve, or deny the application. (Ord. 15-
2011, 8-23-2011)
D. Notice Of Designation:
1. When a historic landmark has been designated by the board of trustees, as provided hereinabove, the community development director shall
properly notify the owners of the historic landmark included therein and shall cause a copy of the designation as described above to be
recorded with the Boulder or Weld County clerk and recorder, as appropriate. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-9: REVOCATION OF DESIGNATION:
A. Advisory Board Action: If a structure or physical feature on a designated historic landmark has been lawfully removed or demolished, the owner
may apply to the advisory board for revocation of designation. The advisory board shall recommend revoking a historic landmark designation if,
after following the procedures prescribed by subsection 3-3-8B of this chapter, it determines that without the demolished structure or physical
feature, the historic landmark as a whole no longer meets the purposes of this chapter and the criteria for designation. A report and
recommendation on the application shall be forwarded to the board of trustees.
B. Board Of Trustees' Action: The board of trustees shall revoke a historic landmark designation if, after following the procedures prescribed by
subsection 3-3-8C of this chapter, it determines that without the demolished structure or physical feature, the historic landmark as a whole no
longer meets the purposes of this chapter and the criteria for designation. Upon adoption by the board of trustees, the community development
director shall properly notify the owners of the historic landmark included therein and shall cause a copy of the revocation to be recorded with
the Boulder or Weld County clerk and recorder, as appropriate. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-10: LIMITATIONS ON RESUBMISSION AND RECONSIDERATION OF PROPOSED DESIGNATION:
Whenever the board of trustees denies a proposed designation, no person shall submit an application for a period of one year from the effective
date of the denial on the original application. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-11: AMENDMENT OF DESIGNATION:
Designation of a historic landmark may be amended to add physical features, structures or sites to the landmark under the procedures prescribed
by subsections 3-3-8B and C of this chapter. Whenever a designation has been amended in this manner, the community development director
shall notify the owners of the historic landmark included therein and shall cause a copy of the amended designation to be recorded with the
Boulder or Weld County clerk and recorder, as appropriate. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-12: REGISTER OF HISTORIC LANDMARKS; REFERRAL OF BUILDING PERMIT APPLICATIONS:
The community development director shall maintain a current record of all designated historic landmarks and pending designations. If the building
division receives an application for a permit to carryout any new construction, alteration, removal or demolition of a building or other feature on a
designated historic landmark or in an area for which designation proceedings are pending, the building division shall promptly forward such permit
application to the advisory board as outlined in section 3-3-15 of this chapter. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-13: CONSTRUCTION ON PENDING HISTORIC LANDMARKS:
No person shall receive a building permit to construct, alter, remove or demolish any structure or other physical feature on a pending historic
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 90/449
landmark after the date an application has been filed to initiate the designation of such historic landmark. No such permit application filed after
such date will be approved while proceedings are pending on such designation. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-14: CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS REQUIRED:
No person shall carry out or permit to be carried out on a designated historic landmark any new construction, alteration, removal, or demolition of a
building or other physical feature without first obtaining a certificate of appropriateness for the proposed work under this chapter. (Ord. 28-2010,
11-23-2010)
3-3-15: CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS; APPLICATION:
An owner of property designated as a historic landmark may apply for a certificate of appropriateness by filing an application with the community
development director and including in the application all information that the advisory board determines is necessary to consider the application,
including, without limitation, plans and specifications showing the proposed exterior appearance, with texture, materials and architectural design
and detail. The community development director shall then forward the application to the advisory board chairperson. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-16: CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS; ADVISORY BOARD REVIEW; BOARD OF TRUSTEES REVIEW;
ISSUANCE:
A. Advisory Board Procedures:
1. Advisory Board Review: The advisory board shall review an application for a certificate of appropriateness for new construction, alteration,
removal or demolition of a designated historic landmark within sixty (60) days after the filing of the application. The advisory board shall
determine whether the application meets the criteria set forth in this chapter for certificates of appropriateness. Within thirty (30) days after
the advisory board's review, unless otherwise mutually agreed upon by the advisory board and the applicant, the advisory board shall adopt
written findings and conclusions and recommend that the board of trustees approve, modify and approve, or deny the application. The
advisory board shall then notify the board of trustees of its recommendation. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
When reviewing a certificate of appropriateness involving moving or demolition of a structure or other physical feature, the advisory board
may extend the review period up to ninety (90) additional days if the advisory board finds the original application does not meet the criteria
set forth in this chapter for certificates of appropriateness. The ninety (90) day extension period shall be used to encourage both the
applicant and the advisory board to explore acceptable alternative solutions to the original submittal. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010; amd. Ord.
15-2011, 8-23-2011)
B. Board Of Trustee Procedures:
1. Board Of Trustee Review: The board of trustees shall review an application for a certificate of appropriateness for new construction,
alteration, removal or demolition of a designated historic landmark structure within sixty (60) days after receipt of a decision of the advisory
board referred to hereinabove. The board of trustees shall determine whether the application meets the criteria set forth in this chapter for
certificates of appropriateness. Within thirty (30) days after the hearing date first set, unless otherwise mutually agreed upon by the board of
trustees and the applicant, the board of trustees shall adopt written findings and conclusions.
a. A decision of the board of trustees approving or denying an application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be determined in the
manner provided for by subsection 3-3-8C of this chapter, except the board of trustees will consider the certificate of appropriateness
rather than landmark designation.
b. The community development director shall issue a certificate of appropriateness if an application has been approved by the board of
trustees. When approving an application for a certificate of appropriateness, the board of trustees may impose a time limit for the applicant
to apply for a building permit conforming to the certificate.
c. If the board of trustees denies an application for a certificate of appropriateness, no person may submit a subsequent application for the
same or substantially the same construction, alteration, removal or demolition within one year from the date of the final action upon the
original application. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-17: UNSAFE OR DANGEROUS CONDITIONS EXEMPTED:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent any measures of construction, alteration, removal, or demolition necessary to correct the
unsafe or dangerous condition of any structure, other physical feature, or parts thereof where such condition is declared unsafe or dangerous by
the town's chief building official, or the Mountain View fire protection district's fire marshal, and where the proposed measures have been declared
necessary by the town administrator to correct the condition. Any temporary measures may be taken without first obtaining a certificate of
appropriateness, but such a certificate shall be required for permanent construction, alteration, removal or demolition. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-18: PROPERTY MAINTENANCE REQUIRED:
The board of trustees intends to preserve from deliberate or inadvertent neglect the exterior portions of designated historic landmarks and all
interior portions thereof whose maintenance is necessary to prevent deterioration of any exterior portion. No owner, lessee, or occupant of any
designated historic landmark shall fail to prevent significant deterioration of the exterior of the structure or physical feature beyond the condition of
the structure or physical feature on the effective date of the designation. No owner, lessee, or occupant of any designated historic landmark shall
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 91/449
fail to comply with all applicable provisions of this chapter and other codes of the town regulating property maintenance. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-
2010)
3-3-19: CRITERIA FOR DESIGNATION:
The advisory board shall consider the following criteria in reviewing nominations of properties for designation, and the board of trustees shall
consider the following criteria in reviewing properties for designation:
A. Historic Landmarks: Historic landmarks must be at least fifty (50) years old and meet, among others, one or more of the criteria for architectural,
social/historic, or geographic/environmental significance as described below. A historic landmark may be exempt from the age standard if it is
found to be exceptionally important in other significant criteria.
1. Historic sites shall meet one or more of the following criteria:
a. Architectural criteria:
(1) Exemplifies specific elements of an architectural style or period;
(2) Example of the work of an architect or builder who is recognized for expertise nationally, statewide, regionally, or locally;
(3) Demonstrates superior craftsmanship or high artistic value;
(4) Represents an innovation in construction materials or design; (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
(5) Style is particularly associated with Erie or one of its neighborhoods; (Ord. 15-2011, 8-23-2011)
(6) Represents a built environment of a group of people in an era of history;
(7) Pattern or grouping of elements representing at least one of the above criteria; or
(8) Significant historic remodel.
b. Social/historic criteria:
(1) Site of a historic event that had an effect on society or the community;
(2) Exemplifies cultural, political, economic, or social heritage of the community; or
(3) An association with a notable person or the work of a notable person.
c. Geographic/environmental criteria:
(1) Enhances sense of identity of the community; or
(2) An established and familiar natural setting or visual feature of the community. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
2. Archeological sites (historic and prehistoric) shall meet one or more of the following criteria: (Ord. 15-2011, 8-23-2011)
a. Architectural Criteria:
(1) Exhibits distinctive characteristics of type, period or manner of construction, or
(2) A unique example of structure.
b. Social/historic criteria:
(1) Demonstrable potential to make an important contribution to the knowledge of the area's history or prehistory;
(2) An association with an important event in the area's development;
(3) An association with a notable person(s) or the work of a notable person(s);
(4) A typical example/association with a particular ethnic group; or
(5) A unique example of an event in Erie's history.
c. Geographical/environmental criterion:
(1) Geographically or regionally important.
3. All sites will be evaluated for their physical integrity using the following criteria, but a site need not meet all of the following criteria:
a. Shows character, interest or value as part of the development, heritage or cultural characteristics of the community, region, state or nation;
b. Retains original design features, materials and/or character;
c. Original location or same historic context after having been moved; or
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 92/449
d. Has been accurately reconstructed or restored based on documentation. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-20: CRITERIA FOR CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS; NEW CONSTRUCTION OR ALTERATION:
A. The board of trustees shall issue a certificate of appropriateness for any proposed new construction or alteration on a designated historic
landmark only if the board of trustees can determine that the proposed work would not detrimentally alter, destroy or affect any architectural or
landscape feature that contributes to its original historic designation. The board of trustees must find that the proposed work is visually
compatible with designated historic structures located on the property in terms of designs, finish, material, scale, mass and height.
B. In determining compatibility, the board of trustees shall use the definition set forth in section 3-3-25 of this chapter and the following criteria:
1. The effect on the general historic and architectural character of the structure and property;
2. The architectural style, arrangement, texture and material used on the existing and proposed structures and their relation to and compatibility
with other structures;
3. The size of the structure, its setbacks, location, and the appropriateness thereof when compared to existing structures and the site;
4. The compatibility of accessory structures and fences with the main structure on the site, and other structures;
5. The effects of the proposed work in creating, changing, destroying, or otherwise impacting the exterior architectural features of the structure
upon which such work is done;
6. The condition of existing improvements and whether they are a hazard to public health and safety;
7. The effects of the proposed work upon the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of the property; and
8. Compliance with the United States secretary of the interior's "Standards For Rehabilitation". (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-21: CRITERIA FOR CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS; RELOCATING A STRUCTURE:
In addition to the criteria in section 3-3-20 of this chapter, the board of trustees shall use the following criteria in considering an application for a
certificate of appropriateness for relocation of a historic landmark, a structure on a historic landmark site, or a structure onto a historic landmark
site.
A. For consideration of the original site, the board of trustees will review for compliance with all of the following criteria:
1. Documentation showing the structure cannot be rehabilitated or reused on its original site to provide for any reasonable beneficial use of the
property;
2. The contribution the structure makes to its present setting;
3. Whether plans are specifically defined for the site to be vacated, and have been approved by the town administrator;
4. If the structure can be moved and resited without significant damage to its physical integrity and the applicant can show the relocation
activity is the best preservation method for the character and integrity of the structure; and
5. Whether a structural report submitted by a licensed structural engineer adequately demonstrates the soundness of the structure proposed
for relocation.
B. For consideration of the new location, the advisory board will review for compliance with all of the following criteria:
1. Whether the building or structure is compatible with its proposed site and adjacent properties; and if the receiving site is compatible in nature
with the structure or structures proposed to be moved;
2. The structure's architectural integrity and its consistency with the character of the neighborhood;
3. Whether the relocation of the structure would diminish the integrity or character of the neighborhood of the receiving site; and
4. If a relocation plan has been submitted and approved by the town administrator, to ensure the safe relocation, preservation and repair of the
structure, site preparation and infrastructure connections as provided in applicable codes of the town.
C. When a structure is relocated, the town may require the owner of the property to post a performance bond in an appropriate amount for the
purpose of ensuring that the structure is reestablished in the new location according to the town's codes. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-22: CRITERIA FOR CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS; DEMOLITION OF STRUCTURE:
A. Approval Of Replacement/Reuse Plan: If demolition approval is granted on any basis other than that of an imminent hazard or economic
hardship, a certificate of appropriateness will not be issued until a replacement/reuse plan for the property has been approved by the town
administrator.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 93/449
B. Review Criteria For Total Demolition Of A Designated Historical Landmark:
1. The structure proposed for demolition is not structurally sound despite evidence of the owner's efforts to properly maintain the structure;
2. The structure cannot be rehabilitated or reused on site to provide for any reasonable beneficial use of the property;
3. The structure cannot be practically moved to another site in the town; and
4. The applicant demonstrates that the proposal mitigates to the greatest extent possible the following:
a. Any impacts that occur to the visual character of the neighborhood where demolition is proposed to occur;
b. Any impact on the historic importance of the structure or structures located on the property and adjacent properties; and
c. Any impact to the architectural integrity of the structure or structures located on the property and adjacent properties.
C. Review Criteria For Partial Demolition Of A Designated Historical Landmark: An applicant requesting a certificate of appropriateness for partial
demolition shall provide data clearly to demonstrate that the situation meets all of the following criteria:
1. The partial demolition is required for the renovation, restoration or rehabilitation of the structure; and
2. The applicant has mitigated, to the greatest extent possible, and at the applicant's own cost:
a. Impacts on the historic importance of the structure or structures located on the property;
b. Impacts on the architectural integrity of the structure or structures located on the property.
D. Archeological Sites: In the case of designated archeological sites, consideration will be given to whether information can be recovered before or
as part of the demolition process.
E. Assumption Of Costs: The applicant shall assume all of the costs associated with the mitigation efforts. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-23: EXEMPTIONS:
If the application to the board of trustees for a certificate of appropriateness is denied, an applicant may request an exemption from the certificate
requirements, provided that the intent and purpose of this chapter is not significantly compromised and provided that adequate documentation is
submitted to the board of trustees, either in writing or by testimony, to establish qualification for one of the exemptions set forth in subsection A or
B of this section. Such documentation or testimony must be substantiated by professional opinion or through explanation of how the information
was obtained, and at the applicant's expense, during a public hearing as provided for in subsections C and D of this section.
A. Economic Hardship: An economic hardship exemption may be granted if the applicant demonstrates, after consideration of all facts and
circumstances, that he is unable to obtain a reasonable return on his investment.
B. Health/Safety Hardship: A health and/or safety hardship exemption may be granted if the applicant shows that the application of the criteria
creates a situation substantially inadequate to meet the applicant's needs because of specific health and/or safety issues, but not if the health
and/or safety issues were created by the action or inaction of the applicant.
C. Review Of Application: The board of trustees shall review an application for an exemption as provided for herein within sixty (60) days after
receipt of the application. The board of trustees shall determine whether the application meets the criteria and standards set forth in this
chapter for exemptions. Within thirty (30) days after the hearing date first set, unless otherwise mutually agreed upon by the board of trustees
and the applicant, the board of trustees shall adopt written findings and conclusions.
D. Decision: A decision of the board of trustees approving or disapproving an application for an exemption shall be determined in the manner
provided for by subsection 3-3-8C of this chapter, except the board of trustees will consider the exemption rather than landmark designation.
(Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-24: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
Violations of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-25: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words are defined as follows:
ALTERATION: Any act or process that changes either:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 94/449
A. One or more of the exterior architectural features of a structure, or
B. One or more of the physical features of a site.
BOARD OF TRUSTEES: The board of trustees of the town of Erie, Colorado.
CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS: A certificate issued by the town showing approval of plans for construction, alteration, demolition, or
relocation of structures that would affect a designated landmark.
CODE: The municipal code of the town of Erie, Colorado.
COMPATIBILITY: Consistent with, harmonious with, and/or enhancing the mixture of complementary architectural styles either of the architecture
of an individual structure or the character of the surrounding structures.
CONTRIBUTING STRUCTURES: Those structures or physical features within a site that help to define the historic significance of that site.
DESIGNATED HISTORIC LANDMARK: A structure or site officially designated by the town.
EXTERIOR ARCHITECTURAL FEATURES: The exterior architectural features of a structure, including, but not limited to, the color, kind and
texture of building materials, and the type, design and character of windows, doors and appurtenances.
HISTORIC LANDMARK: A structure or site that has been designated as such by the town because of its historic significance and importance to
the community. Historic landmark may be used interchangeably herein with the term historic property.
HISTORIC PRESERVATION ADVISORY BOARD OR ADVISORY BOARD: A citizen committee appointed by the board of trustees to administer
the town's historic preservation program, including designation of historic landmarks. The advisory board shall perform the various functions and
duties provided for it in this chapter.
HISTORIC PROPERTY: The cultural resources, including buildings, structures, objects and sites that are of historical significance.
HISTORIC SIGNIFICANCE: Having importance in the history, architecture or culture of the town, Boulder County or Weld County.
NONCONTRIBUTING STRUCTURES: Structures or physical features that may be within a site but are not of historic significance per se; however,
the relationship of these structures with the contributing structures may be important in the preservation of the site.
NONDESIGNATED STRUCTURES: Structures that have not been designated as historic landmarks.
OVERWHELMING HISTORIC IMPORTANCE: A. Possessing such unusual or uncommon significance that any structure's potential demolition or
major alteration would diminish the character and sense of place in the town, or
B. Possessing superior or outstanding examples of the architecture, social or geographic historic significance criteria outlined in the standards
and criteria set forth in this chapter. The term "superior" shall mean excellence of its kind and the term "outstanding" shall mean marked by
eminence and distinction.
OWNER: The person or persons listed in the records of the Boulder or Weld County clerk and recorder or the Boulder or Weld County assessor as
having legal title to the property vested in them.
PRESERVATION: The protection, enhancement, and maintenance of historic properties.
REGISTER: Locally maintained list of properties nominated as historically significant and designated as historically significant.
SITE: The scene of an activity that has a historic significance to the town. The site may not include historic structures or structures at all; for
example, parks, abandoned mining or agricultural areas, and archeological sites.
TOWN: The town of Erie, Colorado.
TOWN ADMINISTRATOR: The town administrator of the town and anyone designated on his staff to administer the duties set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
3-3-26: RELATIONSHIP TO BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND TOWN STAFF:
A. The historic preservation advisory board shall advise and recommend to the board of trustees exclusively on those matters pertinent to the
historic preservation advisory board's duties and subject area, as set forth herein.
B. The historic preservation advisory board shall biannually prepare a written report which shall be presented orally to the board of trustees at a
board of trustees meeting, with the first report and presentation occurring after the first of the year and the second prior to the start of the town's
budget consideration for the following year.
C. Staff will be available to attend historic preservation advisory board meetings quarterly at the request of the historic preservation advisory
board's chairperson.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 95/449
D. A member of the board of trustees shall be appointed as the board of trustees' liaison to the historic preservation advisory board. The liaison will
attend regular board meetings and be the conduit of bidirectional information to and from the board of trustees. The liaison is not a member of
the historic preservation advisory board nor is the liaison entitled to a vote. (Ord. 28-2010, 11-23-2010)
Chapter 4
OPEN SPACE AND TRAILS ADVISORY BOARD
3-4-1: BOARD CREATED; MEMBERSHIP; QUALIFICATIONS; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created an open space and trails advisory board for the town. The open space and trails advisory board shall consist of seven (7)
members. All seven (7) members shall be bona fide residents of the town. If any member shall cease to reside in the town, his or her membership
on the open space and trails advisory board shall immediately terminate. All members shall serve without compensation. Any nonresident member
duly appointed and currently serving on the open space and trails advisory board at the time of adoption hereof, may continue to serve as a
member of the open space and trails advisory board until his or her term expires. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
3-4-2: APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE; REMOVALS:
A. Appointment:
1. All members of the open space and trails advisory board shall be appointed as at large members by the board of trustees.
2. The temporary appointment of members shall be made by the board of trustees at a regular board meeting held within thirty (30) days from
the effective date hereof. The term of the temporary members shall terminate at the next regular town election. The initial appointment of
members shall take place at the regular meeting of the board of trustees first following the next regular town election.
3. Vacancies occurring other than through the expiration of the term of the member shall be filled for the remainder of that member's term by
appointment by the board of trustees.
4. Members of the open space and trails advisory board may be reappointed at the discretion of the board of trustees.
B. Terms Of Office: The term of office for each member appointed shall be as follows:
1. The first four (4) members appointed to serve as initial members of the open space and trails advisory board shall each be appointed for a
four (4) year term.
2. The next three (3) members appointed to serve as initial members of the open space and trails advisory board shall each be appointed for a
two (2) year term.
3. Appointments made following the expiration of the initial terms, as set forth in subsections B1 and B2 of this section, shall each be for a term
of four (4) years. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
C. Removal From Office: The board of trustees may, by a majority vote of those present, remove any member of the open space and trails
advisory board for the following reasons: 1) a conflict of interest violation; 2) any violation of law, regulation, or policy; 3) nonattendance to duty;
4) failure to attend three (3) consecutive regularly scheduled meetings without a leave of absence approved by a majority of the open space
and trails advisory board; 5) being a plaintiff or being actively involved or participating in a lawsuit against the town; or 6) any other cause. (Ord.
01-2010, 1-12-2010)
3-4-3: OFFICERS AND COMMITTEES:
A. Officers Enumerated: The open space and trails advisory board shall elect its chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary from among the full
membership of the open space and trails advisory board. The terms of the chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary shall be for one year.
B. Election Of Officers: The election of officers shall be held at the first regular meeting of the open space and trails advisory board held after
appointment of the members as provided in section 3-4-2 of this chapter. If no appointments are necessary, then the election shall be held at
the first regular meeting of the open space and trails advisory board held after one year from the date of the prior election of officers.
C. Vacancies In Office:
1. A vacancy in the office of chairperson shall be filled automatically by the vice chairperson, and a new vice chairperson shall be elected at the
next regular meeting of the open space and trails advisory board from among the remaining members.
2. A vacancy in the office of vice chairperson or secretary shall be filled at the next regular meeting of the open space and trails advisory board
from among the remaining members.
3. The officer elected to fill an irregular vacancy in the offices of chairperson, vice chairperson or secretary shall serve until the next following
election as provided for herein.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 96/449
D. Committees: The board of trustees, alone, may appoint ad hoc committees from among the members of the open space and trails advisory
board. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
3-4-4: MEETINGS, ORGANIZATION AND RULES:
A. Regular Meetings: The open space and trails advisory board shall hold regularly scheduled monthly meetings on the second Monday of each
month at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. in the town hall, unless alternative dates, times, or places are approved by the open space and trails
advisory board. The board shall hold a minimum of six (6) meetings per year. The board shall determine the yearly schedule of meetings and
provide such schedule to the town clerk for publication.
B. Special Meetings: The open space and trails advisory board may call for special meetings in accordance with rules adopted.
C. Open Meetings: All meetings shall be open to the public.
D. Quorum: A quorum shall be one-half (1/2) of the total number of actual members of the open space and trails advisory board, rounded up to the
nearest whole. No meeting shall be held without a quorum.
E. Public Input: The public attending an open space and trails advisory board meeting shall be allowed to address the open space and trails
advisory board prior to the open space and trails advisory board's consideration of regular business items. Persons wishing to address the
open space and trails advisory board shall state their name and address for the record.
F. Presiding Officer:
1. The chairperson shall preside at all regular, special or adjourned meetings of the open space and trails advisory board, and shall, subject to
the rules of the board, decide all points of procedure.
2. The vice chairperson shall assume the duties and responsibilities of the chairperson in the event the chairperson is absent or unable to
perform.
3. When both the chairperson and the vice chairperson are absent, those members present shall select a member by a majority vote to preside
over the meeting.
G. Conduct Of Meetings: Conduct of all meetings shall be pursuant to rules of conduct as adopted by the board of trustees. The open space and
