trails advisory board shall adopt bylaws, which bylaws may be amended from time to time by a majority vote of both the open space and trails
advisory board and a majority vote of the town board of trustees.
H. Voting Requirements:
1. A majority vote of the members present is required for all recommendations, determinations, and elections. Such a majority vote shall be
presented to the board of trustees as an advisory opinion of the open space and trails advisory board. A minority opinion may also be
submitted to the board of trustees.
2. All members, inclusive of the chairperson, are eligible to vote on any item.
3. Any open space and trails advisory board member shall request of the chairperson to be excused from any discussion or vote on any matter
in which the member feels there is a personal conflict of interest.
I. Minutes And Records: The open space and trails advisory board shall keep minutes of its meetings and records of its transactions, which shall
be publicly available. Such minutes and records shall be turned over to the town clerk for keeping. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
3-4-5: DUTIES:
The duties of the open space and trails advisory board are as follows:
A. To advise the board of trustees, by written report, in connection with matters relating to the planning, acquisition, development, maintenance
and management of open space and trails throughout the Erie planning area.
B. To promote and encourage the development, public awareness and proper use of open space and trails throughout the Erie planning area.
C. To coordinate with Boulder and Weld Counties and neighboring jurisdictions in the identification and acquisition of open space and trails.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 97/449
D. To assess open space and trail related provisions of the town's plans and ordinances, and if determined to be necessary, recommend, by
written report, amendments to the board of trustees.
E. To recommend, by written report, grants or other sources of funding for open space acquisition and trail development.
F. To promote open space and trails awareness at town events or at the request of interested individuals or groups.
G. To perform such other functions associated with open space and trails as the board of trustees may from time to time direct.
H. To perform such other duties as may be directed by the board of trustees from time to time.
I. To make recommendations, by written report, to the board of trustees on the expenditure of the receipts from the trails, natural areas and open
space tax created by ordinance 02-2004. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
3-4-6: RELATIONSHIP TO BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND TOWN STAFF:
A. The open space and trails advisory board shall advise and recommend to the board of trustees exclusively on those matters pertinent to open
space and trails.
B. The open space and trails advisory board shall biannually prepare a written report which shall then be presented orally to the board of trustees
at a board of trustees meeting, with the first report and presentation occurring after the first of the year and the second prior to the start of the
town's budget consideration for the following year.
C. Staff will be available to attend open space and trails advisory board meetings quarterly at the request of the open space and trails advisory
board chairperson.
D. A member of the board of trustees shall be appointed as the board of trustees' liaison to the open space and trails advisory board. The liaison
will attend regular board meetings and be the conduit of bidirectional information to and from the board of trustees. The liaison is not a member
of the open space and trails advisory board, nor is the liaison entitled to a vote. (Ord. 03-2008, 1-8-2008)
Chapter 5
SUSTAINABILITY ADVISORY BOARD
3-5-1: BOARD CREATED; MEMBERSHIP; QUALIFICATIONS; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created a Sustainability Advisory Board for the Town. The Sustainability Advisory Board shall consist of seven (7) members. All
seven (7) members shall be bona fide residents of the Town. If any member shall cease to reside in the Town, his or her membership on the
Sustainability Advisory Board shall immediately terminate. All members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 14-2018, 3-27-2018)
3-5-2: APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE; REMOVALS:
A. Appointment:
1. All members of the Sustainability Advisory Board shall be appointed as at large members by the Board of Trustees.
2. The temporary appointment of members shall be made by the Board of Trustees at a regular Board meeting held within thirty (30) days from
the effective date hereof. The term of the temporary members shall terminate at the next regular Town election. The initial appointment of
members shall take place at the regular meeting of the Board of Trustees first following the next regular Town election.
3. Vacancies occurring other than through the expiration of the term of the member shall be filled for the remainder of that member's term by
appointment by the Board of Trustees.
4. Members of the Sustainability Advisory Board may be reappointed at the discretion of the Board of Trustees.
B. Terms Of Office: The term of office for each member appointed shall be as follows:
1. The first four (4) members appointed to serve as initial members of the Sustainability Advisory Board shall each be appointed for a four (4)
year term.
2. The next three (3) members appointed to serve as initial members of the Sustainability Advisory Board shall each be appointed for a two (2)
year term.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 98/449
3. Appointments made following the expiration of the initial terms, as set forth in subsections B1 and B2 of this section, shall each be for a term
of four (4) years.
C. Removal From Office: The Board of Trustees may, by a majority vote of those present, remove any member of the Sustainability Advisory Board
for the following reasons: 1) a conflict of interest violation; 2) any violation of law, regulation, or policy; 3) nonattendance to duty; 4) failure to
attend three (3) consecutive regularly scheduled meetings without a leave of absence approved by a majority of the Sustainability Advisory
Board; 5) being a plaintiff or being actively involved or participating in a lawsuit against the Town; or 6) any other cause. (Ord. 14-2018, 3-27-
2018)
3-5-3: OFFICERS AND COMMITTEES:
A. Officers Enumerated: The Sustainability Advisory Board shall elect its Chairperson, Vice Chairperson and Secretary from among the full
membership of the Sustainability Advisory Board. The terms of the Chairperson, Vice Chairperson and Secretary shall be for one year.
B. Election Of Officers: The election of officers shall be held at the first regular meeting of the Sustainability Advisory Board held after appointment
of the members as provided in section 3-5-2 of this chapter. If no appointments are necessary, then the election shall be held at the first regular
meeting of the Sustainability Advisory Board held after one year from the date of the prior election of officers.
C. Vacancies In Office:
1. A vacancy in the Office of Chairperson shall be filled automatically by the Vice Chairperson, and a new Vice Chairperson shall be elected at
the next regular meeting of the Sustainability Advisory Board from among the remaining members.
2. A vacancy in the Office of Vice Chairperson or Secretary shall be filled at the next regular meeting of the Sustainability Advisory Board from
among the remaining members.
3. The officer elected to fill an irregular vacancy in the Offices of Chairperson, Vice Chairperson or Secretary shall serve until the next following
election as provided for herein.
D. Committees: The Board of Trustees, alone, may appoint ad hoc committees from among the members of the Sustainability Advisory Board.
(Ord. 14-2018, 3-27-2018)
3-5-4: MEETINGS, ORGANIZATION AND RULES:
A. Regular Meetings: The Sustainability Advisory Board shall hold at least one regular meeting in the Town Hall in each month. The board shall
determine the yearly schedule of meetings and provide such schedule to the Town Clerk for publication. Alternative dates, times, or places may
be approved by the Sustainability Advisory Board, as long as notice of such meetings is posted and such meetings are held in public places.
The board shall hold a minimum of six (6) meetings per year.
B. Special Meetings: The Sustainability Advisory Board may call for special meetings in accordance with rules adopted.
C. Open Meetings: All meetings shall be open to the public.
D. Quorum: A quorum shall be one-half (1/2) of the total number of actual members of the Sustainability Advisory Board, rounded up to the nearest
whole. No meeting shall be held without a quorum.
E. Public Input: The public attending a Sustainability Advisory Board meeting shall be allowed to address the Sustainability Advisory Board prior to
the Sustainability Advisory Board's consideration of regular business items. Persons wishing to address the Sustainability Advisory Board shall
state their name and address for the record.
F. Presiding Officer:
1. The Chairperson shall preside at all regular, special or adjourned meetings of the Sustainability Advisory Board, and shall, subject to the
rules of the board, decide all points of procedure.
2. The Vice Chairperson shall assume the duties and responsibilities of the Chairperson in the event the Chairperson is absent or unable to
perform.
3. When both the Chairperson and the Vice Chairperson are absent, those members present shall select a member by a majority vote to
preside over the meeting.
G. Conduct Of Meetings: Conduct of all meetings shall be pursuant to rules of conduct as adopted by the Board of Trustees. The Sustainability
Advisory Board shall adopt bylaws, which bylaws may be amended from time to time by a majority vote of both the Sustainability Advisory
Board and a majority vote of the Town Board of Trustees.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 99/449
H. Voting Requirements:
1. A majority vote of the members present is required for all recommendations, determinations, and elections. Such a majority vote shall be
presented to the Board of Trustees as an advisory opinion of the Sustainability Advisory Board. A minority opinion may also be submitted to
the Board of Trustees.
2. All members, inclusive of the Chairperson, are eligible to vote on any item.
3. Any Sustainability Advisory Board member shall request of the Chairperson to be excused from any discussion or vote on any matter in
which the member feels there is a personal conflict of interest.
I. Minutes And Records: The Sustainability Advisory Board shall keep minutes of its meetings and records of its transactions, which shall be
publicly available. Such minutes and records shall be turned over to the Town Clerk for keeping. (Ord. 14-2018, 3-27-2018)
3-5-5: DUTIES:
The duties of the Sustainability Advisory Board are as follows:
A. To advise the Board of Trustees, by written report, in connection with matters relating to the planning, development, maintenance and
management of sustainability activities throughout the Erie planning area.
B. To create a sustainability master plan with the support of the Town staff to be reviewed and approved by the Board of Trustees, updating it every
five (5) years, or sooner if needed. The initial sustainability master plan shall be created by the Sustainability Advisory Board on or prior to
December 31, 2019.
C. To occasionally survey the community to understand local perspectives on the progress of sustainable activities and the desires for additional
sustainable activities.
D. To promote and encourage the development, public awareness and proper use of sustainability activities throughout the Erie planning area.
E. To coordinate with Boulder and Weld Counties and neighboring jurisdictions, Town staff and other Erie boards and commissions/committees in
the identification and promotion of sustainability activities.
F. To assess sustainability related provisions of the Town's plans and ordinances, and if determined to be necessary, recommend, by written report,
amendments to the Board of Trustees.
G. To recommend, by written report, grants or other sources of funding sustainability activities.
H. To promote sustainability awareness at Town events or at the request of interested individuals or groups.
I. To perform such other functions associated with sustainability as the Board of Trustees may from time to time direct.
J. To perform such other duties as may be directed by the Board of Trustees from time to time. (Ord. 14-2018, 3-27-2018)
3-5-6: RELATIONSHIP TO BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND TOWN STAFF:
A. The Sustainability Advisory Board shall advise and recommend to the Board of Trustees exclusively on those matters pertinent to sustainability.
B. The Sustainability Advisory Board shall biannually prepare a written report which shall then be presented orally to the Board of Trustees at a
Board of Trustees meeting, with the first report and presentation occurring after the first of the year and the second prior to the start of the
Town's budget consideration for the following year.
C. Staff will be available to attend Sustainability Advisory Board meetings quarterly at the request of the Sustainability Advisory Board
Chairperson.
D. A member of the Board of Trustees shall be appointed as the Board of Trustees' liaison to the Sustainability Advisory Board. The liaison will
attend regular board meetings and be the conduit of bidirectional information to and from the Board of Trustees. The liaison is not a member of
the Sustainability Advisory Board, nor is the liaison entitled to a vote. (Ord. 14-2018, 3-27-2018)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 100/449
Title 4
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 29-2019 - REGISTRATION OF UNIT OWNERS' ASSOCIATIONS. Go to new

Chapter 1
SOLICITATION PERMITS
4-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
CRIME OR ACTS AGAINST THE PROPERTY OF ANOTHER: Theft, burglary, breaking and entering, larceny, and other similar felonies involving
moral turpitude.
CRIMES OR ACTS OF VIOLENCE AGAINST THE PERSON OF ANOTHER: Homicide, attempted homicide, rape, attempted rape, sexual
assault, assault, battery, and other similar felonies involving moral turpitude by whatever name.
SOLICITATION: To enter or remain upon any private property in the Town, not having been requested or invited by the occupants thereof, for the
purpose of contacting said occupants to solicit the immediate or future purchase or sale of goods, services or any other thing of value, or to solicit
a gift or donation of any kind; provided, however, that solicitation does not include political canvassing, political advocacy, or religious proselytizing.
(Ord. 07-2019, 3-26-2019)
4-1-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in solicitation in the Town without first obtaining a solicitation permit as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 07-2019, 3-26-2019)
4-1-3: APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE:
A. Application: Each applicant for a solicitation permit shall file with the Town Clerk an application including the following information, in addition to
the application fee established by resolution of the Board of Trustees:
1. The full name, residence address, mailing address, and telephone number of the applicant;
2. A description of the applicant, including height, weight, eye color, and hair color;
3. The number and state of issuance of any state-issued identification card issued to applicant, including a state motor vehicle operator's
license or chauffeur's license;
4. A brief explanation of the nature of the merchandise to be sold or other activity requiring a solicitation permit under this chapter; and
5. An authorization for the Town Clerk to conduct a background check of the applicant.
B. Grounds For Denial: Unless the Town Clerk finds grounds for denial, the Town Clerk shall issue the solicitation permit within seven (7) days of
receipt of a complete application. The Town Clerk may deny the application for the following reasons:
1. Failure to comply with any provision of this Code;
2. Felony convictions for crimes against the person or property of another, or institutionalizations for mental illness which caused acts of
violence against the person or property of another; provided, however, that such felony convictions or institutionalizations occurred within five
(5) years preceding the date of application; or
3. Convictions of any crime committed while engaged in solicitation in the Town.
C. Notice And Appeal: If the Town Clerk denies the application, the Town Clerk shall notify the applicant in writing, stating the reasons for the
denial, and shall mail such notice by regular United States mail to the address provided on the application. Within seven (7) days of the date of
mailing such notice, the applicant may file a written request for an appeal to the Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees shall hear and
decide such appeal within thirty (30) days of receipt of the appeal request. At the appeal, the applicant shall be entitled to be heard and present
evidence.
D. Permits Nontransferable: Permits may not be transferred from person to person.
E. Expiration: Each permit shall expire one year from the date of issuance.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 101/449
F. Revocation: If, after issuance of a permit, the Town Clerk finds that any of the grounds stated in subsection B of this section exist, the Town
Clerk shall revoke the permit and provide written notice to the permittee of such action. The permittee may appeal the Town Clerk's decision in
the manner set forth in subsection C of this section. (Ord. 07-2019, 3-26-2019)
4-1-4: DOOR HANGERS:
A. No person, other than the Town or its designees, shall fasten or deposit in any manner any notice, poster, or other advertising or promotional
material upon private property, including personal property, without having permission to do so from the owners or occupants of such property.
Permission to so fasten or deposit such materials shall be implied from the presence of an improved walkway, including a driveway, connecting
such property directly to a public right-of-way, unless:
1. Access to such walkway is physically restricted by a fence, gate, or other permanent structure; or
2. A "No Trespassing" or "No Solicitors" sign or a sign conveying a similar message is posted on the property at a visible location. (Ord. 07-
2019, 3-26-2019)
4-1-5: PERMISSIBLE TIMES:
Solicitation is prohibited before eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. or after the later of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. or sunset, as announced and published by the
National Weather Service daily. (Ord. 07-2019, 3-26-2019)
4-1-6: "DO NOT SOLICIT" LIST:
A. Any owner or occupant of private property in the Town may prohibit solicitation at such property by registering the property on the Town's "Do
Not Solicit" list pursuant to this section.
B. The registration shall contain the following information:
1. The full name of the person filing the form, and whether such person is an owner, occupant, or both;
2. The property address; and
3. A list of individuals or groups who are not subject to the solicitation prohibition.
C. If the owner or occupant filing the form ceases to be the owner or occupant of the property, the registration shall expire; otherwise, it shall
remain in effect until modified by the owner or occupant.
D. Properties on the "Do Not Solicit" list shall be listed only by address, and the name of the person filing the form shall not be included. (Ord. 07-
2019, 3-26-2019)
4-1-7: NO SOLICITATION SIGNS:
A. In addition to or in lieu of registration on the Town's "Do Not Solicit" list, any person may post a sign on his or her property indicating that the
owners or occupants do not wish to be disturbed by door-to-door solicitation. Such sign shall state, "No Trespassing", "No Solicitors", or other
similar message indicating that door-to-door sales are not authorized.
B. Such sign shall not exceed two and one-half (21/2) square feet in area.
C. Such sign shall be allowed in addition to the number and types of signs permitted by the Unified Development Code.
D. Solicitation at any property at which such a sign is posted is a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 07-2019, 3-26-2019)
4-1-8: CARRYING OF PERMIT AND IDENTIFICATION:
Each permittee shall carry on his or her person the solicitation permit and personal identification at all times while engaging in solicitation, and shall
present such identification and permit upon request of any person. (Ord. 07-2019, 3-26-2019)
4-1-9: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
It is unlawful to violate any provision of this chapter. Any violation of this chapter is deemed to be a criminal violation, and upon conviction, the
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 102/449
penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4B of this Code shall apply. (Ord. 07-2019, 3-26-2019)
Chapter 2
AMUSEMENTS
4-2-1: POOL HALLS; GAME ROOMS; RESTAURANTS:
A. Authority To Grant Licenses Or Permits; Term; Conditions: The town board of trustees may grant such number of licenses or permits for a
period of not to exceed one year to such persons as shall comply with the requirements of this section. (1928 Code, part IV)
B. Application For License Or Permit: Any person desiring to carry on the business of temperance hall, restaurant, pool or billiard or card room, or
any room where any game of chance or skill, or any gaming device whatsoever is carried on shall present and file with the town clerk and the
state, a written application, stating particularly the name of the applicant or applicants, or if a firm or partnership, the name or names of the
partners composing the same, together with the name and style of the said partnership or firm, the kind and nature of the said business
proposed to be carried on and the premises or place where the same is to be conducted, giving the location and number of rooms if more than
one, which said application shall be signed by a majority of the property owners on both sides of the street adjoining the block where the same
is to be carried on, requesting that a permit or license be issued to the person named in such application at the place and premises therein
designated, and when such premises or proposed place of business shall happen to be on the corner of any block, then such application
aforesaid shall be signed by a majority of the property owners half way in such block and on each side thereof from such corner.
C. License Fee: The town board of trustees shall not entertain or consider any such application until such applicant shall deposit with the town
clerk the sum as provided in section 2-10-2 of this code upon the receipt of which it is made the duty of the clerk to endorse on such application
that such applicant has deposited with him said sum, the same being the license fee for which such application is made, and if there be more
than one room in which such business is to be carried on, then there is required an additional sum as provided in section 2-10-2 of this code for
each and every other room so to be used for such business, to be deposited in addition to the sum first above mentioned; said sum when so
deposited shall be the payment of such permit or license fee for the period of one year granted, and if for any reason the same be not granted
or is refused, then the clerk shall, on demand and tender of receipt of such applicant so depositing the same, return to said party the sum so
placed on deposit. (1928 Code, part IV; amd. Ord. 756, 8-14-2001; 2004 Code)
D. Issuance Of License Or Permit; Form: In case the application is allowed and granted by the town board of trustees, then it shall be the duty of
the clerk to issue and deliver to such applicant a permit or license to carry on such business, which shall be substantially in the following form:
Town of Erie, Colorado, , 20
To All Whom It May Concern:
Be It Known, That the Board of Trustees of the Town of Erie, in the State of Colorado, on receipt of , the receipt of which is hereby
acknowledged, have and do hereby license and empower to pursue and carry on the business of at and in the building and premises known as
consisting of rooms, situate on Street, in the said Town of Erie, State of Colorado, from the day of , A.D. 20 , to the day of , A.D. 20 , both days
inclusive, under and subject to such regulations and restrictions as are now or may hereafter be provided by the ordinances of the said Town of
Erie, Colorado, in relation thereto.
Mayor
(Seal)
Attest:
Clerk
Upon the issuance of such permit or license as aforesaid, the clerk shall turn over to the town treasurer all monies so deposited with him by the
applicant therefor, and take his receipt or voucher therefor, which he shall file in his office, subject to the inspection of any officer of the town,
or other person having an interest therein. (1928 Code, part IV; amd. 2004 Code)
E. Transfer Of License Or Permit: The permit or license thus issued shall not be transferable or assignable to any other person, nor shall it allow or
authorize such person named to carry on such business therein designated at any other premises, room or rooms than are stated in such
permit or license and application therefor unless permission shall have been first had and obtained from the town board of trustees by a written
application, stating such facts and signed by such transferee or assignee, or in case of the change of rooms or the addition of rooms to the
premises which the said business is to be carried on by the original applicant in the same manner as in the case of an original application as
above set forth, in which event the said board of trustees shall have the power and authority to grant permission for such transfer, assignment
or change of rooms or premises as in the first instance. (1928 Code, part IV)
F. License Or Permit To Be Posted; Penalty: It shall be the duty of each and every person to whom the permit or license shall have been issued or
granted as aforesaid to post the same in some conspicuous place on the wall within the premises or place of business thus carried on by him
so as to permit easy access and inspection thereof by anyone desiring to inspect the same and especially by any police officer of the town, and
any person failing so to do or failing to show the same when so requested by any of the town officers or trustees shall be in violation of this
chapter. (1928 Code, part IV; amd. Ord. 489, 7-27-1995; 2004 Code)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 103/449
G. Days And Hours Of Operation: Each and every one of the proprietors or keepers, or any or either of them, of the places and premises
enumerated in this section, or any of the said game or games of skill or chance, or gaming device or game whatsoever, shall promptly and
punctually close their several places of business at eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. of the evenings of weekdays, and keep the same closed until
five o'clock (5:00) A.M. of the following day, and from eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Saturday evening until five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on the
following Monday morning. The same shall at all times be left closed during each and all of the said hours of closing, and no person, except the
proprietors or keepers, shall be permitted to go in or to remain around the same, but all and every other person shall be expelled or put out of
the same at the time named. If it shall appear that any person not employed in and about such place of business has been permitted to be in or
around any such place during the time herein prohibited, such fact shall be prima facie evidence in favor of the guilt of the accused party. (1928
Code, part IV; amd. 2004 Code)
H. Certain Persons Prohibited:
1. Minors And Drunkards Prohibited: Any person being the proprietor or keeper of any of the places or kinds of businesses mentioned and
contemplated, either with or without a license therefor, obtained in the manner as herein provided, who shall permit any minor or habitual
drunkard to frequent or to be in or about the said premises or place of business, or to procure or drink any spirituous, malt or vinous liquors in
or about the same, or to participate in any of the game or games carried on in the said premises or place of business, or in any game of pool,
billiards, cards, or any other game of skill or chance whatsoever, either with or without betting, shall be in violation of this chapter. (1928
Code, part IV; amd. Ord. 489, 7-27-1995; 2004 Code)
2. Sign Requirements: Each and every proprietor or keeper of any of the places or premises herein enumerated or contemplated within the
terms or provisions of this section, or any of the game or games, or any gaming device, whatsoever, which shall be carried on within the
corporate limits of the town shall and are hereby required to make and place in every room a sign, with letters not less than two inches (2") in
height and of corresponding proportions, so as to be plainly legible and seen from any part of the room in which the same is placed, and
containing the following words: "No Minor or Habitual Drunkard Allowed Here", which sign may be printed on cardboard, or any other suitable
substance, capable of making the said sign permanent and easily read, and which must be so placed as to attract notice, and any person,
either the proprietor or keeper of any of the places or premises, failing to comply with the requirements of this subsection, shall be in violation
of this chapter. (1928 Code, part IV; amd. 2004 Code)
I. Gambling Prohibited: Nothing in this section shall be held or construed to allow or permit any game or gaming, or any sort or species of
gambling, at any place within the corporate limits of the town in violation of any law or statute now or hereafter in force within the state, the
intention of this section being only to regulate and control all such games of chance or skill as are permitted by the laws of the state and in
conformity with the said laws, and for no other purpose. (1928 Code, part IV)
4-2-2: BILLIARD TABLES, OTHER GAMES, AND SHOOTING GALLERIES:
A. License Required: It shall not be lawful for any person to carry on the business of keeper, for gain or hire, within this town, any billiard table,
bagatelle table, pigeonhole table, shuffleboard, pin alley, shooting gallery, or any table on which games are played with balls, without a license
therefor first obtained according to the provisions of this section. (1928 Code, part IV)
B. License Fee: For a license, for one year, to keep any table mentioned in subsection A of this section, the amount as provided in section 2-10-2
of this code shall be paid. No license shall be issued for any table or game mentioned in subsection A of this section until the fee therefor is
paid. (1928 Code, part IV; amd. Ord. 756, 8-14-2001)
C. Enforcement: It shall be the duty of the chief of police to see that the provisions of this section are strictly enforced. (1928 Code, part IV; amd.
2004 Code)
4-2-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code. (2004 Code)
ARTICLE A. AMUSEMENT DEVICES
4-2A-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
MUSIC BOX: A coin operated device for the reproduction of music, or any mechanical or electrical device for which the listener is required to pay
for the privilege of choosing and listening to a certain musical selection or series of selections.
PERSON: Includes every natural person, company, corporation, copartnership or other business organization.
PINBALL GAME: A game which conforms to the following basic principles of operation: a game or amusement device contained in a rectangular
box with a glass top and is released for operation when a coin is deposited in the machine, so that small balls are made available for play. These
balls are propelled by a plunger operated by the player, and each ball so propelled moves and behaves according to the manner in which the
plunger is manipulated by the player and eventually drops in one of a number of holes in the surface upon which it has been traveling; these holes
are protected by greater or lesser hazards, and the object of the game is to direct the ball so that it will drop in the more difficult hole by skillful
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 104/449
manipulation of the plunger. The machines exit no money, slugs or any article of any kind, and the player receives no reward from any source
either in merchandise, prizes, money or anything whatsoever, other than the amusement and pleasure derived from playing the game. (Ord. 157,
5-4-1953)
4-2A-2: LICENSES REQUIRED:
All persons are hereby prohibited from keeping, operating or leasing, for gain or hire, any "pinball game", "music box" or other similar amusement
device, as defined in section 4-2A-1 of this article, within the town, unless such persons shall have first obtained a license therefor in accordance
with the provisions of this article and shall comply with the other provisions hereof. No person operating or keeping any such pinball game, music
box or other similar amusement device shall lease or rent the same from any person who does not have a license to lease such games or devices
within the town. (Ord. 157, 5-4-1953; amd. 2004 Code)
4-2A-3: LICENSE FEES:
A. Operation Of Amusement Devices: For a license for one year to keep, maintain or operate any pinball game, music box or similar amusement
device, the location operator shall pay to the town clerk the fee as provided in section 2-10-2 of this code.
B. Dealers In Amusement Devices: Any dealer or owner of pinball games, music boxes or other similar amusement devices who shall lease or rent
the same for operation within the town shall pay to the town clerk the sum as provided in section 2-10-2 of this code as a license fee for the
privilege of renting or leasing such games or mechanisms within the town. The foregoing license fee does not include the license fee herein
provided for the operation of each specific pinball game, music box or other similar amusement device, but covers only the right to lease or rent
pinball games, music boxes or similar amusement devices within the town. (Ord. 157, 5-4-1953; amd. Ord. 756, 8-14-2001)
4-2A-4: ANNUAL LICENSE; PAYMENT OF FEE:
All licenses provided for herein shall be upon a calendar year basis and shall be due and payable on January 1 in each year, payable in advance
at the town hall. (Ord. 157, 5-4-1953; amd. 2004 Code)
4-2A-5: LICENSE TO BE POSTED:
The license for the operation of a pinball game, music box or similar amusement device shall be conspicuously posted upon the machine or
mechanism. (Ord. 157, 5-4-1953)
4-2A-6: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE; EXPIRATION:
The licenses issued under this article shall not be transferable, except as specified herein, and shall expire on January 1 each year, and no
deduction in license fee shall be allowed for a fractional part of a year. (Ord. 157, 5-4-1953)
4-2A-7: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
A. Gambling: It shall be unlawful to permit betting, wagering or gambling of any kind upon the result of any pinball game.
B. Prizes And Awards: No slugs, coin or merchandise awards of any kind shall be given to the player of any pinball game, music box or similar
amusement device. (Ord. 157, 5-4-1953)
4-2A-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
A. Standards For Revocation: All licenses issued hereunder shall be revocable by the board of trustees for breach of any of the provisions of this
article. In the event that a pinball machine, music box, or other similar amusement device shall be so constructed as to permit a violation of this
article by the giving of coins, slugs, merchandise or an award of any kind to the player, the license of the owner thereof to lease or operate
machines within the town may be revoked by the board of trustees.
B. Notice Of Revocation; Hearing; Fees Nonrefundable: In the event that a license is revoked as aforesaid, the board of trustees shall give to the
holder of such license notice of its intention to revoke the same and an opportunity to be heard before the board of trustees on the date
specified in the said notice. In the event of the revocation of any such license, the holder thereof shall be entitled to no refund for the unexpired
period of such license. (Ord. 157, 5-4-1953)
4-2A-9: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the terms and provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 105/449
punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code. (Ord. 157, 5-4-1953; amd. Ord. 437, 10-22-1992; Ord. 489, 7-27-1995; 2004 Code)
ARTICLE B. SPECIAL EVENTS
4-2B-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
All special events, races, festivals, or similar exhibitions, parades, processions or open air meetings conducted within the Town shall be required to
obtain a permit from the Town prior to commencing such activities. This requirement shall not apply to such activities as private parties, community
group functions, church activities, etc., that are conducted solely on private property; except, that such activities shall be conducted in compliance
with all applicable ordinances of the Town, applicable regulations imposed by the Counties of Boulder and/or Weld, and applicable laws of the
State. (Ord. 03-2017, 2-14-2017)
4-2B-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Permit application forms may be obtained from the Town Clerk or designee. All applications must be properly completed and submitted to the Town
Clerk or designee at least sixty (60) days prior to the date the activity is to occur or a permit may not be issued due to a lack of proper review and
evaluation time. (Ord. 03-2017, 2-14-2017)
4-2B-3: FEE AND DEPOSIT:
A. Fee: The fee as provided in section 2-10-2 of this Code shall be paid by the applicant to the Town at the time an application is submitted to the
Town Clerk or designee. Failure to pay the required fees will be grounds for the Town Clerk or designee to declare the application incomplete.
B. Deposit: Deposit may be required at the time of application submittal; deposit amount shall be determined on a case-by-case basis considering
the nature of the activity to be conducted; except, that no deposit shall be less than fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 03-2017, 2-14-2017)
4-2B-4: PENALTY:
Any person found to be in violation of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord.
353, 8-8-1985; amd. Ord. 437, 10-22-1992; 2004 Code)
Chapter 3
HANDBILL DISTRIBUTORS1
4-3-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person not having a regularly established place of business or operation within the corporate limits of the town to
directly or indirectly pass, distribute or circulate any printed or written handbills, posters, dodgers or other advertising matter without first having
obtained a license so to do from the town clerk. (Ord. 113, 8-1-1943; amd. 2004 Code)
4-3-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Every person applying for such license shall file with the clerk his permanent address and, if a corporation, shall give the state where it is
incorporated and, if a firm, association or partnership, the names and addresses of its members and shall pay for such license charge or fee as
provided in section 2-10-2 of this code, which license shall give the person obtaining the same the privilege of distributing his advertising matter for
the period designated in such license; provided, however, that no charitable or nonprofit organization or enterprise shall be required to pay any
license fee but shall be required to give to the clerk the name and address of its officers or promoters. (Ord. 113, 8-1-1943; amd. Ord. 756, 8-14-
2001; 2004 Code)
4-3-3: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punishable as
provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code. (Ord. 113, 8-1-1943; amd. 2004 Code)
Chapter 4
JUNK DEALERS
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 106/449
4-4-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Every person engaged or engaging in the business of purchasing or selling old iron, rags, bottles, bones or junk of any kind or nature whatsoever,
within the town, shall first obtain from the town clerk, a license to carry on said business. (Ord. 155, 4-6-1953)
4-4-2: LICENSE FEE:
For a license to carry on said business of buying or selling old iron, bottles, rags, bones or junk of any kind and nature whatsoever, there shall be
paid to the town the sum as provided in section 2-10-2 of this code, payable in advance. (Ord. 155, 4-6-1953; amd. Ord. 756, 8-14-2001)
4-4-3: FENCE REQUIREMENTS; PEST CONTROL:
Every such person as defined in section 4-4-1 of this chapter shall be required to surround and enclose said junkyard with a solid fence of board,
sheet metal or other construction approved by the town board. Such fence or enclosure shall be of the height of eight feet (8') but not to exceed
ten feet (10') and shall be tight against the ground. It shall be painted and kept painted and in good condition and repair. Licensee shall keep such
yard in a clean and healthy condition and shall exterminate all rats, mice, rodents, insects or other harmful or disease bearing objects. Failure so to
do, upon notice by the town board to such licensee, shall be grounds for revocation of license and such other penalties as are provided in this
chapter. (Ord. 155, 4-6-1953)
4-4-4: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Whoever shall violate the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punishable as
provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code. (Ord. 155, 4-6-1953; amd. 2004 Code)
Chapter 5
BUILDING CONTRACTORS
4-5-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
A. Permits Issued To Licensed Contractor: On any work requiring a licensed or registered contractor, permits under this chapter shall be issued
only to the contractor or registrant or to his authorized representative.
B. Fraudulent Use Of License Or Registration: It shall be unlawful for any person to fraudulently use a license or registration issued to a contractor
or registrant under this chapter to obtain permits for another person.
C. Failure To Obtain Required Permit Or Inspection: It shall be unlawful for a contractor to fail to obtain inspection services when the same are
required, or to fail to obtain a permit when it is required. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
D. Responsibility For Contracted Work:
1. A contractor shall be responsible for all work included in his contract, whether or not such work is done by him directly or by a subcontractor.
He shall be responsible for all funds or property received by him for completion of a specific contract, or for a specific purpose.
2. It shall be unlawful for any contractor licensed or registered under this chapter to abandon any contract or undertaking, or to make material
departure from the plans and specifications for any contract or undertaking submitted in writing to the building department without good
cause.
E. General Safety Standards:
1. All state laws, provisions of this chapter, or other town ordinances dealing with measures for the safety of workmen and the public shall be
observed by contractors and/or registrants within the town.
2. It shall be unlawful for a contractor to be careless or negligent in implementing minimum safety measures, including appliances, apparatus,
and equipment, to protect workmen and the public. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995; amd. 2004 Code)
4-5-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS; COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS; PREREQUISITES:
A. Licenses Required; Exemptions:
1. Licenses shall be required for all types of work specified in section 4-5-10 of this chapter, unless otherwise stated, and shall be classified in
accordance with the provisions of said section 4-5-10. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 107/449
2. Any person performing work on a single-family dwelling which he owns and occupies is exempt from the licensing requirements. (2004
Code)
B. Compliance With Provisions: All licenses enumerated in section 4-5-10 of this chapter shall be issued in accordance with the terms and
provisions of this chapter and other town ordinances, and shall be subject to the supervisory clauses contained in section 4-5-7 of this chapter.
C. Prerequisites: Any licenses, registrations, or other lawful requirements imposed upon an applicant for a contractor's license or registration under
this section and sections 4-5-3 through 4-5-12 of this chapter, other ordinances of the town, or laws of the state, shall be deemed prerequisites
to the issuance of such license or registration. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
4-5-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES AND REGISTRATIONS:
A. Form: Applications for contractors' licenses and/or registrations shall be on such forms and shall furnish such information as the building official
prescribes. The building official shall receive and sign all applications for licenses and/or registrations set out in section 4-5-10 of this chapter.
B. Review Standards: The building official shall review applicants for licenses and/or registrations issued under sections 4-5-2 through 4-5-12 of
this chapter. The standard to be applied in the conduct of such review shall be the protection of the public health, welfare, and safety of the
people of the town, so that those who are recommended to be licensed or registered under this chapter are financially and morally responsible
and qualified, in terms of their skills, knowledge, and practical experience, to contract for or to do the work for which they seek to be licensed.
Applicants who are so qualified shall be licensed and/or registered as provided in sections 4-5-2 through 4-5-12 of this chapter. (Ord. 486, 7-13-
1995)
4-5-4: EXAMINATIONS:
A. Examinations Required:
1. The building official may, before approving any application for a license required by subsection 4-5-2A of this chapter, require the applicant to
take a written or oral examination; licensed electrical and plumbing contractors are excepted from this requirement. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995;
amd. 2004 Code)
2. The building official may, at his discretion, set standards for the examining requirements, so long as they do not conflict with any provision of
this chapter.
3. The building official shall limit the examination requirements to areas applicable to the license being sought.
B. Exemptions: All persons who have been previously licensed by the town under the provisions of sections 4-5-2 through 4-5-12 of this chapter, to
engage in the trades, jobs, or contractual services, shall not be required to be examined; provided, however, that all persons must hold a
license issued by the state, if required by the state, before engaging in any trade, job, or contractual service within the town limits. (Ord. 486, 7-
13-1995)
4-5-5: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE OR REGISTRATION:
If, in the opinion of the building official, the applicant for a license or registration required by sections 4-5-2 through 4-5-12 of this chapter is
qualified by training or experience to fulfill the obligations of a contractor, and is financially and morally responsible, he shall issue the applicant a
license or registration upon payment of the annual fee prescribed in section 4-5-11 chapter. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
4-5-6: TERM OF LICENSES AND REGISTRATIONS; RENEWALS:
A contractor's license or registration issued under the provisions of sections 4-5-2 through 4-5-12 chapter shall terminate on the last day of the
calendar year in which it was issued, and may be renewed any time prior to the expiration date by payment of the annual license fee prescribed by
section 4-5-11 of this chapter. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
4-5-7: QUALIFIED SUPERVISOR TO EXEMPT LICENSEE FROM CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS:
Except as otherwise specifically provided, all licenses enumerated in section 4-5-10 of this chapter shall be issued under authority of and in
accordance with the terms and provisions of this section and shall be subject to the supervisory clauses contained in this section.
A. Qualified Supervisor Required: Licensees and/or registered electrical contractors, whether individuals, firms or corporations, shall not be
required to possess those skills and qualifying experience records required for the work they are permitted to do under the terms and
provisions of their respective licenses; provided, that they retain in their business a supervisor whose skills and qualifying experience record
are such that he would be qualified to do all work in his principal's license category. The licensees' or registrants' right to do business shall be
dependent upon the continued retention of the designated supervisors in an active, full time capacity. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 108/449
B. Procedure Upon Termination Of Supervisor: Whenever a designated supervisor terminates his connection with a licensee or registrant or
otherwise becomes inactive, the licensee or registrant shall immediately notify the building official. In such event, the license or registration
shall be deemed to be suspended, and there shall be a thirty (30) day grace period in order to acquire a proper supervisor before complete
termination of the license or registration. Should the supervisor be replaced, or should his connection with the business of the licensee or
registrant be renewed, such fact shall be made known to the building official. If the proposed replacement has been found by the building
official to meet the qualifications imposed by this section, the license shall again be deemed in full force and effect without imposition of an
additional license or registration fee for the same calendar year. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995; amd. 2004 Code)
C. Review Of Supervisor; Supervisor Designated In Application: Each individual who is to act as a supervisor shall be reviewed in accordance with
the provisions of sections 4-5-2 through 4-5-12 of this chapter for the work proposed to be done. Each individual who is to act as a supervisor
shall be designated as such in each application for a license or registration. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
4-5-8: PERMITS:
A. Prerequisites To Permit Issuance: No permit shall be issued to any contractor who has not first obtained a license as required by subsection 4-
5-2A of this chapter, or who is delinquent in the payment of his annual fee, or whose license or registration has been suspended or revoked by
action of the building official. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995; amd. 2004 Code)
B. Permit Restricted To Certain Work: Licensed contractors or registrants may apply for and be issued permits to do only such work as they are
entitled to do under their respective licenses or registrations.
C. Fraudulent Application: Any application for a permit, license, or registration filed in derogation of this section shall be deemed to have been filed
with fraudulent intent and shall be a nullity. Any permit, license, or registration issued on the basis of such fraudulent application shall be null
and void.
D. Certain Permits Exempt From Contractor's License Or Registration:
1. Table 3-A of the 1997 uniform building code as adopted by the town1, may be used as a reference for occupancy classifications. Any
individual who owns and occupies a group R, division 3 building, or U-1 building may make application for a permit to erect, construct,
enlarge, alter, repair, improve, convert, or demolish such building, and shall be excepted from the license or registration requirement of
subsection 4-5-2A of this chapter; provided, that such individual does not erect or construct more than one of the building occupancies
mentioned in this subsection per every two (2) years, and does not enlarge, alter, repair, improve, or convert more than one of the building
occupancies mentioned in this subsection more often than one per year. (Ord. 486. 7-13-1995; amd. 2004 Code)
2. Homeowners building or remodeling their own home shall not be required to have a contractor's license.
E. Processing And Issuance Of Permits: Applications under subsection D of this section shall be processed as are all other applications for
permits, and permits shall be issued only in accordance with those portions of the building, electrical, plumbing, gas fitting, warm air heating,
boiler, and pressure vessel regulations which relate to structural, technical, and safety requirements. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
4-5-9: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Insurance Required: Every contractor granted a license or registration under the terms of sections 4-5-2 through 4-5-12 of this chapter shall be
required to maintain at all times employees' liability and public liability insurance with minimum limits of not less than one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000.00) for one person, and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any one accident, and property damage insurance
with a minimum limit of not less than twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for any one accident.
B. Certificate Of Insurance: At the time application is made, and before a license or registration can be issued, the contractor shall file with the
building official a certificate signed by a qualified agent of an insurance company stating: that the policies required by subsection A of this
section have been issued to the licensee for employees' liability or worker's compensation insurance, public liability insurance, and public
property damage insurance; the minimum limits of each; the policy numbers; the name of the company; the effective dates of the policies; and
the expiration dates of the policies, together with a statement and a copy of an endorsement placed on each policy requiring ten (10) days'
written notice by registered mail to the building official if it becomes necessary to cancel the policy for any reason.
C. Cancellation Of Insurance: In the event of a cancellation of a policy, the licensee or registrant shall be required to furnish a new certificate in full
compliance with the terms of this section within the ten (10) day period; otherwise, the license or registration shall be automatically revoked.
The license or registration shall be reinstated when the licensee or registrant has furnished a certificate of insurance in compliance with this
section, unless such license is suspended for reasons other than the failure to file a proper certificate of insurance. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995)
4-5-10: CLASSES OF LICENSES:
A. Appliance License:
1. Definition: As used in this subsection, the term "appliance" refers to any appliance whose installation would be subject to the regulations set
out in this chapter, the uniform building code, the national electrical code, and the uniform plumbing code as adopted by the town.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 109/449
2. Scope Of License: An appliance license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and install appliances, as defined in subsection A1 of
this section, where the installation of such appliance requires a permit under this chapter, or under other town ordinances governing the
contracting for and installation of appliances.
3. Exemptions From License: Holders of plumbing, electrical, warm air heating, steam heating, and gas fitting licenses are not required to hold
appliance licenses to install domestic appliances.
B. Builder's Licenses:
1. Class A License: A builder's license, class A, shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of building or contracting for, or
altering or adding to the structural portions of any building, structure, or portion thereof of type I, II, III, IV, or V construction in any and all
occupancy group classifications where such work requires the issuance of a permit under this chapter or other town ordinances. All such
work shall be done in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter and all other town and state laws governing the same. A
builder's license, class A, shall entitle the licensee to contract for and do necessary demolition and wrecking work in connection with the work
specified in this subsection.
2. Class B License: A builder's license, class B, shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of building or contracting for, or
altering or adding to structural portions of buildings, structures, or portions thereof of types III, IV, and V construction in the occupancy
classification, group R, division 3, where the floor area of any individual structure does not exceed three thousand (3,000) square feet.
3. Class C License: A builder's license, class C, shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of altering or adding to structural
portions of buildings, structures, or portions thereof of types III, IV, and V construction in the group R, division 3 occupancy classification,
where the floor area of any individual structure does not exceed three thousand (3,000) square feet.
C. Concrete And Form License:
1. Scope Of License: A concrete and form license shall entitle the individual holder thereof to contract for and install forms for concrete
products and to pour and finish concrete products and to mix concrete products, subject to the following limitations:
a. All concrete work is to be done in accordance with chapters 18, 19, and 21 of the uniform building code, as adopted by town ordinance.
b. All concrete and form work on types I, II, III, IV, and V structures over one thousand (1,000) square feet shall be under the supervision of a
holder of a builder's license, class A, B, or C.
2. Exemptions From License: Holders of a class A, B, or C builder's license need not have a concrete and form license to do the work referred
to under this subsection. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995; amd. 2004 Code)
D. Electrical License: All electrical licenses are the responsibility of the Colorado electrical board. A registration fee as provided in section 2-10-6 of
this code per year will be required from all state-licensed electrical contractors working within the town. All other provisions of this chapter will
apply. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995; amd. Ord. 756, 8-14-2001)
E. Excavating License:
1. Scope Of License: An excavating license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to do the work of cutting into public rights of way,
and excavating into the public right of way and on private property within the town. The holder of an excavating license shall be subject to the
provisions in the town ordinance controlling excavations, and the uniform building code as adopted by the town.
2. Exemptions From License: The holders of a license under any other section of this chapter shall not be required to be licensed under this
subsection, but shall be subject to the provisions of this subsection.
F. Gas Fitter's License:
1. Scope Of License: A gas fitter's license shall entitle the individual holder thereof to install all gas piping, fittings, controls, burners, and
venting on all gas fired, oil fired, and liquefied petroleum fired appliances in accordance with the uniform mechanical code and the uniform
building code as adopted by the town.
2. Exemptions From License: Holders of plumber's licenses, class A, B or C, steam heating licenses, class A or B, or heating, cooling and
ventilating licenses may do the work of a gas fitter without holding a gas fitter's license.
3. License Required: No person may install gas piping, fitting controls, burners, or venting on gas fired, oil fired and liquefied petroleum fired
appliances unless he is specifically licensed as mentioned under this subsection.
G. House And Building Mover's License: The holder of a house and building mover's license shall be permitted to contract for and engage in the
moving of structures within, into and out of the town limits, subject to the following limitations:
1. New structural alterations, additions, and foundation work are to be done by the holder of a builder's license, class A, B, or C.
2. Plumbing work necessary in moving and relocating the structure is to be done by the holder of a plumbing license.
3. Electrical work necessary in moving and relocating the structure is to be done by the holder of an electrical license.
H. Masonry License:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 110/449
1. Scope Of License: A masonry license shall entitle the individual license holder to erect, construct, alter, or demolish chimneys, fireplaces,
walls, and pilasters, and to do other work on a building composed of masonry units in accordance with the uniform building code, as adopted
by town.
2. Exemptions From License: Holders of builder's licenses, class A, B, or C, need not have a masonry license to do the work referred to under
this subsection.
I. Plumber's Licenses:
1. Master License: A master plumber's license, shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to install all sanitary plumbing and potable
water supply piping for which a permit is required under the provisions of this chapter, other town ordinances, and state laws governing the
same.
2. Journeyman License: A journeyman plumber's license, shall entitle the individual holder thereof to install all sanitary plumbing and potable
water supply piping for which a permit is required under the terms and provisions of this chapter, other town ordinances, and state laws
governing the same. Licensees under this subsection I2 may perform the work which they are licensed to do only under the supervision or in
the employ of a master plumber licensee.
3. Number Of Unlicensed Employees Restricted: No more than two (2) unlicensed plumber's helpers may be employed for each licensed
master or journeyman license holder without the prior consent of the building official.
J. Steam Heating Licenses:
1. Scope Of License: A steam heating license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to install high pressure and low pressure steam
and hot water heating systems, processing pipes, and similar commercial hot water and water vapor systems, and heating or steam power
systems where the installation of such requires a permit under the provisions of this chapter or other town ordinances governing the same.
2. Restrictions On Unlicensed Employees:
a. No person who engages in the installation of heating work shall employ unlicensed helpers unless under the direct supervision of a license
holder.
b. No more than two (2) unlicensed steam heating helpers may be employed for each license holder without the prior consent of the building
official.
K. Heating, Cooling And Ventilation License: A heating, cooling and ventilation license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and install
heating, cooling and ventilation and their appurtenances. All work shall be performed only in accordance with the uniform mechanical code. All
electrical work shall be performed by a holder of an electrical license.
L. Wrecker's License: A wrecker's license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract and engage in the demolition of existing structures. All work
connected with wrecking and demolishing structures shall be done in accordance with the uniform building code, as adopted by the town.
M. Special Contractor's License: A special contractor's license shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of a particular trade or
job connected with the building industry excluding the licenses enumerated in subsections A through L of this section. Such special contractor's
license shall be limited to the trade or particular kind of work specified in the license, and such other work as may be incidental thereto. (Ord.
486, 7-13-1995; amd. 2004 Code)
4-5-11: LICENSE FEES:
The annual license fees applicable to the licenses required and enumerated in sections 4-5-2 through 4-5-10 of this chapter shall be as provided in
section 2-10-6 of this code. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995; amd. Ord. 756, 8-14-2001)
4-5-12: SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSE OR REGISTRATION:
A. Hearing: The building official may, upon the verified complaint in writing of any person, require any person licensed or registered under this
chapter to appear and show cause why the contractor's license should not be suspended or revoked.
B. Authority To Revoke Or Suspend: The building official shall have the power to temporarily suspend or permanently revoke a license or
registration if the holder thereof is found to have committed one or more of the acts prohibited in this chapter. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995; amd. 2004
Code)
4-5-13: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any contractor licensed or registered under the provisions of this chapter to violate any provision of this chapter, or to violate
or refuse to obey any order issued, or neglect to pay any fee assessed, under authority of this chapter. Any person violating the terms or conditions
of this chapter or any provision of applicable state law is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punishable as provided in
title 1, chapter 4 of this code. (Ord. 486, 7-13-1995; amd. Ord. 489, 7-27-1995; 2004 Code)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 111/449
Chapter 6
OIL AND GAS REGULATIONS
(Rep. by Ord. 36-2007, 11-27-2007)
Chapter 7
COMMERCIAL DEPOSIT OF SEWAGE SLUDGE
4-7-1: SEWAGE SLUDGE ACTIVITIES PROHIBITED:
A. Business Receiving: The receiving of sewage sludge for deposit on or in any place within or within one mile of the town limits, which place, as a
part of its business, receives sewage sludge for a consideration, is hereby prohibited.
B. Business Sending: The sending of sewage sludge for deposit to a place within or within one mile of the town limits, which place, as a part of its
business, receives sewage sludge for a consideration, is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 496, 1-11-1996)
4-7-2: PENALTIES:
Any person in violation of this chapter may be punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code. Each occurrence of sending and/or
receiving sewage sludge shall constitute a separate violation of this chapter. (Ord. 496, 1-11-1996; amd. 2004 Code)
Chapter 8
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
4-8-1: LOCAL LICENSING AUTHORITY PROCEDURES ESTABLISHED:
The local licensing authority procedures are hereby established. (Ord. 797, 9-24-2002)
4-8-2: LICENSING AUTHORITY:
A. Authority Established; Authority Generally: There is established a local licensing authority, which shall have and is vested with the authority to:
grant or refuse licenses and special permits for the sale at retail of malt, vinous or spirituous liquors and fermented malt beverages; designate
and assess fees; promulgate reasonable rules and regulations, as provided by law; conduct investigations as are required by law; and to
suspend or revoke such licenses for cause in the manner provided by law. Such authority shall have all the powers of the local licensing
authority as set forth in Colorado Revised Statutes title 12, articles 46, 47 and 48, as may have been amended or repealed and reenacted from
time to time.
B. Municipal Judge Serve As Licensing Authority: The local licensing authority for the Town shall be the Municipal Court Judge. (Ord. 797, 9-24-
2002)
4-8-3: DUTIES OF TOWN CLERK:
A. The Town Clerk shall receive all applications for licenses and shall issue all licenses granted by the local licensing authority upon payment of
fees required and upon approval of the appropriate licensing authority.
B. The Town Clerk shall serve as the official Secretary of the authority and shall designate a person or persons to provide the necessary notice of
meetings, and secretarial and reporting services for the authority. The Secretary shall keep the electronic recordings of all licensing authority
hearings. The Secretary shall transcribe or make arrangement for transcription of such records whenever required for appeals or otherwise.
(Ord. 797, 9-24-2002)
4-8-4: HEARINGS:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 112/449
A. The authority shall hold hearings at such times as may be required to consider licensing functions or matters relating to the establishment of
rules and regulations, procedural considerations or other matters permitted of the local licensing authority by State law.
B. The Town Clerk shall schedule local licensing authority hearings by notifying the authority as to any matter requiring the authority to act
pursuant to law. Otherwise, the authority may schedule meetings at her or his discretion and initiative in accordance with procedures
established for the licensing authority.
C. All decisions of the local licensing authority are final, subject only to appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 797, 9-24-2002)
4-8-5: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
The local licensing authority shall be governed by State law now in effect or subsequently amended, and the rules and regulations of the Executive
Director of the Department of Revenue of the State, as the State licensing authority, which shall apply to the licensing of fermented malt beverages
and malt, vinous and spirituous liquors within the Town, where applicable. In the event of a conflict between the Colorado laws and any provisions
set forth in this chapter, the state law, rule or regulation shall prevail. (Ord. 797, 9-24-2002)
4-8-6: LICENSE FEES:
Before the authority considers an application, the applicant shall pay the following fees to the town clerk:
A. All fees specified and set in an amount pursuant to Colorado Revised Statutes title 12, articles 46, 47 and 48, as amended, repealed and
reenacted from time to time1.
B. Application fees for fermented malt beverage and alcoholic beverage licenses set by the authority to cover the actual and necessary expenses
to the town of such application, subject to the limitations expressed by state law as to the maximum amounts which may be charged in
conjunction with applications.
C. Application fees set by the authority in conjunction with special event permits for both investigation and issuance of such permits, subject to the
limitations on fee amounts set forth in state law. (Ord. 797, 9-24-2002)
4-8-7: POWERS REGARDING SALE OF FERMENTED MALT BEVERAGES:
The local licensing authority shall have the power to make reasonable rules and regulations with respect to the sale of fermented malt beverages
as provided by Colorado Revised Statutes title 12, article 46, as amended, repealed and reenacted from time to time. (Ord. 797, 9-24-2002)
4-8-8: FINGERPRINTING:
The police department shall record the fingerprints of each applicant for a new liquor license and all employees of such licensee dispensing
alcoholic beverages. The fingerprints shall become and remain a permanent part of the record of the license applicant. (Ord. 797, 9-24-2002)
4-8-9: LICENSE RENEWALS:
A. Application For Renewal: Application for the renewal of an existing license shall be made to the town clerk not less than forty five (45) days, and
to the state licensing authority not less than thirty (30) days, prior to the date of expiration.
B. Approval Of Application: The town clerk may approve the renewal application, if there have been no liquor violations over the previous twelve
(12) months.
C. Action When Violations Have Occurred: If the applicant/establishment has any liquor violations, the local licensing authority may cause a
hearing on the application for renewal to be held. No renewal hearing provided for by this subsection shall be held by the local licensing
authority until a notice of hearing has been conspicuously posted on the licensed premises for a period of ten (10) days and notice of the
hearing has been provided the applicant at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing. The licensing authority may refuse to renew any license for
good cause, subject to judicial review. Any renewal hearing held by the state licensing authority shall be pursuant to Colorado Revised Statutes
section 12-47-305 (2). (Ord. 797, 9-24-2002)
4-8-10: OPTIONAL PREMISES AND OPTIONAL PREMISES WITH HOTEL/RESTAURANT LICENSES:
A. Standards Adopted: The following standards for the issuance of optional premises licenses or for optional premises for a hotel and restaurant
license are hereby adopted pursuant to the provisions of Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-310:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 113/449
1. Standards Are Additional: These standards adopted herein shall be considered in addition to all other standards applicable to the issuance of
licenses under the Colorado liquor code for the optional premises license or for optional premises for a hotel and restaurant license. These
two (2) types of licenses for optional premises will collectively be referred to as "Optional Premises" in these standards unless otherwise
provided.
2. Eligible Facilities:
a. An optional premises may only be approved when that premises is located on or adjacent to an outdoor sports and recreational facility as
defined in Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-103(22)(a). The types of outdoor sports and recreational facilities which may be
considered for an outdoor premises license include the following:
(1) Country clubs;
(2) Golf courses and driving ranges;
(3) Ice skating arenas;
(4) Mini-golf course;
(5) Swimming pools; and
(6) Outdoor tennis courts and clubs.
b. There are no restrictions on the minimum size of the outdoor sports and recreational facilities which may be eligible for the approval of an
optional premises license. However, the Erie liquor licensing authority may consider the size of the particular outdoor sports or recreational
facility in relation to the number of optional premises requested for the facility, and may deny any optional premises application if it
considers the related facility to be too small to require an optional premises.
3. Number Of Optional Premises: The Erie liquor licensing authority, in its discretion, may restrict the number of optional premises which any
one licensee may have. Any licensee requesting approval of more than one optional premises shall:
a. Explain the reason for each optional premises requested;
b. Demonstrate how the optional premises relate to each other from an operational standpoint;
c. Demonstrate to the satisfaction of Erie liquor licensing authority the need for each optional premises in relation to the outdoor sports and
recreational facility and its guests; and
d. Demonstrate that the optional premises will not adversely affect the neighborhood in which it is located.
4. Submittal Requirements: When submitting a request for the approval of an optional premises initially, and annually thereafter, an applicant
shall also submit the following:
a. An application fee per optional premises and the local and state license fees2.
b. A map or other drawing illustrating the outdoor sports or recreational facility boundaries and the approximate location of each optional
premises requested.
c. A legal description of the approximate area within which the optional premises shall be located.
d. A description of the method which shall be used to identify the boundaries of the optional premises when it is in use.
e. A description of the provisions which have been used to identify and control the optional premises when it is in use. For example, the
applicant may describe the types of signs, fencing or other notices or barriers to be used in order to control the optional premises.
B. Advance Notification: Pursuant to Colorado Revised Statutes title 12, section 12-47-310(3) and (4), no alcoholic beverages may be served on
an optional premises without the licensee having provided written notice to the state and the Erie liquor licensing authority.
C. Notice And Hearing Procedures: The notice, standards and hearing procedures of the town and the Colorado liquor code shall be used. (Ord.
803, 2-11-2003)
4-8-11: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE TASTINGS:
Pursuant to section 12-47-301(10)(a), Colorado Revised Statutes, the town of Erie hereby authorizes alcoholic beverage tastings for licensed retail
liquor stores and liquor licensed drugstores within the town. The town shall not require a further application prior to allowing retail liquor licensees
or liquor licensed drugstores to conduct alcoholic beverage tastings. At least seventy two (72) hours prior to conducting an alcoholic beverage
tasting in accordance with this section, the licensed retail liquor store or liquor licensed drugstore shall notify the town clerk of the intended date,
location and hours of such alcoholic beverage tasting. (Ord. 17-2010, 7-27-2010)
4-8-12: PERMIT; CONSUMPTION OF FERMENTED MALT BEVERAGES:
A. Permit Specifications: The local licensing authority may, upon the filing of the necessary permit application with the office of the town clerk,
issue a permit for the consumption of fermented malt beverages (as defined at section 6-9-1 of this code), by persons twenty one (21) years of
age or older, at an event to be held in a town park or recreation facility. If issued, the permit shall specify the date and time of the event and the
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 114/449
authorized possession and consumption of fermented malt beverage, and the location of the event where such possession and consumption is
authorized.
B. Criteria For Issuance Of Permit: The local licensing authority may approve an open container permit if the application for the open container
permit meets all of the following criteria:
1. The time, location and duration of the event does not interfere with public services.
2. The number and concentration of participants at the event will not result in crowds exceeding limitations in town codes, or other significant
inconvenience to the residents of the surrounding neighborhoods.
3. Underage persons and persons under the influence of alcohol will not obtain fermented malt beverages served at the event, and the
precautions proposed are likely to secure and supervise the area and the participants during the event.
