Chapter 7
OFFENSES RELATED TO ANIMALS
6-7-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the general population of the Town. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004
Code)
6-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
ANIMAL: Any live vertebrate creature, domestic or wild.
AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE: Includes police or animal control officers employed by the Town.
CAT: Any live or dead member of the species Felis catus, regardless of sex.
DOG: Any live or dead member of the species Canis familiaris, regardless of sex.
DOMESTIC ANIMAL: Includes all species of animals commonly and universally accepted as being tame or domesticated.
KEEPER: A person who has custodial or supervisory authority or control over an animal.
PET: Includes dogs, cats, rabbits, rodents, birds, reptiles and any other species of animal which is sold or retained as a household pet but shall not
include skunks, nonhuman primates and any other species of wild, exotic or carnivorous animal.
RUN AT LARGE: Off the premises of the owner or keeper, not restrained by means of an adequate leash and under the control of the owner or
keeper, or other competent person. For purposes of this definition, the premises of the owner shall not include common areas of condominiums,
townhouses, and apartment buildings, and any animal not restrained by means of an adequate leash and in direct control of its owner or keeper
upon the common area of a condominium, townhouse or apartment building, or the grounds thereof, shall be deemed to be running at large.
A dog shall not be deemed to be running at large when the dog is within the enclosed confines of a Town designated dog park.
VICIOUS ANIMAL: An animal that bites or attacks a human or another animal, or approaches a human in an apparent attitude of attack, whether
or not an attack actually occurs.
WILD ANIMAL: Includes all species of animals which commonly exist in a natural, unconfined state and are usually not domesticated. This shall
apply regardless of state or duration of captivity. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. 07-2016, 2-23-2016)
6-7-3: DOGS:
A. Licensing Requirements:
1. License Required: Any person harboring, owning, possessing or keeping any dog six (6) months of age or older within the Town for any
consecutive fourteen (14) day period, or longer, shall secure a license for such dog from the Town Clerk and pay the license fee therefor.
(Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
2. Tag And Collar: A metal tag shall be furnished as license identification with each license, bearing the number of the license. The license tag
shall be attached to the collar worn by the animal so licensed, unless a microchip containing identifying information of the owner has been
placed in the animal by a licensed veterinarian.
3. Expiration Of License: Each license shall be for the term of the rabies vaccination administered to each individual dog, for a term of one year
or three (3) years. (Ord. 09-2014, 2-25-2014)
4. Nontransferability Of License: Licenses and symbols of license identification under this subsection are not transferable.
5. Importation Period; Time Limit: Any dog brought into the Town or adopted shall comply with this subsection within thirty (30) days of
importation or adoption. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6. License Fee: The annual license fee shall be as provided in section 2-10-8 of this Code. The fee shall apply for any full year or part thereof
and shall not be refunded for any reason. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. Ord. 726, 10-10-2000)
B. Rabies Vaccination Required: It is unlawful for any person to own, keep, harbor, or possess any dog over the age of six (6) months which has
not been vaccinated against rabies. The owner of any dog shall have the animal vaccinated by a licensed veterinarian by six (6) months of age,
and shall keep the vaccinations current. The vaccines used will be ones licensed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture and approved by the
Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment and will provide for at least a one year duration of immunity. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
C. Restraint And Control: No owner or keeper shall allow his dog to "run at large", as that term is defined in this chapter. Every owner or keeper of
a dog shall keep such dog exclusively upon his own premises; provided that such dog may be off such premises if it is under the control of a
competent person who is able to control the dog, and restrained by a leash not exceeding fifteen feet (15') in length and in a manner as to not
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 147/449
have access to any passerby. Any owner or keeper with a dog at a designated dog park shall be governed by the provisions at section 6-7-9,
"Dog Parks", of this chapter. (Ord. 07-2016, 2-23-2016)
D. Prohibited Acts And Conditions:
1. Noise: It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper of any dog to fail to prevent the animal from disturbing any person by barking, howling,
yelping or making any other audible sound. No summons shall be issued and no person shall be convicted at trial for violating this subsection
D1 unless a minimum of two (2) witnesses from separate households testify about the nature of the barking, howling, yelping, or other
audible sound. A police officer or Code Enforcement Officer may corroborate the elements of this subsection D1 and may issue the
summons and testify as a second witness. (Ord. 06-2006, 2-7-2006)
2. Damaging Property1: It shall be unlawful for any owner, possessor, or person who keeps any dog to permit such dog to destroy or damage
the real or personal property of any person, or any public property of the Town. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-7-4: IMPOUNDMENT OF ANIMALS:
A. Animal Shelter: Animals impounded under the provisions of this chapter shall be placed in a designated animal shelter. The Town may provide
by contract with any public agency, private society or association, or animal hospital, for the establishment, maintenance and operation of such
animal shelter.
B. Impoundment:
1. An Erie police officer or Code Enforcement Officer is authorized to seize and impound any animal under the following circumstances:
a. Where the animal is running at large;
b. When the officer has probable cause to believe that an animal constitutes an immediate danger to any person, other animal or the
community;
c. In any case where the owner or keeper responsible for the care of the animal is incapacitated or otherwise not available to provide for the
animal's welfare;
d. Any animal suspected of having bitten any person or other domestic animal. In such case the animal shall be impounded for a period of
ten (10) days or until released by the Chief of Police or designee. At the discretion of the police officer or Code Enforcement Officer, the
animal may be ordered quarantined at the owner or keeper's residence if the animal can be securely contained and the animal will be
available for observation during and after the quarantine period. It is unlawful for any owner or keeper of a quarantined animal to fail to
keep such animal exclusively upon the property of the owner or keeper during the quarantine period;
e. When a police officer/Code Enforcement Officer has probable cause to believe that the animal has acted in an aggressive manner as that
is defined in section 6-7-10 of this chapter, or has engaged in conduct that constitutes an animal attack, as defined in section 6-7-11 of this
chapter, and the officer believes that during the pending criminal case or pending hearing regarding surrender of the animal, the animal
constitutes an immediate danger to any person(s), other animal(s) or the community. At the discretion of the officer, the animal may be
ordered quarantined at the owner or keeper's residence if the animal can be securely contained and will not be removed from the property
until such time as released by the officer or order of the court. It is unlawful for any owner or keeper of a quarantined animal to fail to keep
such animal exclusively upon the property of the owner or keeper during the quarantine period.
2. As soon as practical after impoundment, a bona fide effort shall be made to give notice of impoundment to the owner. If, after a bona fide
effort to locate the owner, he or she cannot be identified and the animal is not claimed within five (5) days, the ownership of the animal is
deemed to transfer to the animal shelter then in possession of said animal. If the owner is identified and the impounded animal is not claimed
by its owner within five (5) days, the animal may be disposed of at the sole discretion of the animal shelter.
C. Claiming Impounded Animals: Any animal impounded pursuant to this section shall be released to the owner upon payment of the impound fee,
boarding fee, veterinary care charges, and any other costs associated with the impound. If the owner of an unclaimed animal is known, such
owner shall be responsible for any costs incurred related to the impoundment, keeping or disposal of the animal.
D. Emergency Medical Treatment: Any police officer or animal control officer may, at such officer's discretion, take an injured animal found
unattended and off of the owner or keeper's premises to a licensed veterinarian for emergency medical treatment. The owner shall be liable for
payment of all such emergency treatment. Payment of medical fees may be required before the animal is released to the owner.
E. Proof Of Ownership: A valid rabies tag worn by any animal shall be presumptive evidence that the owner of the animal is the person registered
as obtaining the rabies vaccination for such animal. (Ord. 25-2019, 8-27-2019)
6-7-5: INSPECTION POWERS:
Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this chapter, or whenever the Chief of Police or his authorized
representative has probable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any animal, which is infected with rabies, or is
being mistreated or neglected, the Chief of Police or his authorized representative may enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to
inspect the same, or to perform any duty imposed upon the Chief of Police by this chapter; provided that, if such building or premises be occupied,
he shall first present proper credentials and request entry, and if such building or premises be unoccupied, he shall first make a reasonable effort
to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of the building or premises and request entry. If such entry is refused, or the owner
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 148/449
or person having control cannot be located, the Chief of Police or his authorized representative shall have recourse to every remedy provided by
law to secure entry. No owner or occupant or any other person having charge, care or control of any animal shall fail or neglect to promptly permit
entry therein by the Chief of Police or his authorized representative for the purpose of inspection and examination pursuant to a warrant regularly
issued. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
6-7-6: DOGS HABITUALLY AT LARGE:
Any dog found running at large on three (3) or more occasions in any twelve-month period may be impounded by an Erie police officer or Code
Enforcement Officer at the animal shelter. Any such dog shall be held until a fact-finding dispositional hearing can be held in the Municipal Court to
determine its proper disposition. The dispositional hearing can take place notwithstanding any court action against any person who has been
charged with a violation of subsection 6-7-3C of this chapter. (Ord. 25-2019, 8-27-2019)
6-7-7: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
A. Prohibited: No person shall:
1. Overdrive, overload, drive when overloaded or overwork any animal;
2. Beat, mutilate or torture any animal;
3. Needlessly shoot at, wound, capture or in any other manner needlessly molest, injure or kill any animal;
4. Carry, transport or keep in a cruel manner any animal.
B. Defense: It is a specific defense to a charge of violating subsection A of this section that the action was necessary to avoid injury to a person or
that the animal was not a domesticated animal and the action was necessary to avoid injury to a person or property.
C. Care: It is unlawful for any person to fail to provide an animal owned or in the custody of such person with adequate food, water, protection from
the elements, veterinary services, humane care and treatment necessary to maintain the good health of the animal and to prevent suffering of
the animal, or other care generally considered to be normal, usual and accepted for the animal's health and well being consistent with the
species, breed, and type of animal.
D. Removal Of Animal: Where there is reasonable suspicion to believe that an animal(s) is being mistreated or neglected, as described in
subsection A or C of this section, an animal control officer or police officer may enter the premises and remove and impound the animal(s).
"Premises", as used in this subsection, is defined to include the land and structures thereon, not to include the residence.
E. Warrant: Where an animal(s) is located in the residence and is not otherwise accessible, and an animal control officer or police officer has
probable cause to believe that the animal(s) is being mistreated or neglected, as described in subsection A or C of this section, to the extent
the life of the animal(s) is endangered, an animal control officer or police officer may enter the residence for the purpose of removing and
impounding the animal(s) upon the issuance of a warrant issued by an appropriate court for such purpose.
F. Owner Responsible For Charges: The owner or keeper of the impounded animal(s) shall be responsible for all charges incurred in impounding
the animal.
G. Notification: Upon impounding the animal(s) the Police Department shall make all reasonable efforts to notify the owner or keeper of the
impoundment. If attempts to notify the owner or keeper of the impoundment in person or by telephone are unsuccessful, notice may be made
by posting written notification of the impoundment at the premises from which the animal(s) was removed.
H. Disposition Of Impounded Animal:
1. When an animal has been seized and impounded pursuant to the provisions of this section, upon motion of the Town Prosecutor, the
Municipal Court may enter an order of forfeiture of the animal if the court finds that there is a continuing threat to the health and welfare of the
animal in the event the animal is returned to the owner or keeper.
2. A copy of the prosecutor's motion for forfeiture, along with notice of the hearing, shall be personally served on the owner or keeper, or mailed
first class mail to the last known address of the owner or keeper at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing.
3. The Town shall bear the burden of proof at the hearing, by a preponderance of the evidence. If the owner or keeper, without good cause,
fails to appear at the hearing, the animal shall be deemed abandoned and, upon proper proof of the need for forfeiture, may be ordered
forfeited.
4. The owner or keeper of the animal shall have the rights afforded defendants in judicial proceedings including the right to be represented by
counsel, the right to cross examine the Town's witnesses, and the right to compel the attendance of witnesses. The defendant shall not have
the right to a jury trial on the issue of forfeiture.
5. The hearing shall be conducted as an administrative hearing and the rules of evidence shall not be binding. Any and all documentary
evidence deemed relevant by the Municipal Judge may be received in evidence. The Municipal Judge shall have the power to determine that
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 149/449
the animal be further confined, to order that the owner or keeper take specific steps to provide for the health and welfare of the animal, or to
order that the owner or keeper forfeit ownership of the animal, which shall then be surrendered to the appropriate animal shelter.
6. The owner or keeper of an animal that is the subject of a motion brought under this section shall be liable for the cost of the care, keeping,
transport, or disposal of the animal. In no event shall the Town of Erie or its employees, agents or staff be liable for such costs.
7. The Municipal Court in its discretion may order a forfeiture authorized by this section as an element of sentencing, as a condition of
probation, or as a condition of a deferred sentence.
8. The owner, possessor or keeper of an animal that has been impounded because of alleged neglect, abuse or cruelty shall post a bond in an
amount to be determined by the Police Department, to cover the estimated costs of the care and keeping of the animal from the date the
animal was taken into custody to the date of the hearing. Such bond shall be filed with the court within five (5) days of the date of written
notification of such bond to the owner, possessor, or keeper. In the event the owner, possessor, or keeper fails to post bond as required
herein, the animal shall be deemed abandoned, the hearing on the issue of forfeiture vacated, and the custody of the animal shall be
deemed transferred to the appropriate animal shelter.
9. If, in the opinion of a licensed veterinarian, the animal is experiencing extreme pain or suffering or is severely injured past recovery, severely
disabled past recovery, or severely diseased past recovery, the animal may be euthanized without a court order.
10. An animal that is not claimed by its owner, possessor or keeper within five (5) days after being eligible for release from impoundment
pursuant to this section, shall be deemed abandoned and may be disposed of at the discretion of the appropriate animal shelter. (Ord. 09-
2014, 2-25-2014)
6-7-8: ANIMAL EXCREMENT:
A. Actions Constituting Littering: It shall be unlawful for any owner, possessor, or person, who keeps any domestic animal, to permit any such
domestic animal to deposit or leave any fecal matter on any public or private property of another, or in any waters. It shall be an affirmative
defense to this subsection that in the event of the depositing of fecal matter by a domesticated animal, the animal is in the immediate control of
a person, and such person forthwith removes such material from the said private or public place. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
B. Offensive Premises: The accumulation of animal feces compromises public health and constitutes a threat to public safety and welfare. It is
unlawful for the owner or keeper of an animal to allow animal feces to accumulate so as to be a health hazard or so that the odor is noticeable
on adjoining property. Such premises are declared to be a public nuisance. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
6-7-9: DOG PARKS:
A. At any Town designated dog park, the owner or keeper of a dog may allow the dog to be at large off leash within the enclosed confines of the
dog park, subject to the requirements set forth in this section.
Any violation of this section is designated noncriminal in nature. Upon conviction, the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4A of this Code shall
apply.
1. Owners/keepers shall obey the hours and rules of the dog park as posted.
2. Owners/keepers shall keep their dogs on a leash held by a person able to control the dog(s) when entering and exiting the fenced enclosure
of the dog park.
3. Dogs must be accompanied by a competent person able to control the dog(s) when inside the dog park.
4. Owners/keepers shall not allow their dogs to aggressively chase or harass wildlife or other dogs. "Harass" as used herein includes, but is not
limited to, excessive barking or nipping, tackling or other aggressive behavior toward another dog.
5. Owners/keepers shall not leave their dog unattended at the dog park.
6. Owners/keepers shall promptly remove dog feces and dispose in the designated trash container at the dog park.
7. Owners/keepers shall not bring any of the following dogs into the dog park:
a. Vicious or aggressive dogs;
b. Female dogs in heat;
c. Dogs without a current rabies vaccination tag and Town license tag attached to the collar worn by the dog;
d. Dogs known to be ill or exhibiting signs of illness.
8. Any person who brings a dog to a dog park shall be considered the owner/keeper for purposes of this section.
9. Anyone entering a designated dog park assumes the risk of injury and property damage caused by their dogs to other dogs, other persons or
any of the facilities at the dog park. By entering the dog park, every person agrees to release the Town and its employees from liability for
injuries or property damage caused by any act or omission of the Town or its employees. The owner/keeper assumes liability for any injury or
property damage to persons or other dogs caused by their dog(s). (Ord. 07-2016, 2-23-2016)
6-7-10: AGGRESSIVE ANIMALS:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 150/449
A. Prohibited Conduct: It is unlawful to possess any animal which engages in any of the following conduct in the Town:
1. Inflicts a puncture wound, abrasion, or other wound upon a person or a domestic animal.
2. Without provocation, and without effective and immediate control, repeatedly snaps at or repeatedly lunges at, or approaches a person while
growling and snarling at such person in a threatening manner.
3. Without provocation, and without effective and immediate control, chases or runs at a person while snapping or biting, growling or snarling at
such person in a threatening manner.
B. Exception: For purposes of this section, no animal shall be deemed an aggressive animal by reason of having threatened or harassed a person
when such person was engaged in any of the following acts:
1. The unlawful entry into or upon the animal owner's or keeper's property where such animal is kept.
2. The unlawful entry into or upon the animal owner's or keeper's motor vehicle or other such vehicle wherein the animal is confined.
3. The attacking or molesting of a person.
C. Impoundment:
1. Pursuant to subsection 6-7-4B of this chapter, a police officer or Code Enforcement Officer may seize and impound an animal that acts in an
aggressive manner, as defined above.
2. It is unlawful for any owner of an animal subject to an impoundment under this section to fail to produce the animal, on demand of any Erie
police officer/animal control officer, for examination and impoundment. If the owner or keeper of any such animal willfully or knowingly
secrets or refuses to produce such animal, such act shall constitute a separate violation of this section.
3. The owner or keeper shall be responsible for payment of all fees, including impound fee, boarding fee, veterinary care charges, and any
other costs associated with the impoundment regardless of the results of any Municipal charges.
D. Violations Of This Section Are Criminal Violations: Upon conviction, the penalties in subsection 1-4-4B of this Code shall apply. In addition to
any sentence imposed, the court may order the owner or keeper of the animal to surrender the animal to the animal shelter. Upon such
surrender ownership of the animal shall be terminated. Disposition of the animal shall be at the sole discretion of the animal shelter. (Ord. 25-
2019, 8-27-2019)
6-7-11: ANIMAL ATTACKS:
A. Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person to own or keep an animal that:
1. Inflicts or causes bodily injury or serious bodily injury to a person, whether on or off the premises of the owner or keeper.
2. Inflicts or causes bodily injury or serious bodily injury upon a domestic animal or livestock or causes the death of any domestic animal or
livestock, whether on or off the premises of the owner or keeper.
B. Definitions: As used herein:
BODILY INJURY: Shall mean any physical injury that results in bruising, muscle tears, or skin lacerations requiring professional medical
treatment or any physical injury that requires corrective or cosmetic surgery.
LIVESTOCK: Shall include, but not be limited to, chickens, ducks, cows, goats, horses.
SERIOUS BODILY INJURY: Shall means any bodily injury which, either at the time of the actual injury or at a later time, involves a substantial
risk of death, a substantial risk of serious permanent disfigurement, a substantial risk of protracted loss or impairment of the function of any part
or organ of the body, or breaks, fractures, or burns of the second or third degree.
C. Defense: It shall be an affirmative defense to subsection A of this section if:
1. That, at the time of the attack, which caused serious bodily injury or bodily injury to a person, the victim of the attack was committing or
attempting to commit a criminal offense against the animal's owner or keeper or the property of the owner or keeper.
2. That, the person who was the victim of the attack by the animal tormented, provoked, abused, or inflicted injury upon the animal.
3. That, at the time of the attack by the animal, which caused bodily injury or serious bodily injury to, or the death of a domestic animal, the
domestic animal was attacking the animal or its owner/keeper.
D. Exception: The provisions of this section shall not apply to the following:
1. To any dog that is used by a police officer while engaged in the performance of officer's duties.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 151/449
2. To any dog that inflicts injury upon or causes the death of a domestic animal while the dog was working as a hunting dog, herding dog, or
predator control dog on the property of or under the control of the dog's owner and the injury or death was to a domestic animal naturally
associated with the work of such dog.
E. Impoundment Of Aggressive Animal:
1. Pursuant to subsection 6-7-4B of this chapter, a police officer/animal control office may seize and impound an animal that acts in an
aggressive manner, as defined above.
2. It is unlawful for any owner of an animal subject to an impoundment under this section to fail to produce the animal, on demand of any police
officer/animal control officer, for examination and impoundment. If the owner or keeper of any such animal willfully or knowingly secrets or
refuses to produce such animal, such act shall constitute a separate violation of this section.
3. The owner or keeper shall be responsible for payment of all fees, including impound fee, boarding fee, veterinary care charges, and any
other costs associated with the impoundment regardless of the results of any Municipal charges.
F. Violations Of This Section Are Criminal Violations: Upon conviction, the penalties in subsection 1-4-4B of this Code shall apply. In addition to any
sentence imposed, the court may order the owner or keeper of the animal to surrender the animal to the animal shelter. Upon such surrender
ownership of the animal shall be terminated. Disposition of the animal shall be at the sole discretion of the animal shelter. (Ord. 25-2019, 8-27-
2019)
6-7-12: DISPOSITIONAL HEARING:
A. When an animal has been impounded pursuant to section 6-7-6, "Dogs Habitually At Large", 6-7-10, "Aggressive Animals", or 6-7-11, "Animal
Attacks", of this chapter, the owner or keeper shall be entitled to a dispositional hearing.
B. The court shall provide written notice of the date and time of the dispositional hearing to the owner or keeper of the animal, if the identity of such
person is known. Such notice may be personally served on the owner or keeper, or by leaving a copy at the last known residence of the owner
or keeper, or by mailing first class mail to the owner or keeper. Service must occur at least seventy two (72) hours before the hearing.
C. The hearing shall be conducted as an administrative hearing, and the formal rules of evidence shall not apply, though may be a guide regarding
admission of evidence. The court shall allow the parties to present evidence, witnesses and have the right of cross examination. Any and all
documentary evidence and other evidence deemed relevant by the court shall be received in evidence. The owner or keeper shall have the
rights of a defendant in a judicial proceeding, including the right to be represented by counsel and the right to compel the attendance of
witnesses. No defendant is entitled to court appointed counsel for representation at the dispositional hearing.
D. If the owner or keeper fails to appear for the hearing, the court may proceed with the hearing in his or her absence.
E. At the hearing, if the court determines that the Town has established, by a preponderance of the evidence, that there is a reasonable likelihood
of future injury to persons, property, or animals, the court shall order the animal to remain impounded at the owner/keeper's expense until the
final disposition of any pending Municipal charges. In making this determination, the court shall consider the following:
1. The conduct of the animal during the incident charged;
2. Any evidence of aggressive or violent behavior by the animal, or threats thereof;
3. Any prior animal related violations by the owner or keeper, including any Municipal ordinance or State law related to animals;
4. Any prior violation by any other owner or keeper, involving the same animal, including any violations of Municipal ordinance or State law
related to animals;
5. Any conditions existing on the property where the animal has been or will be kept which would affect the likelihood of any danger to persons,
animals or property;
6. Any evidence of any mitigating action taken by the owner or keeper of the animal which would affect the likelihood of any danger to any
persons, animals or property;
7. Any other evidence relevant to the issues as determined by the court. (Ord. 25-2019, 8-27-2019)
6-7-13: SEARCH WARRANT AUTHORIZED:
A. The Town declares that violations of sections 6-7-6, "Dogs Habitually At Large", 6-7-10, "Aggressive Animals", and 6-7-11, "Animal Attacks", of
this chapter involve a serious threat to public safety or order within the meaning of rule 241(a)(1) of the Colorado Rules of Municipal Procedure.
B. If the owner or occupant of the premises where the offending dog(s) are kept denies a Erie police officer/Code Enforcement Officer permission
to take custody of the dog(s) for purposes of impoundment pending any dispositional hearing, the officer(s) may request the Erie Municipal
Court to issue a search warrant for the inspection of the premises pursuant to procedure and standards set forth in rule 241(a)(1) of the
Colorado Rules of Municipal Procedure.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 152/449
C. The Erie Municipal Court may issue a search warrant authorizing the officer(s) to inspect the property and take custody of the dog(s) which the
court finds there is probable cause to believe the animal meets the definition of an animal that is habitually at large, as defined in section 6-7-6
of this chapter, has acted in an aggressive manner, as defined in subsection 6-7-10A of this chapter, or has engaged in conduct that constitutes
animal attack, as defined in subsection 6-7-11A of this chapter.
D. The Erie Municipal Court may impose such conditions on a search warrant as may be necessary to protect the private property rights of the
owner of the premises to be inspected or to otherwise ensure that the warrant complies with applicable law.
E. It is unlawful for any owner or occupant of the premises to deny any officer access to the property for purposes of execution of any search
warrant issued by the Erie Municipal Court, if the owner or occupant of the property presents the search warrant to the owner or occupant.
(Ord. 25-2019, 8-27-2019)
Chapter 8
OFFENSES RELATING TO GOVERNMENT
6-8-1: FAILURE TO OBEY REQUIRED COURT APPEARANCE:
It is unlawful for any person accused or convicted of any violation of this Code to knowingly fail to appear before the Municipal Court or agency of
the Municipal Court at the time and place specified on any summons issued by the court or summons and complaint served upon such person, or
as specified by or upon any court order or notice of appearance provided by the court. This action shall not be deemed to preclude the court from
exercising its full powers relating to the setting and forfeiture of bonds and contempt. It shall not be a defense to the provisions of this section that
the underlying charge is defective or the offense upon which the failure to appear is predicated does not result in a trial or conviction, or that the
conviction is reversed upon appeal. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-8-2: RESISTING ARREST:
A. Resisting Arrest Prohibited: It is unlawful to knowingly prevent or attempt to prevent a police officer, acting under color of such officer's official
authority, from effecting an arrest of the person or another by:
1. Using or threatening to use physical force or violence against the police officer or another; or
2. Using any other means which creates a substantial risk of causing physical injury to the police officer or another. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
B. Defense: It is no defense that the police officer was attempting to make an arrest which in fact was unlawful, if such officer was acting under
color of his or her official authority and, in attempting to make the arrest, such officer was not resorting to unreasonable or excessive force
giving rise to the right of self-defense. A police officer acts "under color of his or her authority" when, in the regular course of his duties, such
officer is called upon to make and does make a judgment in good faith, based upon supporting facts and circumstances, that such officer
should make an arrest. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
C. Definition: The term "police officer", as used in this section, means a police officer in uniform or, if out of uniform, one who has identified himself
by exhibiting his or her credentials as such police officer to the person whose arrest is attempted. (2004 Code)
6-8-3: OBSTRUCTING EMERGENCY OFFICIALS:
A. Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE PROVIDER: A member of a public or private emergency medical service agency, whether that person is a
volunteer or receives compensation for services rendered as such emergency medical service provider.
POLICE OFFICER: A police officer in uniform or, if out of uniform, one who has identified himself by exhibiting his or her credentials as such
police officer to the person whose arrest is attempted.
RESCUE SPECIALIST: Means a member of a public or private rescue agency, whether that person is a volunteer or receives compensation for
services rendered as such rescue specialist. (2004 Code; amd. Ord. 29-2018, 10-9-2018)
B. Obstruction Prohibited: It is unlawful to knowingly obstruct, hinder or impair, by using or threatening to use violence, force or physical
interference or obstacle, the enforcement of the penal law or preservation of the peace by a police officer acting under color of such officer's
official authority, or the prevention, control or abatement of fire by a firefighter acting under color of such firefighter's official authority, or the
administration of medical treatment or emergency assistance by an emergency medical service provider or rescue specialist, acting under color
of his or her official authority, or the administration of emergency care or emergency assistance by a volunteer, acting in good faith to render
such care or assistance without compensation at the place of an emergency or accident.
C. Defense: It is no defense that the police officer was acting illegally if the officer was acting under color of his or her official authority as defined in
subsection 6-8-2B of this chapter. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 153/449
D. Unmanned Aircraft: If a person is alleged to have committed the offense described in subsection B of this section by using or threatening to use
an unmanned aircraft system as an obstacle, the offense does not apply if the person who operated the unmanned aircraft system:
1. Obtained permission to operate the unmanned aircraft from a law enforcement agency or other entity that is coordinating the response of
peace officers, fire fighters, emergency medical service providers, rescue specialists, or volunteers to an emergency or accident;
2. Continues to communicate with such entity during the operation of the unmanned aircraft system; and
3. Complies immediately with any instruction from the entity concerning the operation of the unmanned aircraft system. (Ord. 29-2018, 10-9-
2018)
6-8-4: OBSTRUCTING GOVERNMENT FUNCTIONS:
A. Obstructions Prohibited: It is unlawful to knowingly obstruct, impair or hinder the performance of a governmental function by a public servant, by
using or threatening to use violence, force or physical interference or obstacle. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
B. Defense: It shall be an affirmative defense that:
1. The obstruction, impairment or hindrance was of unlawful action by a public servant; or
2. The obstruction, impairment or hindrance of a governmental function was by lawful activities in connection with a labor dispute with the
Town.
C. Definition: "Public servant" means any officer or employee of the Town, whether elected or appointed, and any person participating as an
advisor, or consultant, or otherwise performing a governmental function, including, but not limited to, any person performing work for or on
behalf of the Town on a contractual basis. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-8-5: ESCAPE:
It is unlawful for any person charged with, held for or convicted of any ordinance violation of the Town to knowingly escape or attempt to escape
from custody of a police officer or from the Police Department Detention Facility. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
6-8-6: AID TO POLICE:
A person, eighteen (18) years of age or older, violates this section when, upon command by a person known to him to be a police officer, he
unreasonably refuses or fails to aid the police officer in effecting or securing an arrest or preventing the commission by another of any offense.
(Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
6-8-7: FALSE REPORTS:
It is unlawful to:
A. Knowingly cause by any means, including but not limited to activation, a false alarm of fire or other emergency or a false emergency exit alarm
to sound or to be transmitted to or within an official or volunteer Fire Department, ambulance service, law enforcement agency or any other
government agency which deals with emergencies involving danger to life or property.
B. Knowingly cause by any means a false report of an imminent threat to the safety of a person or persons by use of a deadly weapon.
1. It is not a defense to a prosecution pursuant to this subsection B that the defendant or another person did not have the intent or capability of
committing the threatened or reported act.
2. Upon conviction of this subsection B, in addition to any other sentence imposed or restitution ordered, the court shall sentence the defendant
to pay restitution in an amount equal to the cost of any emergency response or evacuation, including but not limited to fire and police
response, emergency medical service or emergency preparedness response, and transportation of any individual from the building, place of
assembly, or facility of public transportation. (Ord. 29-2018, 10-9-2018)
6-8-8: IMPERSONATING PUBLIC OFFICIALS:
A. Impersonating A Police Officer: It is unlawful to falsely pretend to be a police officer and perform an act in the pretended capacity, except in a
bona fide theatrical performance.
B. Impersonating A Public Servant: It is unlawful to falsely pretend to be a public servant of the Town other than a police officer and perform an act
in that pretended capacity, except in a bona fide theatrical performance. It is no defense that the office the person pretended to hold did not in
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 154/449
fact exist. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
6-8-9: MISUSE OF TOWN SERVICES1:
No person, except the Town's customer of record responsible for the service, shall knowingly obtain or use any electric, water, sewer, refuse or
sanitation utility service the Town provides. It is an affirmative defense to an alleged offense under this section that the defendant, consistent with
all otherwise applicable laws, ordinances, rates, rules and regulations, obtained or used Town utility service with express permission from, or as a
guest or household member of, the Town's customer of record responsible for the service used or obtained. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-8-10: DISRUPTING LAWFUL ASSEMBLY:
A. It is unlawful for any person, intending to prevent or disrupt any lawful meeting, procession, or gathering, to significantly obstruct or interfere with
the meeting, procession or gathering by physical action, verbal utterance, or any other means.
B. This section is designated a criminal violation, subject to the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4B of this Code. (Ord. 25-2014, 7-8-2014)
6-8-11: FAIL TO OBEY LAWFUL ORDER:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to obey the lawful order of a police officer. A "lawful order", as used in this subsection, is an order
issued by a police officer in the exercise of his or her assigned duties relating to the enforcement of the penal law, the preservation of the
peace, or the protection of the safety of persons or property. A police officer may issue a lawful order while performing his or her assigned
duties, preserving the peace, or protecting the safety of persons or property, when in uniform, or if not in uniform, after having identified him or
herself as a police officer.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly fail to obey the lawful order of a Fire Department officer, paramedic or emergency medical
technician. A "lawful order", as used in this subsection, is an order issued by a Fire Department officer, paramedic or emergency medical
technician in the exercise of his or her assigned duties at the scene of a fire or other emergency relating to the preservation of the peace or the
protection of the safety of persons or property. A Fire Department officer, paramedic or emergency medical technician may issue a lawful order
after having identified him or herself as a Fire Department officer, paramedic or emergency medical technician.
C. This section is designated a criminal violation, subject to the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4B of this Code. (Ord. 25-2014, 7-8-2014)
6-8-12: THREATENING PUBLIC OFFICIAL, TOWN EMPLOYEE:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to communicate threats of violence, reprisal or any other injurious act to any public official, Town employee or
agent, who is engaged in the performance of his or her official duties.
B. This section is designated a criminal violation, subject to the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4B of this Code. (Ord. 25-2014, 7-8-2014)
6-8-13: PUBLIC BUILDINGS; TRESPASS, INTERFERENCE:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct himself at or in any public building owned, operated or controlled by the Town of Erie, as to wilfully
deny to any public official, Town employee or agent, or invitee on such premises the lawful rights of such official, employee or agent or invitee
to enter, to use the facilities of, or to leave any such building.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person, at or in any public building owned, operated or controlled by the Town of Erie, to wilfully impede any public
official, or Town employee or agent, in the lawful performance of duties or activities through the use of restraint, abduction, coercion, or
intimidation or by force or violence, or threat thereof.
C. It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully refuse or fail to leave any public building owned, operated or controlled by the Town of Erie, upon
being requested to do so by the Town Administrator, his designee, or any police officer, if the person has committed, is committing, threatens to
commit, or incites others to commit any act which did, or would if completed, disrupt, impair, interfere with, or obstruct the lawful missions,
processes, procedures or functions being carried on in the public building.
D. It shall be unlawful for any person at any meeting or session conducted by the Board of Trustees at or in any public building, to wilfully impede,
disrupt, or hinder the normal proceedings of such meeting or session by any act of intrusion into the area designated for the use of the Board,
or by any act designed to intimidate, coerce, or hinder any member of such body or official engaged in the performance of duties at such
meeting or session.
E. This section is designated a criminal violation, subject to the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4B of this Code. (Ord. 25-2014, 7-8-2014)

Chapter 9
OFFENSES RELATED TO ALCOHOL
6-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
ALCOHOL BEVERAGES: Fermented malt beverage or malt, vinous, or spirituous liquors; except "alcohol beverages" shall not include
confectionery containing alcohol within the limits prescribed by statute.
FERMENTED MALT BEVERAGE: As defined in the Colorado Beer Code, as amended.
MALT LIQUORS: As defined in the Colorado Liquor Code, as amended.
OPEN CONTAINER: Any container other than an original closed container as sealed or closed for sale to the public by the manufacturer or bottler
of the liquor or beverage. If an original container has been unsealed, undone, or opened in any manner, it is an opened container for purposes of
this chapter.
POSSESSION OF ALCOHOL BEVERAGE: A person has or holds any amount of alcohol beverage anywhere on his or her person, or a person
owns or has custody of any alcohol beverage, or has any alcohol beverage in his or her immediate presence and control.
PREMISES: All or any part of the physical boundaries of any establishment duly licensed for the sale and service of alcohol beverages in the
Town. The term "premises" shall include not only the building wherein the business is conducted, but also the parking lot(s) adjacent thereto.
SPIRITUOUS LIQUORS: Any alcohol beverage obtained by distillation, mixed with water and other substances in solution, and includes among
other things brandy, rum, whiskey, gin, and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing at least one-half of one percent (0.5%) alcohol which is
fit for use for beverage purposes. Any liquid or solid containing beer or wine in combination with any other liquor, except as provided in the
definitions of "malt liquors" and "vinous liquors", as defined herein, shall not be construed to be fermented malt or malt or vinous liquor but shall be
construed to be "spirituous liquor".
VINOUS LIQUORS: Wine and fortified wines which contain not less than one-half of one percent (0.5%) and not more than twenty one percent
(21%) alcohol by volume, and shall be construed to mean alcohol beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural sugar contents of fruits or
other agricultural products containing sugar. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. 07-2006, 2-7-2006; Ord. 13-2006, 3-14-2006; Ord. 33-
2012, 10-9-2012; Ord. 01-2019, 1-22-2019)
6-9-2: OPEN CONTAINERS:
A. Prohibitions Enumerated: Except upon premises holding valid licenses to sell or serve alcohol beverages, it is unlawful:
1. Generally: To carry or possess any open container of alcohol beverage on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place in the Town, or in
or upon any motor vehicle so located in the Town, or on the grounds of any public or private school, college or university in the Town. (Ord.
608, 9-24-1998)
2. Public Consumption: To consume any alcohol beverage in any public place except any licensed premises permitted under State law to sell
such liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
3. Open Container In Vehicle: For the operator of a vehicle in any public place in the Town to allow any open container of alcohol beverage
within the passenger compartment of the vehicle. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
B. Exemptions: Nothing in this section shall prohibit:
1. Possession or consumption of alcohol beverages in public parks where authorized by a properly issued special event permit issued pursuant
to Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-48-101 et seq., where the person possessing or consuming the alcohol beverage is twenty one (21)
years of age or older; however, no such permit shall allow the possession or consumption of alcohol beverages in any vehicle. (Ord. 13-
2006, 3-14-2006)
2. Possession or consumption of fermented malt beverages in public parks where authorized by a properly issued Town permit issued pursuant
to section 4-8-12 of this Code, where the person possessing or consuming the fermented malt beverage is twenty one (21) years of age or
older. No permit shall allow the possession or consumption of alcohol beverages in any public park. Nor shall any permit authorize the
consumption of fermented malt beverages or alcohol beverages in any vehicle. (Ord. 23-2013, 6-11-2013)
6-9-3: UNDERAGE POSSESSION, CONSUMPTION OR SALE OF ALCOHOL:
A. Prohibitions Enumerated: It is unlawful for any person:
1. To sell, serve, give away, dispose of, exchange, or deliver or permit the sale, serving, giving, or procuring of any alcohol beverage to or for
any person under the age of twenty one (21) years; or
2. To obtain or attempt to obtain any alcohol beverage by misrepresentation of age or by any other method in any place where alcohol
beverages are sold when such person is under the age of twenty one (21) years; or
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 156/449
3. To possess or consume alcohol beverages anywhere in the Town including, but not limited to, in any public or private place, or in any vehicle,
when such person is under twenty one (21) years of age; or
4. Permit any person under twenty one (21) years of age, of whom he or she may be a parent or guardian, to violate subsection A1, A2 or A3 of
this section. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
5. Illegal possession or consumption of an alcohol beverage by an underage person is a strict liability offense. (Ord. 09-2015, 5-12-2015)
B. Prima Facie Evidence: Prima facie evidence of a violation of subsection A3 of this section shall consist of:
1. Evidence that the defendant was under the age of twenty one (21) years and possessed or consumed alcohol beverages anywhere in the
State; or
2. Evidence that the defendant was under the age of twenty one (21) years and manifested any of the characteristics commonly associated
with alcohol intoxication or impairment while present anywhere in the State.
C. Defense: It shall be an affirmative defense that the person under the age of twenty one (21) years was participating in a religious ceremony or
practice, or is participating in a supervised and bona fide investigation conducted by a law enforcement agency. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd.
2004 Code)
D. Additional Penalty: In addition to any other penalty imposed by the court, upon each conviction, or entry of guilty or nolo contendere plea, for
violation of subsection A2 or A3 of this section, any driver's permit or license held by the offender shall be revoked as provided in Colorado
Revised Statutes section 42-2-125(1)(m), as amended, where:
1. The offender has failed to complete an alcohol evaluation or assessment, an alcohol education program, or an alcohol treatment program
ordered by the municipal court in connection with such conviction; or
2. The offender has been convicted, entered a guilty or nolo contendere plea, for violation of subsection A2 or A3 of this section and has a
previous conviction for any similar local or state alcohol offense. (Ord. 20-2009, 9-22-2009)
E. Immune From Criminal Prosecution: An underage person shall be immune from criminal prosecution under this section if he or she establishes
the following:
1. The underage person called 911 and reported in good faith that another underage person was in need of medical assistance due to alcohol
consumption;
2. The underage person who called 911 provided his or her name to the 911 operator;
3. The underage person was the first person to make the 911 report;
4. The underage person who made the 911 call remained on the scene with the underage person in need of medical assistance until
assistance arrived and cooperated with medical assistance or law enforcement personnel on scene. (Ord. 09-2015, 5-12-2015)
6-9-4: JUVENILES IN LICENSED ESTABLISHMENTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 33-2012, 10-9-2012)
6-9-5: PRESUMPTION:
During any trial for a violation of this chapter, any bottle, can or any other container with labeling indicating the contents of such bottle, can or
container shall be admissible into evidence, and the information contained on any label on such bottle, can or other container shall be admissible
into evidence and shall not constitute hearsay. A jury or a judge, whichever is appropriate, may consider the information upon such label to
determine whether the contents of the bottle, can or other container were composed in whole or in part of alcohol. A label which identifies the
contents of any bottle, can or other container as "beer", "ale", "malt beverage", "fermented malt beverage", "malt liquor", "wine", "champagne",
"whiskey", "gin", "vodka", "tequila", "schnapps", "brandy", "cognac", "liquor", "cordial", or "alcohol" shall constitute prima facie evidence that the
contents of the bottle, can or other container was composed in whole or in part of alcohol. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-9-6: CONDUCT PROHIBITED IN LIQUOR ESTABLISHMENTS:
A. Permitting Disturbance Unlawful: It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or employee or agent of said licensee, to permit any disturbance, unlawful
or disorderly act or conduct to be committed by any person or group of persons upon any premises.
B. Encouragement/Participation In Disturbance Unlawful: It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or employee or agent of said licensee, in any
manner to encourage or participate in any disturbance, unlawful or disorderly act or conduct upon the premises.
C. Prohibited Activities: It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or employee or agent of said licensee, to permit within or upon the licensed premises,
any of the following:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 157/449
1. The loitering of a visibly intoxicated person or habitual drunkard;
2. Rowdiness, undue noise, or other disturbances or activity offensive to the senses of the average citizens, or to the residents of the
neighborhood in which the licensed establishment is located.
D. Consumption During Allowed Times Only: It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or employee or agent of said licensee, to permit the consumption
of alcohol beverages on the licensed premises at any time when the sale of such beverages is prohibited by law.
E. Service To Intoxicated Person: It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or employee or agent of said licensee, to sell, serve, give away, dispose of,
exchange, or deliver, or permit the sale, serving, giving, or procuring of, any alcohol beverage to a visibly intoxicated person or a habitual
drunkard.
F. Certain Alcohol Beverages Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or employee or agent of said licensee, to have in possession or upon
the licensed premises any alcohol beverage, the sale of which is not permitted by said licensee.
G. Absence Of Licensee Not A Defense: It shall not be a defense to prosecution under this section that the licensee was not personally present on
the premises at the time the alleged violation occurred. An employee or agent of the licensee shall not be responsible hereunder when absent
from the premises and not on duty.
H. Penalties: This section is declared criminal in nature. Upon conviction, the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4B of this code may be imposed
by the municipal court. (Ord. 33-2012, 10-9-2012)
6-9-7: DUTY TO REPORT DISTURBANCES:
A. Reporting Of Disorderly Acts Required: It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or employee or agent of said licensee, to fail to immediately report
to the Erie police department any unlawful or disorderly act, conduct or disturbance committed on the premises.
B. Posting Of Sign: Each licensee shall post and keep posted at all times visible to the public in a conspicuous place on the premises, a sign to be
provided by the town clerk's office which shall provide:
WARNING: Town of Erie Police Department must be IMMEDIATELY notified of all disturbances that occur in this establishment, including the
grounds and parking lot.
C. Absence Of Licensee Not A Defense: It shall not be a defense to prosecution under this section that the licensee was not personally present on
the premises at the time the alleged violation occurred. An employee or agent of the licensee shall not be responsible hereunder when absent
from the premises and not on duty.
D. Failure To Comply: Failure to comply with the requirements of this section may be considered by the local liquor licensing authority in any action
relating to suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of a liquor or beer license. Repeated failure to comply with the requirements of this section
shall constitute prima facie grounds for the suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of a liquor or beer license.
E. Penalties: This section is declared criminal in nature. Upon conviction, the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4B of this code may be imposed
by the municipal court. (Ord. 33-2012, 10-9-2012)
6-9-8: REMOVAL OF VINOUS LIQUOR FROM LICENSED PREMISES:
A. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 6-9-2 of this chapter, or any provisions of the Colorado liquor code to the contrary, a licensee
described in subsection B of this section may permit a customer of the licensee to reseal and remove from the licensed premises one opened
container of partially consumed vinous liquor purchased on the premises so long as the originally sealed container did not contain more than
seven hundred fifty milliliters (750 ml) of vinous liquor.
B. The provisions of this section shall apply to a licensee:
1. That is duly licensed as a manufacturer's licensee under Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-402, a limited winery licensee under
Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-403, a beer and wine licensee under Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-409, a hotel and
restaurant licensee under Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-411, a tavern licensee under Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-
412, a brew pub licensee under Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-415, or a vintner's restaurant licensee under Colorado Revised
Statutes section 12-47-420; and
2. That has meals, as defined in Colorado Revised Statutes section 12-47-103(20), available for consumption on the licensed premises. (Ord.
33-2012, 10-9-2012)
