Chapter 10
MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES
6-10-1: FIREWORKS:
A. Definitions:
FIREWORKS: Means any composition or device designed to produce a visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration, or detonation,
and that meets the definition of articles pyrotechnic, permissible fireworks, or display fireworks as those terms are defined at Colorado
Revised Statutes 24-33.5-2001, as amended.
"Fireworks" does not include:
1. Toy caps, party poppers, and items similar to toy caps and party poppers that do not contain more than sixteen milligrams (16 mg) of
pyrotechnic composition per item and snappers that do not contain more than one milligram (1 mg) of explosive composition per item;
2. Highway flares, railroad fusees, ship distress signals, smoke candles, and other emergency signal devices;
3. Educational rockets and toy propellant device type engines used in such rockets when such rockets are of nonmetallic construction
and utilize replaceable engines or model cartridges containing less than two (2) ounces of propellant and when such engines or model
cartridges are designed to be ignited by electrical means;
4. Fireworks that are used in testing or research by a licensed explosives laboratory.
PERMISSIBLE FIREWORKS: Means the following small fireworks devices designed to produce audible or visual effects by combustion,
complying with the requirements of the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission as set forth in 16 CFR 1500.1 to 1500.272 and
1507.12, as amended, and classified as consumer fireworks UN0336 and UN0337 pursuant to 49 CFR 172.101, as amended:
1. Cylindrical fountains, total pyrotechnic composition not to exceed seventy five grams (75 g) each for a single tube or, when more than
one tube is mounted on a common base, a total pyrotechnic composition of no more than two hundred grams (200 g);
2. Cone fountains, total pyrotechnic composition not to exceed fifty grams (50 g) each for a single cone or, when more than one cone is
mounted on a common base, a total pyrotechnic composition of no more than two hundred grams (200 g);
3. Wheels, total pyrotechnic composition not to exceed sixty grams (60 g) for each driver unit or two hundred grams (200 g) for each
complete wheel;
4. Ground spinner, a small device containing not more than twenty grams (20 g) of pyrotechnic composition venting out of an orifice usually
in the side of the tube, similar in operation to a wheel, but intended to be placed flat on the ground;
5. Illuminating torches and colored fire in any form, total pyrotechnic composition not to exceed two hundred grams (200 g) each;
6. Dipped sticks and sparklers, the total pyrotechnic composition of which does not exceed one hundred grams (100 g), of which the
composition of any chlorate or perchlorate shall not exceed five grams (5 g);
7. Any of the following that do not contain more than fifty milligrams (50 mg) of explosive composition:
a. Explosive auto alarms;
b. Toy propellant devices;
c. Cigarette loads;
d. Strike-on-box matches; or
e. Other trick noise makers;
8. Snakes or glow worm pressed pellets of not more than two grams (2 g) of pyrotechnic composition and packaged in retail packages of
not more than twenty five (25) units;
9. Fireworks that are used exclusively for testing or research by a licensed explosive laboratory;
10. Multiple tube devices with:
a. Each tube individually attached to a wood or plastic base;
b. The tubes separated from each other on the base by a distance of at least one-half of one inch;
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 159/449
c. The effect limited to a shower of sparks to a height of no more than fifteen feet (15') above the ground;
d. Only one external fuse that causes all of the tubes to function in sequence; and
e. A total pyrotechnic composition of no more than five hundred grams (500 g).
"Permissible fireworks" do not include aerial devices or audible ground devices, including, but not limited to, fireworks.
PERSON: Includes an individual, partnership, firm, company, association, corporation, or governmental entity.
RETAILER: Includes any person who sells, delivers, consigns, or furnishes permissible fireworks to another person not for resale.
WHOLESALER: Includes any person who sells, delivers, consigns, gives or otherwise furnishes permissible fireworks to a retailer for resale
in Erie. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. Ord. 16-2018, 5-8-2018)
B. Permit Requirements:
1. Scope Of Permit: Permits may only be granted for supervised public displays of fireworks by the Town or for other organizations and groups,
for the public benefit.
2. Application For Permit: Application for a permit shall be made in writing at least thirty (30) days in advance of the date of display. (Ord. 608,
9-24-1998)
3. Approval Or Denial Of Application: The application for permit shall be submitted for review to the Chief of the Mountain View Fire Protection
District, or his agent, and the Chief of the Erie Police Department, or his agent, who shall each submit to the Town Administrator a written
recommendation regarding approval or denial of the permit. Review and approval or denial of the permit shall be by the Town Administrator.
(Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
4. Issuance Of Permit: An approved permit shall be issued by the Town Clerk.
5. Nontransferability Of Permit: No permit shall be transferable or assignable.
6. Bond: There shall be required a performance bond from the permittee in a sum not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) conditioned
upon compliance with the conditions of this section. The Town government shall not be required to post a performance bond.
C. Restrictions On Displays:
1. Supervision Of Displays: Every display shall be personally supervised by a competent operator and shall be of such character and so
located, discharged and fired as not to be hazardous to property, or endanger any person.
2. Insurance Requirements: Pyrotechnic displays for the public benefit and enjoyment shall be permitted under this section; provided, that the
organization sponsoring the display shows proof of adequate public liability insurance, as defined by the Board of Trustees, by separate
resolution, which may be changed from time to time. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
D. Prohibitions And Restrictions:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person: (Ord. 16-2018, 5-8-2018)
a. To knowingly furnish to any person who is under sixteen (16) years of age, by gift, sale or any other means, any fireworks, except as
provided in subsection D2b of this section.
b. Who is under sixteen (16) years of age to purchase any fireworks, including those defined as "permissible fireworks" in subsection A of
this section.
c. To possess or discharge any fireworks, other than "permissible fireworks" as defined in subsection A of this section, anywhere in the Town.
(Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
d. Who is not licensed as a retailer in retail transactions with the public by the State of Colorado, to offer for sale, expose for sale, sell, or
have in the person's possession with the intent to offer for sale any fireworks or permissible fireworks as defined in subsection A of this
section. (Ord. 16-2018, 5-8-2018)
2. It is lawful for any person:
a. Over the age of sixteen (16) years to possess and discharge permissible fireworks.
b. Under the age of sixteen (16) years to possess and discharge permissible fireworks, if such person is under immediate adult supervision.
E. Enforcement:
1. Every twenty four (24) hour period in which a violation exists constitutes a separate violation.
2. The Town Police Department shall seize, take, and remove, at the expense of the owner, all stocks of fireworks or combustibles offered or
exposed for sale, stored, held, or used in violation of this section. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 160/449
6-10-2: ABANDONED CONTAINERS, WELLS OR CISTERNS3:
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building, structure or dwelling under his control, in a place
accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator, well or cistern, or other container which has a door or a lid,
snaplock, or other locking device which may not be released from the inside without removing said door or lid, snaplock or other locking device.
(Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-10-3: POSSESSION OF MARIJUANA:
A. Prohibited; Twenty One Years Of Age Or Older: It shall be unlawful for any person twenty one (21) years of age or older to:
1. Possess more than one ounce but less than two (2) ounces of marijuana;
2. Openly and publicly display, consume or use two (2) ounces or less of marijuana;
3. Possess more than two (2) ounces but no more than six (6) ounces of marijuana;
4. Openly and publicly display, consume or use more than two (2) ounces of marijuana;
5. Consume marijuana in a manner that endangers others.
B. Prohibited; Under Twenty One Years Of Age: It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty one (21) years of age to:
1. Possess two (2) ounces or less of marijuana;
2. Openly and publicly display, consume or use two (2) ounces or less of marijuana;
3. Possess more than two (2) ounces but no more than six (6) ounces of marijuana;
4. Openly and publicly display, consume or use more than two (2) ounces of marijuana;
5. Consume marijuana in a manner that endangers others.
C. Exception: No person shall be charged with a violation of subsection A or B of this section provided the person has been issued a medical
marijuana registry card by the State of Colorado, pursuant to the provisions of the Colorado Medical Marijuana Code, Colorado Revised
Statutes 12-43.3-101 et seq., as may be amended, and the Colorado medical marijuana program, Colorado Revised Statutes 25-1.5-106, as
may be amended, and the person is in full compliance with State and local law regarding the use and possession of medical marijuana, and all
other applicable State and local laws.
D. Town Property: No person shall display, consume or use any amount of marijuana on or in any building, facility or property owned or controlled
by the Town of Erie, to include any Town park, trail or open space.
E. Possession Defined: Open and public display, consumption, or use of any amount of marijuana shall be deemed possession thereof.
F. Noncriminal Violations: Subsections A1, A2, B1, B2 and D of this section are designated noncriminal violations, subject to the penalties set forth
at subsection 1-4-4A of this Code.
G. Criminal Violations: Subsections A3, A4, A5, B3, B4 and B5 of this section are designated criminal violations, subject to the penalties set forth
at subsection 1-4-4B of this Code. (Ord. 20-2013, 6-11-2013)
H. Definitions: As used herein, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
CONSUMPTION: The act of smoking, inhaling, eating, drinking, or otherwise causing marijuana, marijuana concentrate or any product
containing marijuana to enter a person's body.
MARIJUANA: All parts of the plant of the genus Cannabis whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of the
plant, and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the plant, its seeds, or its resin, including marijuana
concentrate. "Marijuana" does not include industrial hemp, nor does it include fiber produced from the stalks, oil, or cake made from the seeds
of the plant, sterilized seeds of the plant which are incapable of germination, or the weight of any other ingredient combined with marijuana to
prepare topical or oral administrations, food, drink or other product.
OPEN AND PUBLIC OR OPENLY AND PUBLICLY: Does not include any activity occurring on private residential property by the occupant
thereof or their guests.
OPEN OR OPENLY: Means observable by the public or a substantial number of the public.
PUBLIC OR PUBLICLY: Means a place to which the public or a substantial number of the public has access without restriction, including but
not limited to streets and highways, transportation facilities, places of amusement, parks, playgrounds, and the common areas of buildings and
other facilities. (Ord. 20-2013, 6-11-2013; amd. Ord. 26-2019, 8-27-2019)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 161/449
I. Underage Possession Or Consumption: Illegal possession or consumption of marijuana by a person under the age of twenty one (21) years of
age is a strict liability offense.
J. Underage Person Immune From Criminal Prosecution: An underage person shall be immune from criminal prosecution under this section if he
or she establishes the following:
1. The underage person called 911 and reported in good faith that another underage person was in need of medical assistance due to
marijuana consumption;
2. The underage person who called 911 provided his or her name to the 911 operator;
3. The underage person was the first person to make the 911 report;
4. The underage person who made the 911 call remained on the scene with the underage person in need of medical assistance until
assistance arrived and cooperated with medical assistance or law enforcement personnel on scene. (Ord. 09-2015, 5-12-2015)
6-10-4: POSSESSION OF DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
A. Possession Prohibited: It is unlawful to knowingly possess drug paraphernalia. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
B. Definitions: As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this subsection:
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Those items defined in Colorado Revised Statutes title 18, article 18, as amended.
DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: All equipment, products, and materials of any kind which are used, intended for use, or designed for use in
planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, packaging, repackaging, storing,
containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance in violation of the
law. "Drug paraphernalia" includes, but is not limited to:
1. Testing equipment used, intended for use, or designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of
controlled substances;
2. Scales and balances used, intended for use, or designed for use in weighing or measuring controlled substances;
3. Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use, or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from or in otherwise cleaning or
refining marijuana;
4. Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons, and mixing devices used, intended for use, or designed for use in compounding controlled
substances;
5. Capsules, balloons, envelopes, baggies, bindles and other containers used, intended for use, or designed for use in packaging small
quantities of controlled substances;
6. Containers or other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances; or
7. Objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana, cocaine, hashish, or
hashish oil into the human body, such as:
a. Water pipes;
b. Carburetion tubes and devices;
c. Smoking and carburetion masks;
d. Roach clips, meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as a marijuana cigarette that has become too small or too short to
be held in the hand;
e. Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials;
f. Chamber pipes;
g. Carburetor pipes;
h. Electric pipes;
i. Air driven pipes;
j. Bongs; or
k. Ice pipes or chillers. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 162/449
C. Factors Determining Drug Paraphernalia: In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, the court, in its discretion, may consider, in
addition to all other relevant factors, the following:
1. Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use.
2. The proximity of the object to controlled substances.
3. The existence of any residue of controlled substance on the object.
4. Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning its use.
5. Descriptive materials accompanying the object which explain or depict its use.
6. National or local advertising concerning its use.
7. The existence and scope of legal uses for the object in the community.
8. Expert testimony concerning its use. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-10-5: SUBSTANCES RELEASING TOXIC VAPORS:
A. Use Prohibited: No person shall knowingly smell or inhale the fumes of toxic vapors for the purpose of causing a condition of euphoria,
excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction or dulled senses or nervous system, or possess, buy or use any such substance for the purpose of
violating or aiding another to violate this section.
B. Sales Or Furnishing To Minors: It is unlawful to knowingly sell, give, deliver or furnish any substance releasing toxic vapors to any child under
the age of eighteen (18) years without the personal or written consent of a parent or guardian of such child, except when the sale of one tube of
glue is made simultaneously with or as part of a sale, purchase or delivery of a hobby or model kit. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
6-10-6: ABANDONED, INOPERABLE VEHICLES4:
(Rep. by Ord. 04-2019, 2-12-2019)
6-10-7: SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL:
A. Removal Of Snow And Ice Required; Time Limitation: Every owner of any premises within the Town having a sidewalk on or adjacent to the
premises, shall have the duty to keep the sidewalk clean of snow and ice. All snow and ice shall be removed from the sidewalk within twenty
four (24) hours of cessation of snowfall.
B. Definitions:
OWNER: The fee owner of record, an agent or representative of the fee owner, any person entitled by tenancy or lease to possession of the
premises, or the occupant. "Owner" shall include any entity owning, possessing or occupying the premises, or with any legal obligation for the
condition and upkeep of the premises.
PREMISES: Any lot, parcel, outlot or other subdivision of real property whether occupied or not and whether or not a structure exists on the lot,
parcel, outlot or other subdivision. (Ord. 13-2010, 5-11-2010)
C. Written Warning: Upon inspection and determination that a violation of this section exists, a law enforcement officer or Code Enforcement
Officer may issue a written warning to the owner or occupant of the property, advising that the violation shall be corrected within twelve (12)
hours from the time the written warning is issued. If no owner or occupant is available to receive the written warning upon issuance, the
warning may be posted on the property. (Ord. 04-2019, 2-12-2019)
D. Failure To Comply: Should the owner or occupant fail to comply with this section after the issuance of a written warning, the owner or occupant
shall be served with a summons charging violation of this section. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-10-8: CIGARETTES AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS:
A. Prohibitions:
1. Providing To Minors: It is unlawful for any person to knowingly furnish to any person who is under eighteen (18) years of age, by gift, sale, or
any other means, any cigarettes or tobacco products. It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under this subsection A1 that the
person furnishing the cigarettes or tobacco product was presented with and reasonably relied upon a document which identified the person
receiving the cigarettes and/or tobacco product as being eighteen (18) years of age or older.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 163/449
2. Purchase By Minors: It is unlawful for any person who is under eighteen (18) years of age to purchase or attempt to purchase any cigarettes
or tobacco products.
3. Possession By Minors: It is unlawful for any person who is under eighteen (18) years of age to possess any cigarettes or tobacco products.
(Ord. 747, 4-24-2001)
B. Definition: As used in this section, "tobacco product" means:
1. Any product that contains nicotine or tobacco or is derived from tobacco and is intended to be ingested or inhaled by or applied to the skin of
an individual; or
2. Any electronic device that can be used to deliver nicotine to the person inhaling from the device, including, but not limited to, an electronic
cigarette, cigar, cigarillo, or pipe. (Ord. 26-2014, 7-8-2014)
C. Violations: Violations enumerated in this section are designated as noncriminal violations. (Ord. 747, 4-24-2001)
6-10-9: CURFEW FOR MINORS:
A. Purpose: Acts of vandalism within the Town have been increasing, and the investigation and apprehension of minors involved therein may place
additional pressures upon the authorities of the Town during the late evening and early morning hours, to the extent that police procedures and
the protection of health, safety and the property of the citizens of the Town may be impaired.
B. Age And Hour Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to be or remain in or upon any street, alley,
park, playground, schoolyard, or other public area subsequent to the hour of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M., or prior to the hour of five o'clock (5:00)
A.M., Sunday through Thursday, or subsequent to the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on Friday and Saturday and prior to five o'clock
(5:00) A.M. of the following day; provided, however, that the provisions of this subsection do not apply to a minor who is:
1. Engaged in lawful employment; or
2. Accompanied by a parent, guardian or other person of the age of twenty one (21) years, when that parent, guardian or person has
permission to have the custody and care of such minor from the minor's parent or guardian; or
3. Accompanied by any person between the age of eighteen (18) years and twenty one (21) years, having in his or her possession written
permission from the parent or guardian of the minor to have the care or custody of such minor; or
4. Upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by the parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of the
minor.
C. Responsibility Of Parents And Guardians: It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a
minor under the age of eighteen (18) years to knowingly permit such minor to be or remain in or upon any street, alley, park, playground,
schoolyard, or other public area subsequent to the hour of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M., or prior to the hour of five o'clock (5:00) A.M., Sunday
through Thursday, or subsequent to the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on Friday and Saturday and prior to five o'clock (5:00) A.M. of
the following day; provided, however, that the provisions of this subsection do not apply to those instances excepted in subsection B of this
section. (Ord. 789, 7-23-2002)
6-10-10: PUBLIC URINATION:
A. It is unlawful for any person to urinate in any public place where such conduct is likely to be viewed by any other person. It shall not be an
offense under this section where such voiding is made into a receptacle that has been provided for that purpose that stores or disposes of the
waste in a sanitary manner and that is enclosed from view of the general public.
B. This section is designated as noncriminal. Upon conviction, the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4A of this Code shall apply. (Ord. 34-2012,
10-9-2012)
6-10-11: POSSESSION OF MARIJUANA ACCESSORIES:
A. "Marijuana accessories" means any equipment, products, or materials of any kind which are used, intended for use, or designed for use in
planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, composting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing,
testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, vaporizing, or containing marijuana, or for ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing
marijuana into the human body.
B. It is unlawful for any person under twenty one (21) years of age to knowingly possess marijuana accessories. This section is designated a
noncriminal violation, subject to the penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4A of this Code. (Ord. 20-2013, 6-11-2013)
6-10-12: REGULATIONS RELATED TO RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA5:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 164/449
(Rep. by Ord. 21-2018, 8-14-2018)
6-10-13: POSTING, POSSESSION, OR EXCHANGE OF A PRIVATE IMAGE BY A JUVENILE:
A. A juvenile commits the offense of posting a private image by a juvenile if he or she, through digital or electronic means:
1. Knowingly distributes, displays, or publishes to the view of another person a sexually explicit image of a person other than himself or herself
who is at least fourteen (14) years of age or is less than four (4) years younger than the juvenile:
a. Without the depicted person's permission; or
b. When the recipient did not solicit or request to be supplied the image and suffered emotional distress; or
c. When the juvenile knew or should have known that the depicted person had a reasonable expectation that the image would remain
private; or
2. Knowingly distributes, displays, or publishes, to the view of another person who is at least fourteen (14) years of age or is less than four (4)
years younger than the juvenile, a sexually explicit image of himself or herself when the recipient did not solicit or request to be supplied with
the image and suffered emotional distress.
B. A juvenile commits the offense of possessing a private image by a juvenile if he or she, through digital or electronic means, knowingly
possesses a sexually explicit image of another person who is at least fourteen (14) years of age or is less than four (4) years younger than the
juvenile without the depicted person's permission; except that it is not a violation of this subsection B if the juvenile:
1. Took reasonable steps to either destroy or delete the image within seventy two (72) hours after initially viewing the image; or
2. Reported the initial viewing of such image to law enforcement or a school resource officer within seventy two (72) hours after initially viewing
the image.
C. A juvenile commits the offense of exchange of a private image by a juvenile if he or she, through digital or electronic means:
1. Knowingly sends a sexually explicit image or images of himself or herself to another person who is at least fourteen (14) years of age or is
less than four (4) years younger than the juvenile, and the image or images depict only the sender and no other person and the sender
reasonably believed that the recipient had solicited or otherwise agreed to the transmittal of the image or images; or
2. Knowingly possesses a sexually explicit image or images of another person who is at least fourteen (14) years of age or is less than four (4)
years younger than the juvenile, and the image or images depict only the sender and no other person and the juvenile reasonably believed
that the depicted person had transmitted the image or images or otherwise agreed to the transmittal of the image or images.
D. It is an affirmative defense to subsection A, B, or C, of this section if a juvenile is coerced, threatened or intimidated into distributing, displaying,
publishing, possessing, or exchanging a sexually explicit image of a person under eighteen (18) years of age.
E. Aggravating factors the Municipal Court may consider at sentencing in the event of a conviction, which shall include a guilty plea or deferred
judgment, include:
1. That the juvenile committed the offense with the intent to coerce, intimidate, threaten, or otherwise cause emotional distress to the depicted
person;
2. The juvenile had previously posted a sexually explicit image;
3. The juvenile distributed, displayed, or published three (3) or more images that depicted three (3) or more separate and distinct persons.
F. As used in this section:
JUVENILE: Means a person under eighteen (18) years of age.
SEXUALLY EXPLICIT IMAGE: Means any electronic or digital photograph, video, or video depiction of the external genitalia or perineum or
anus or buttocks or pubes of any person or the breast of a female person. (Ord. 02-2018, 1-9-2018)

Article II: Definitions:
(28.5) "Electrical assisted bicycle" means a vehicle having two or three wheels, fully operable pedals, and an electric motor not
exceeding seven hundred fifty watts of power. Electrical assisted bicycles are further required to conform to one of three classes as
follows:
(a) "Class 1 electrical assisted bicycle" means an electrical assisted bicycle equipped with a motor that provides assistance only when
the rider is pedaling and that ceases to provide assistance when the bicycle reaches a speed of twenty miles per hour.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 169/449
(b) "Class 2 electrical assisted bicycle" means an electrical assisted bicycle equipped with a motor that provides assistance regardless
of whether the rider is pedaling but ceases to provide assistance when the bicycle reaches a speed of twenty miles per hour.
(c) "Class 3 electrical assisted bicycle" means an electrical assisted bicycle equipped with a motor that provides assistance only when
the rider is pedaling and that ceases to provide assistance when the bicycle reaches a speed of twenty-eight miles per hour.
(Ord. 20-2017, 9-12-2017)
(28.7) "Electrical personal assistive mobility device" or "EPAMD" means a self-balancing, nontandem two-wheeled device, designed to
transport only one person, that is powered solely by an electric propulsion system producing an average power output of no more than
seven hundred fifty watts.
(39.5) "Golf car" means a self-propelled vehicle not designed for operation on roadways and that has:
(a) A design speed of less than twenty miles per hour;
(b) At least three wheels in contact with the ground;
(c) An empty weight of not more than one thousand three hundred pounds; and
(d) A carrying capacity of not more than four persons.
(49.5) (a) "Low-power scooter" means a self-propelled vehicle designed primarily for use on the roadways with not more than three
wheels in contact with the ground, no manual clutch, and either of the following:
(I) A cylinder capacity not exceeding fifty cubic centimeters if powered by internal combustion; or
(II) A wattage not exceeding four thousand four hundred seventy-six if powered by electricity.
(b) "Low-power scooter" shall not include a toy vehicle, bicycle, electrical assisted bicycle, wheelchair, or any device designed to assist
mobility impaired people who use pedestrian rights-of-way.
(49.6) "Low-speed electric vehicle" means a vehicle that:
(a) Is self-propelled utilizing electricity as its primary propulsion method;
(b) Has at least three wheels in contact with the ground;
(c) Does not use handlebars to steer; and
(d) Exhibits the manufacturer's compliance with 49 CFR 565 or displays a seventeen-character vehicle identification number as provided
in 49 CFR 565.
(56) "Motorcycle" means every motor vehicle designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground; except that
the term does not include a farm tractor or low-power scooter.
(Ord. 21-2010, 8-24-2010)
(58) "Motor vehicle" means any self-propelled vehicle that is designed primarily for travel on the public highways and that is generally
and commonly used to transport persons and property over the public highways or a low-speed electric vehicle; except that the term does
not include electrical assisted bicycles, low-power scooters, wheelchairs, or vehicles moved solely by human power.
(Ord. 20-2017, 9-12-2017)
(111)(a) "Toy vehicle" means any vehicle that has wheels and is not designed for use on public highways or for off-road use.
(b) "Toy vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, gas-powered or electric-powered vehicles commonly known as mini bikes, "pocket"
bikes, kamikaze boards, go-peds, and stand-up scooters.
(c) "Toy vehicle" does not include off-highway vehicles or snowmobiles.
(121) "Vehicle" means a device that is capable of moving itself, or of being moved, from place to place upon wheels or endless tracks.
"Vehicle" includes, without limitation, a bicycle, electric assisted bicycle, or EPAMD, but does not include a wheelchair, off-highway vehicle,
snowmobile, farm tractor, or implement of husbandry designed primarily or exclusively for use and used in agricultural operations or any
device moved exclusively over stationary rails or tracks or designed to move primarily through the air.
103(2)(b). Scope And Effect Of Model Traffic Code - Exceptions To Provisions.

118 Driving under restraint.
Any person who drives a motor vehicle or off-highway vehicle upon any highway with knowledge that the person's license or privilege to
drive, either as a resident or nonresident, is under restraint for an outstanding judgment is in violation of this section, which is designated
a traffic infraction.
221 Bicycle and personal mobility device equipment.
(9)(a) On or after January 1, 2018, every manufacturer or distributor of new electrical assisted bicycles intended for sale or distribution in
this state shall permanently affix to each electrical assisted bicycle, in a prominent location, a label that contains the classification number,
top assisted speed, and motor wattage of the electrical assisted bicycle. The label must be printed in the arial font in at least nine-point
type.
(b) A person shall not knowingly modify an electrical assisted bicycle so as to change the speed capability or motor engagement of the
electrical assisted bicycle without also appropriately replacing, or causing to be replaced, the label indicating the classification required
by subsection (9)(a) of this section.
(10)(a) An electrical assisted bicycle must comply with the equipment and manufacturing requirements for bicycles adopted by the United
States Consumer Product Safety Commission and codified at 16 CFR 1512 or its successor regulation.
(b) A class 2 electrical assisted bicycle must operate in a manner so that the electric assisted motor is disengaged or ceases to function
when the brakes are applied. Class 1 and class 3 electrical assisted bicycles must be equipped with a mechanism or circuit that cannot
be bypassed and that causes the electric motor to disengage or cease to function when the rider stops riding.
(c) A class 3 electrical assisted bicycle must be equipped with a speedometer that displays, in miles per hour, the speed the electrical
assisted bicycle is traveling.
(Ord. 20-2017, 9-12-2017)
236 Child Restraint Systems Required - Definitions - Exemptions.
(1) As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires:
(a) "Child care center" means a facility required to be licensed under the "child care licensing act," article 6 of title 26, C.R.S.
(a.5) "Child restraint system" means a specifically designed seating system that is designed to protect, hold, or restrain a child in a
motor vehicle in such a way as to prevent or minimize injury to the child in the event of a motor vehicle accident that is either
permanently affixed to a motor vehicle or is affixed to such vehicle by a safety belt or a universal attachment system, and that meets
the federal motor vehicle safety standards set forth in section 49 CFR 571.213, as amended.
(a.8) "Motor vehicle" means a passenger car; a pickup truck or a van, minivan, or sport utility vehicle with a gross vehicle weight
rating of less than ten thousand pounds. "Motor vehicle" does not include motorcycles, low-power scooters, motorscooters,
motorbicycles, motorized bicycles, and farm tractors and implements of husbandry designed primarily or exclusively for use in
agricultural operations.
(b) "Safety belt" means a lap belt, a shoulder belt, or any other belt or combination of belts installed in a motor vehicle to restrain
drivers and passengers, except any such belt that is physically a part of a child restraint system. "Safety belt" includes the
anchorages, the buckles, and all other equipment directly related to the operation of safety belts. Proper use of a safety belt means
the shoulder belt, if present, crosses the shoulder and chest and the lap belt crosses the hips, touching the thighs.
(c) "Seating position" means any motor vehicle interior space intended by the motor vehicle manufacturer to provide seating
accommodation while the motor vehicle is in motion.
(2)(a)(I) Unless exempted pursuant to subsection (3) of this section and except as otherwise provided in subparagraphs (II) and (III) of
this paragraph (a), every child who is under eight years of age and who is being transported in this state in a motor vehicle or in a
vehicle operated by a child care center, shall be properly restrained in a child restraint system, according to the manufacturer's
instructions.
(II) If the child is less than one year of age and weighs less than twenty pounds, the child shall be properly restrained in a rearfacing
child restraint system in a rear seat of the vehicle.
(III) If the child is one year of age or older, but less than four years of age, and weighs less than forty pounds, but at least twenty
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 171/449
pounds, the child shall be properly restrained in a rear-facing or forward facing child restraint system.
(b) Unless excepted pursuant to subsection (3) of this section, every child who is at least eight years of age but less than sixteen
years of age who is being transported in this state in a motor vehicle or in a vehicle operated by a child care center, shall be properly
restrained in a safety belt or child restraint system according to the manufacturer's instructions.
(c) If a parent is in the motor vehicle, it is the responsibility of the parent to ensure that his or her child or children are provided with
and that they properly use a child restraint system or safety belt system. If a parent is not in the motor vehicle, it is the responsibility of
the driver transporting a child or children, subject to the requirements of this section, to ensure that such children are provided with
and that they properly use a child restraint system or safety belt system.
(3) Except as provided in section 42-2-105.5(4), C.R.S., the requirements of subsection (2) of this section do not apply to a child who:
(a) Repealed.
(b) Is less than eight years of age and is being transported in a motor vehicle as a result of a medical or other life-threatening
emergency and a child restraint system is not available;
(c) Is being transported in a commercial motor vehicle, as defined in section 42-2-402(4)(a), that is operated by a child care center;
(d) Is the driver of a motor vehicle and is subject to the safety belt requirements provided in section 237;
(e) Repealed;
(f) Is being transported in a motor vehicle that is operated in the business of transporting persons for compensation or hire by or on
behalf of a motor vehicle carrier as defined in section 40-10-101(4)(a), C.R.S., a contract carrier by motor vehicle as defined in section
40-11-101(3), C.R.S., or an operator of a luxury limousine service as defined in section 40-16-101(3.3), C.R.S.
(4) No person shall use a safety belt or child restraint system, whichever is applicable under the provisions of this section, for children
under sixteen years of age in a motor vehicle unless it conforms with all applicable federal motor vehicle safety standards.
(5) Any violation of this section shall not constitute negligence per se or contributory negligence per se.
(6) This section is designated a traffic infraction. Upon conviction, the municipal court may impose a minimum fine of $100.00 for a first
offense.
(7) The municipal court may waive all or part of the fine if the defendant presents the court with satisfactory evidence of proof of the
acquisition, purchase, or rental of a child restraint system by the time of the court appearance.

1206. Unattended Motor Vehicle.
(1) A person driving or in charge of an unlocked motor vehicle shall not permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine,
locking the ignition, removing the key from the ignition, and effectively setting the brake thereon. When the vehicle is standing upon any
grade, the person shall turn the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway in such a manner as to prevent the vehicle from rolling
onto the traveled way.
(2) The use or operation of a remote starter system or adequate security system measures is sufficient to comply with subsection 1 of
this section.
(3) As used in this section:
(a) "Adequate security system" includes, but is not limited to:
(i) Using a vehicle that requires a key to put the vehicle into gear and move the vehicle;
(ii) Keeping a keyless start fob out of the proximity of the vehicle; or
(iii) Employing steering wheel security devices.
(b) "Remote starter system" means a device installed in a motor vehicle that allows the engine of the vehicle to be started by remote
or radio control.
(Ord. 30-2018, 10-9-2018)
1211. Limitations On Backing.
(1) The driver of a vehicle, whether on public or private property which is used by the general public for parking purposes, shall not back
the same unless such movement can be made with safety and without interfering with other vehicles or traffic.
(2) The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same upon any shoulder or roadway of any controlled-access highway.
(Ord. 21-2010, 8-24-2010)

1413. Eluding Or Attempting To Elude A Police Officer.
It shall be unlawful for any operator of a motor vehicle who a police officer has reasonable grounds to believe has violated a state law or
municipal ordinance, who has received a visual or audible signal such as a red light or a siren from a police officer driving a marked
vehicle showing the same to be an official police, sheriff, or Colorado state patrol car directing the operator to bring the operator's vehicle
to a stop, to willfully increase his or her speed or extinguish his or her lights in an attempt to elude such police officer, or willfully attempt
in any other manner to elude the police officer, or elude such police officer.
1703. Parties To A Crime.
Every person who commits, conspires to commit, or aids or abets in the commission of any traffic violation, whether a traffic infraction or
a traffic offense, and whether individually or in connection with one or more other persons or as a principal, agent, or accessory, is guilty
of such offense or liable for such offense, and every person who falsely, fraudulently, forcibly, or willfully induces, causes, coerces,
requires, permits, or directs another to violate any provision of this code is likewise guilty of such infraction or offense.
(Ord. 21-2010, 8-24-2010)
6-11-2: DEFINITIONS:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 174/449
As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
ABANDONED VEHICLE: A motor vehicle left unattended on public property, including any portion of a public right-of-way, for a period of twenty
four (24) hours or more.
CHARGING DOCUMENT: The document commencing or initiating the traffic infraction matter, whether denoted as a complaint, summons and
complaint, citation, penalty assessment notice, or other document charging the person with the commission of a traffic infraction or infractions.
COMMERCIAL VEHICLE: A motor vehicle used for any commercial or business purpose, including without limitation a trailer used for commercial
or business purposes, but excluding any passenger vehicle, with or without an attached trailer, used for any commercial or business, the total or
combined length of which does not exceed twenty five feet (25'), as measured from the extreme front bumper to the extreme rear bumper.
DEFENDANT: Any person charged with the commission of a traffic infraction including, but not limited to, the following terms used in the
implementing legislation: "cited person", "cited party", "individual", "person charged with a traffic violation", "violator", or "accused".
DOCKET FEE: A fee assessed according to the provisions of this title, or a fee established by the rules of the Municipal Court.
GOLF CAR: Shall be defined as set forth in Colorado Revised Statutes section 42-1-102, as follows:
"Golf car" means a self-propelled vehicle not designed primarily for operation on roadways and that has:
A. A design speed of less than twenty (20) miles per hour;
B. At least three (3) wheels in contact with the ground;
C. An empty weight of not more than one thousand three hundred (1,300) pounds; and
D. A carrying capacity of not more than four (4) persons.
INOPERABLE VEHICLE: A motor vehicle that is not capable of travel under its own power for any reason, including without limitation mechanical
failure, collision, fire, damage, flat tire(s) or lack of parts.
JUDGMENT: The admission of guilt or liability for any traffic infraction, the entry of judgment of guilt or liability, or the entry of default judgment as
set forth in this chapter against any person for the commission of a traffic infraction.
LOADING AND UNLOADING: The uninterrupted activity of continuously moving material, equipment, goods or other items of personal property
from or to a motor vehicle.
MOTOR VEHICLE: A self-propelled vehicle that is designed primarily for travel on the public highways and that is generally and commonly used to
transport persons and property over the public highways or a low-speed electric vehicle; except that the term does not include electrical assisted
bicycles, low-power scooters, wheelchairs, or vehicles moved solely by human power.
OFFICER: A peace officer who tenders or serves a charging document.
PENALTY: A fine imposed pursuant to this chapter for the violation of a traffic infraction.
REFEREE: Any person appointed by the Municipal Judge as a referee pursuant to this chapter, to determine parking assessments.
RESIDENTIAL STREET: A public street with the primary function to provide access to immediately adjacent property used for single-family or
multi-family residential purposes.
SEMI-TRAILER: A wheeled vehicle, without motive power, designed to be used in conjunction with a truck-tractor so that some part of its own
weight and that of its cargo load rest upon or are carried by such truck-tractor and which are commonly used to carry and transport property over
the public highways.
TRUCK-TRACTOR: A motor vehicle generally and commonly designed to draw a semi-trailer and its cargo over the public highways.
UNLAWFUL VEHICLE: A motor vehicle that would be unlawful to operate on any street or highway in the Town, including without limitation any
vehicle that does not display vehicle registration license plates or displays expired registration plates.
UNSAFE VEHICLE: A motor vehicle that is in such unsafe condition as to create an unreasonable risk of harm, or which, by virtue of its condition,
when such vehicle is driven, moved, parked, or left unattended, creates a safety risk to the driver, occupant(s) or the general public. (Ord. 608, 9-
24-1998; amd. Ord. 19-2010, 8-24-2010; Ord. 03-2019, 2-12-2019)
6-11-3: MOTOR SCOOTERS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
A. Definition: "Motor scooter" means a self-propelled, wheeled device consisting of a motorized platform, footboard, ski like device, shoe, boot, or
similar object mounted on wheels and designed or intended to propel a rider by mechanical power, gasoline power, or electric power. The term
"motor scooter" shall include, but not be limited to, motorized toy vehicles capable of carrying a person and motorized skateboards, scooters,
rollerskis, rollerskates, and in-line skates.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 175/449
B. Motor Scooters Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor scooter on any public street, road, highway, alley, sidewalk,
public parking lot, privately owned parking lot open to the public, park, open space or other public area within the Town.
C. Responsibility For Minors: It shall be unlawful for any parent or legal guardian to authorize, assist, permit or encourage any minor to operate a
motor scooter in violation of this section.
D. Exemptions: This section shall not apply to:
1. Motor scooters operated on private property by the owner of such private property or persons operating such devices with the permission of
the owner of the private property.
2. Operation of motor scooters in areas specifically designated and posted by the Town for use and operation of motor scooters. (Ord. 724, 10-
10-2000)
3. Operation of low power scooters, low speed electric vehicles, and personal mobility devices, which is governed by the model traffic code,
2010 edition, as adopted by the town. (Ord. 21-2010, 8-24-2010)
6-11-4: OPERATION OF AIRCRAFT ON STREETS:
A. Crossing Restrictions: Aircraft shall be allowed to cross town streets and roadways in order to access the Erie municipal airport taxiways and
runways by way of legal easements under the following conditions:
1. The aircraft engine shall be off, and the aircraft shall be towed across the street or roadway.
2. The aircraft shall cross the town street or roadway only from existing easements for such aircraft use and in order to reach existing
easements for such aircraft use on the opposite side of the street or roadway.
3. The aircraft shall cross the town street or roadway only at a location specifically designated for such aircraft crossing by the town, which
locations shall be clearly marked with signs and markings approved and installed by the town.
4. The owner of the aircraft must have in effect liability insurance equal to or greater than that liability insurance required by the state motor
vehicle department for an automobile operating on a town street or roadway.
B. Operation On Streets Prohibited: In no event shall an aircraft, under its own power, operate on a town street or roadway.
C. Violation; Penalty: This section is designated as noncriminal. Any person convicted of violating this section may be punishable as provided in
title 1, chapter 4 of this code. (Ord. 789, 8-14-2001; amd. 2004 Code)
6-11-5: CIVIL TRAFFIC INFRACTIONS:
Notwithstanding any provision contained to the contrary as set forth in this chapter, all violations of any provisions of any town ordinance or code
relating to traffic or any provision of the model traffic code for Colorado municipalities, as adopted or amended by the town for which a fine only is
established as a penalty for the violation thereof, are hereinafter referred to as "traffic infractions" and shall constitute civil matters and not criminal
violations, except those violations set forth in subsection 6-11-6B of this chapter and any other traffic offense for which, upon conviction, a term of
imprisonment may be imposed. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998; amd. 2004 Code)
6-11-6: APPLICATION OF JURY TRIAL:
A. Traffic Infractions: A defendant brought to trial solely upon a traffic infraction or infractions shall have no right to a trial by jury as promulgated by
Colorado Revised Statutes section 13-10-114 or rule 223, municipal court rules of procedure, and trial of civil traffic infractions shall be to the
court. No defendant found civilly liable for a traffic infraction shall be punished by imprisonment for said infraction. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
B. Noncivil Traffic Offenses:
1. Any adult defendant (person 18 years of age or older) charged with any traffic violation punishable, upon conviction, with the imposition of a
penalty which includes the possibility of imprisonment, shall have the right, upon proper perfection of a jury demand, to a trial by jury. Such
offenses include the following, as set forth in the model traffic code, 2010 edition, as adopted and amended by the town: (Ord. 838, 7-27-
2004; amd. Ord. 21-2010, 8-24-2010)
Section 1101 Speed limit, where the speed alleged is greater than 25 mph over the lawful speed
Section 1105 Speed contests
Section 1401 Reckless driving
Section 1409 Compulsory motor vehicle insurance
