Section 1413 Eluding or attempting to elude a peace officer
Section 1903 Failure to stop for school buses
No person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age shall be entitled to a jury trial on a noncivil traffic offense.
2. In the event an adult defendant (person 18 years of age or older) is charged with more than one traffic violation arising out of the same
incident and at least one of the charged offenses is listed in subsection B1 of this section, the defendant shall have the right to demand a trial
by jury as to all such offenses, which shall be consolidated for purposes of trial. (Ord. 838, 7-27-2004)
6-11-7: COMMENCEMENT OF ACTION:
An action under this chapter charging a civil traffic infraction is commenced by the tender or service of a charging document upon a defendant, or
by conspicuously attaching a parking assessment to the subject vehicle, and by filing of the charging document with the municipal court. (Ord. 608,
9-24-1998)
6-11-8: PAYMENT BEFORE APPEARANCE:
A. The clerk of the court shall accept payment of a penalty for a traffic infraction and court surcharge by a defendant without an appearance, if
payment in full is received seven (7) days prior to the date set for first hearing.
B. A defendant charged with a traffic infraction, as defined in section 6-11-5 of this chapter, may elect to receive an early payment point reduction if
payment is received by the court seven (7) days prior to the date set for first hearing. The penalty point reduction shall be two (2) points per
charge for any violation that carries six (6) points, four (4) points or three (3) points. For any two (2) or one point violation, the penalty point
reduction shall be one point. The early payment point reduction shall not apply to zero point violations.
C. At the time of payment, which shall include the fine, court surcharge and all costs and fees regularly assessed by the court for defendant's
pleading or being found guilty of traffic infractions, the defendant shall sign a waiver of rights and acknowledgment of guilt or liability. A parent
must sign in addition to the juvenile defendant wishing to receive the early payment point reduction. Failure to sign the waiver of rights and
acknowledgment of guilt will require appearance at the first hearing.
D. This procedure shall constitute an entry and satisfaction of judgment. (Ord. 08-2006, 2-7-2006)
6-11-9: PROCEDURES FOR HEARINGS; JUDGMENTS:
A. First Hearing:
1. If the defendant has not previously acknowledged guilt or liability and satisfied the judgment, he shall appear before the court at the time
scheduled for first hearing.
2. The defendant may appear in person or by counsel, who shall enter appearance in the case; provided, however, if an admission of guilt or
liability is entered, the court may require the presence of the defendant for the assessment of the penalty.
3. If the defendant appears in person, the court shall advise him in open court of the following:
a. The nature of the infractions alleged in the charging document;
b. The penalty, any fees and costs that may be assessed, and the penalty points that may be assessed against the driving privilege;
c. The consequences of the failure to appear at any subsequent hearing including entry of judgment against the defendant and reporting the
judgment to the state motor vehicle division, which may assess points against the driving privilege and may deny an application for a
driver's license;
d. The right to be represented by an attorney at the defendant's expense;
e. The right to remain silent, because any statement made by the defendant may be used against him;
f. Guilt or liability must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt;
g. The right to testify, subpoena witnesses, present evidence, and cross examine any witnesses for the state;
h. Any answer must be voluntary and not the result of undue influence or coercion on the part of anyone; and
i. An admission of guilt or liability constitutes a waiver of the foregoing rights and any right to appeal.
4. The defendant personally or by counsel shall answer the allegations in the charging document either by admitting guilt or liability or by
denying the allegations.
5. If the defendant admits guilt or liability, the court shall enter judgment and assess the appropriate penalty and the fees and costs after
determining that the defendant understood the matters set forth in subsection A3 of this section, and has made a voluntary, knowing, and
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 177/449
intelligent waiver of rights.
6. If the defendant denies the allegations, the matter shall be set for final hearing, and the defendant, the prosecuting attorney's office and the
charging officer shall be notified.
B. Subpoenas:
1. The defendant and town shall have the right to the issuance of subpoenas by the court clerk as in all other noncivil municipal prosecutions to
secure the attendance of witnesses at final hearing.
2. The service of a subpoena shall be by first class mail, if the person to whom it is delivered waives personal service. No fees or mileage need
be tendered with service by mail. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
3. If the person to whom a subpoena is directed does not waive personal service, the issuance and service of a subpoena shall be as provided
by rule 217, municipal court rules of procedure, except as otherwise provided in this rule. (Ord. 838, 7-27-2004)
C. Speedy Trial: The charges shall be dismissed if the final hearing is not held within the time requirements and standards otherwise applicable to
the trial of noncivil municipal code violations.
D. Final Hearing: The hearing of all traffic infractions, except for parking assessments, shall be conducted pursuant to the Colorado rules of
evidence, and the conduct of the hearing shall otherwise be in the form applicable to noncivil municipal offenses tried in the court.
E. Judgment After Final Hearing:
1. If all elements of a traffic infraction are proven beyond a reasonable doubt, the court shall find the defendant guilty or liable and enter
appropriate judgment.
2. If any element of a traffic infraction is not proven beyond a reasonable doubt, the court shall dismiss the charge and enter appropriate
judgment; provided, however, that the court may find the defendant guilty of or liable for a lesser included traffic infraction, if based on the
evidence offered, and enter appropriate judgment.
3. If the defendant is found guilty or liable, the court shall assess any applicable fees, and additional costs otherwise generally imposed in
noncivil municipal offenses.
4. The judgment shall be satisfied upon payment to the clerk of the total amount assessed as set forth above.
5. If the defendant fails to satisfy the judgment upon the finding of guilt or liability, or within the time of a reasonable extension granted upon a
showing of good cause by, and upon application of, the defendant, then such nonpayment in the full amount of the penalty, fees and costs
shall be treated as a default.
F. Post Hearing Motions And Appeal: There shall be no post hearing motions except for a motion to set aside a default judgment as provided by
subsection G of this section.
G. Default:
1. If the defendant fails to appear for any hearing on a traffic infraction, the court shall enter judgment against the defendant. The record of such
judgment, including the points assessed, shall be forwarded to the Colorado division of motor vehicles.
2. The amount of the judgment shall be the appropriate penalty assessed after a finding of guilt or liability, outstanding judgment fee, and
additional costs assessable to municipal violations generally upon conviction of municipal charges, except such fees and additional costs
shall not be added to parking assessment default judgments.
3. The court may set aside a judgment entered under this rule on a showing of good cause or excusable neglect by the defendant. A motion to
set aside the judgment shall be made to the court not more than seven (7) calendar days after entry of judgment.
4. The defendant may satisfy a judgment entered under this rule by paying the clerk.
5. No warrant shall issue for the arrest of a defendant who fails to appear at a hearing on a traffic infraction or fails to satisfy a judgment
assessed for a finding of guilt or liability of a traffic infraction. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-11-10: APPEALS:
Appeal of any finding of guilt or liability of traffic infractions shall be subject to the same procedures as applicable to convictions of municipal
offenses generally. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-11-11: PARKING ASSESSMENTS:
A. Referee Appointed: The municipal judge may appoint a referee to hear and determine parking assessments.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 178/449
B. Hearing Procedures:
1. The hearing of parking assessment contents shall be informal, the object being to dispense justice and resolution promptly and economically.
2. The town shall first provide sworn testimony and evidence to the facts concerning the alleged parking infraction, subject to cross
examination.
3. Upon the conclusion of testimony and examination, the court or referee may further examine or allow rebuttal as deemed appropriate.
4. Upon the conclusion of all testimony, each party, or their respective counsel, shall be permitted to make a closing statement.
5. The Colorado rules of evidence shall not apply to hearings relating to parking assessments. (Ord. 608, 9-24-1998)
6-11-12: PENALTIES:
See section 1-4-7 of this code for penalties relating to traffic infractions and offenses. (Ord. 21-2010, 8-24-2010)
6-11-13: PARKING OF VEHICLES FOR SALE, LEASE:
It is unlawful to park a vehicle upon a roadway, street, alley, sidewalk or sidewalk area, in a park or in any publicly owned parking area within the
town for the principal purpose of displaying such vehicle for sale or lease.
"Vehicle" is defined in subsection 6-11-1C of this chapter. (Ord. 748, 5-24-2001)
6-11-14: OPERATION OF GOLF CARS:
A. No person shall operate a golf car on the roadway or a street within the town of Erie, except as provided for in this chapter.
B. An operator of a golf car shall have been legally issued and possess a currently valid driver's license and be twenty one (21) years of age or
older.
C. Every golf car operating on a town street or roadway as allowed herein shall be equipped, at a minimum, with the following equipment:
1. Front headlamps;
2. Front and rear turn signal lamps;
3. Rear taillamps and stop lamps;
4. A rearview mirror or mirrors;
5. A parking brake;
6. A front windshield;
7. Seat belts for each occupant;
8. Two (2) rear reflectors as either part of the taillamps or separately; and
9. A slow moving vehicle sign, as provided for by state law, shall be attached on the rear of the golf car, and shall be visible in daylight and at
night from all distances between six hundred feet (600') and one hundred feet (100') from the rear when directly in upper beam of
headlamps.
D. The number of persons allowed to travel in a golf car shall be limited to the number of seats in the golf car, in accordance with the design of the
golf car, but in no event shall there be more than four (4) persons.
E. Every child passenger in a golf car shall be secured in a child restraint device as required by state law for children riding as passengers in a
motor vehicle.
F. Golf cars shall be restricted to operation on streets and roadways within the Town of Erie which have a speed limit of twenty five (25) miles per
hour or less, and to operation on Mountain View Boulevard; except that a golf car may be operated to directly cross a roadway that has a
speed limit greater than twenty five (25) miles per hour at an at grade crossing to continue traveling along a roadway with a speed limit equal to
or less than twenty five (25) miles per hour. If the owner of the golf car resides at a street address where operation of a golf car is not allowed
due to this speed restriction, the owner shall be allowed to drive the shortest route to and from the owner's residence to a street where the golf
car is allowed to operate.
G. Golf cars shall be restricted to operation on streets and roadways within the Town of Erie as provided for herein. Golf cars shall not be allowed
on Town paths or trails.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 179/449
H. Prior to the operation of a golf car on a Town street or roadway as allowed herein, each owner shall obtain and carry a liability insurance policy
for that golf car meeting the following minimum requirements: the liability insurance policy shall be issued by an insurance carrier authorized to
do business in the State of Colorado; shall cover a golf car operating on public streets and roadways; shall have coverage with a minimum sum
of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for damages to property of others, a minimum sum of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00) for damages for or on account of bodily injury or death of one person as a result of any one accident, and, subject to such limit
as to one person, a minimum sum of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for or on account of bodily injury to or death of all persons
as a result of any one accident.
I. Every person operating a golf car in the Town shall be subject to all traffic laws adopted by the Town of Erie, and may be subject to the issuance
of a summons and complaint for any such traffic violation. Upon conviction of any traffic violation, penalties established in section 1-4-7 of this
Code shall apply. A traffic ticket issued to any operator of a golf car shall be governed by the procedures set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 19-
2010, 8-24-2010)
J. Nothing contained herein to the contrary withstanding, it shall be legal for a Town authorized golf car to operate on Town paths, trails and areas
within the parks, greenbelts, open spaces, and recreation facilities for public safety, upkeep and maintenance purposes. (Ord. 01-2011, 3-8-
2011)
6-11-15: PROVIDING FALSE EVIDENCE OF PROOF OF MOTOR VEHICLE INSURANCE; PENALTY:
A. It is unlawful for any person to offer, use or attempt to offer or use any means, manner, type of paper, document, card, digital image, or any
other proof of motor vehicle insurance required by State and local law to a law enforcement officer, Judge, prosecutor, or employee of the Court
Clerk's Office with the intent to mislead that official regarding the status of any motor vehicle liability insurance policy in the course of an official
investigation, or for the purposes of dismissing the charge under Model Traffic Code, section 1409, where such means, manner, type or kind of
proof of insurance offered or used, or that is attempted to be offered or used, is known or should be known by the person to be false,
fraudulent, or incorrect in any material manner or way, or which is known or should be known by the person to be altered, forged, defaced, or
changed in any material respect, unless such changes are required or authorized by law.
B. This section is designated a noncriminal violation, subject to the penalties set forth at section 1-4-4 of this Code upon conviction. (Ord. 32-2013,
10-22-2013)
6-11-16: PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
A. It is unlawful to park a semi-trailer, truck-tractor or commercial vehicle on any roadway, street, public right-of-way or residential property in the
Town, except:
1. During loading or unloading of such motor vehicle; or
2. When such motor vehicle is being used to render services to property located within two hundred feet (200') of where the vehicle is parked.
B. It is unlawful to park any motor vehicle of more than twenty five feet (25') in length on any roadway, street, public right-of-way or residential
property in the Town, except:
1. During loading or unloading of such motor vehicle; or
2. When such motor vehicle is being used to render services to property located within two hundred feet (200') of where the vehicle is parked.
(Ord. 03-2019, 2-12-2019)
6-11-17: ABANDONED, INOPERABLE AND UNSAFE VEHICLES:
A. Prohibition: It is unlawful to park or store or permit to be parked or stored anywhere in the Town, unless otherwise specifically allowed by this
Code, any of the following:
1. An abandoned vehicle.
2. An inoperable vehicle, unless stored in a completely enclosed permanent structure.
3. An unsafe vehicle, unless stored in a completely enclosed permanent structure.
4. An unlawful vehicle, unless stored in a completely enclosed permanent structure.
B. Exception: One inoperable, unsafe or unlawful vehicle is allowed per lot or parcel of real property, if it is owned by the owner or occupant of the
real property on which it is parked, it is covered by a car cover or opaque tarp, securely fastened at all times, and it remains in compliance with
subsection 5-1-6G of this Code.
C. Additional Penalty: In addition to any other penalty, any vehicle found to be in violation of this section is deemed to be a public nuisance, and
the Town may bring a civil action before any court of competent jurisdiction for abatement. The court shall assess all costs incurred by the Town
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 180/449
in securing the abatement, including impoundment and storage expenses, and reasonable attorney fees, against the person responsible for
maintaining the nuisance. (Ord. 03-2019, 2-12-2019)
6-11-18: REMOVAL OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
A. The Town is authorized to remove a motor vehicle to the nearest place of safety or to a secure impound lot or facility when:
1. A motor vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, causeway or viaduct, or in any underpass, where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction
to traffic;
2. A motor vehicle on a street is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic, or the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are, by
reason of physical injury or otherwise, incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody and removal;
3. A motor vehicle is found being driven on a street and is not in proper condition to be driven;
4. A motor vehicle is left unattended on a street and is parked so as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of
traffic or proper street or highway maintenance;
5. A motor vehicle has been abandoned on public property;
6. The driver of a motor vehicle is taken into custody by a police officer and such motor vehicle would thereby be left unattended on a street or
public right-of-way;
7. Removal is necessary in the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, storm or other emergency reason;
8. The motor vehicle is situated on public property and is inoperable;
9. The motor vehicle is parked in a tow-away zone;
10. There is probable cause to believe that the driver of the motor vehicle does not hold a valid driver's license, or the driver's license is actively
suspended, revoked, denied or canceled;
11. A law enforcement officer has reason to believe that the driver of the motor vehicle is not in rightful possession of the motor vehicle and the
officer cannot verify ownership through readily available means; or
12. There is probable cause to believe that the owner or operator of the motor vehicle fails to have a complying policy or certificate of selfinsurance
in full force and effect, as required by Colorado Revised Statutes sections 10-4-619 and 10-4-624.
B. All costs incurred by the Town in removal of any motor vehicle pursuant to this section shall be the responsibility of the owner of such motor
vehicle. (Ord. 03-2019, 2-12-2019)
Chapter 12
OFFENSES RELATED TO HEALTH AND SANITATION
6-12-1: PURPOSE:
The accumulation of garbage, rubbish and junk encourages the infestation of rodents, pests and vermin, compromises the public health resulting
from dangerous and unsanitary conditions, constitutes a fire hazard and threat to public safety and general welfare, and otherwise erodes the
aesthetic conditions of the community, degrading the quality of life of the citizens of the Town. (Ord. 05-2012, 3-13-2012)
6-12-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
BUILDING MATERIALS: Lumber, bricks, concrete or cinderblocks, plumbing materials, electrical wiring or equipment, heating ducts or equipment,
shingles, mortar, concrete or cement, sand, gravel, dirt, rocks, nails, screws or any other materials, or the debris from such materials, used in
construction or modifying any building, structure or landscaping improvement on any real property.
GARBAGE: Any animal or vegetable waste resulting from the preparation, cooking and serving of food, or the storage or sale of produce, and
includes any discarded, damaged and/or dilapidated household items, wearing apparel of any kind.
JUNK: Any manufactured goods, appliances, fixtures, furniture, machinery, salvage material, scrap metal, scrap material, and other items in such
condition of deterioration or disrepair so as to be unusable in their existing state.
OWNER: Any person leasing, owning, occupying, having the right of possession and/or control of any property real or personal located within the
Town boundaries.
PROPERTY: The area of the owner's lot or tract of land, improved or vacant, and the area to the center of the alley adjacent to the lot or tract of
land, and the sidewalk, parking area, curb, and gutter adjacent to said lot or tract.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 181/449
RECREATIONAL VEHICLE: A self-propelled, wheeled or tracked vehicle primarily designed to be operated for recreational purposes on land or on
land and water and which is not licensed for travel on public streets, roads or highways, including without limitation trail bikes, dirt bikes, minibikes,
tote-goats, dune buggies, go-carts, snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles.
RUBBISH: All accumulation of waste; refuse; rejected animal, mineral or vegetable matter; manure; ashes; wastepaper; cans; bottles; leaves;
grass cuttings; shrubbery and tree trimmings; weeds; or other waste material. Rubbish shall also mean discarded construction materials, including,
but not limited to, the following: lumber, plaster, roofing material, gravel, bricks, sheetrock, concrete blocks and landscaping ground cover.
TOWN ADMINISTRATOR: The Town Administrator or designee.
UNUSABLE MERCHANDISE: Parts of machinery or motor vehicles, appliances that can no longer be used for their intended purpose, remnants of
wood, metal, plastic or any other material or cast off material of any kind, whether or not same could be put to some reasonable use, or any item of
merchandise that is so dilapidated or deteriorated that it cannot be reasonably used for its intended purpose. (Ord. 05-2012, 3-13-2012; amd. Ord.
04-2019, 2-12-2019)
6-12-3: UNLAWFUL PROPERTY CONDITIONS:
A. Building Materials: In any area zoned for residential use, the outside, uncovered storage upon any real property of building materials is
prohibited, unless there is a current, valid building permit issued by the Town for construction or modification of a structure on the real property,
and the building materials are intended for use in connection with such construction or modification. Building materials may be stored inside an
enclosed building, or may be stacked and covered in the rear of the property, out of view from any adjoining street, whether or not a building
permit is in force.
B. Outside Storage: In any area zoned for residential use, the outside storage or accumulation of unusable merchandise is prohibited.
C. Accumulation Of Trash:
1. In any area zoned for residential use, the outside storage or accumulation of trash, rubbish, garbage, refuse of any kind or litter upon or
around any part of the yard or any area of the ground immediately surrounding the building or structure located on the real property, including
porches or landings of such buildings, is prohibited.
2. In any area zoned for multifamily residential use, the common areas, parking areas and streets shall also be kept clear of trash, garbage,
rubbish and refuse, except for common trash enclosures.
3. In any area zoned for commercial use, the owner, proprietor, landlord or management company shall ensure that the premises, including the
parking lot and that part of any public right-of-way adjoining the premises and outside the curb line are kept free of trash, rubbish, garbage,
discarded merchandise, discarded goods or materials or any other kind of junk or refuse of any kind. The owner, proprietor, landlord or
management company shall provide for daily cleaning of the premises and other such areas and take all reasonable steps to provide trash
receptacles and order all employees and tenants to use them.
D. Motor Vehicles: In any area zoned for residential use, the owner or occupant of real property shall maintain any and all areas of said real
property free and clear of inoperable, unsafe, unlawful or abandoned motor vehicles, motor homes or recreational vehicles. (Ord. 04-2019, 2-
12-2019)
6-12-4: LITTERING:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, throw, or leave any litter on any public or private property or in any waters.
B. It shall be an affirmative defense, that:
1. Such property is an area designated by law for the disposal of such material and the person is authorized by proper public authority to so
use the property; or
2. The litter is placed in a receptacle or container installed on such property for that purpose; or
3. Such person is the owner or occupant in lawful possession of such property.
C. "Litter" as used in this section, means all garbage, rubbish, waste material, trash, debris, or other foreign substances, solid or liquid, of every
form, size, kind and description.
D. Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle in violation of this section, the operator of said motor vehicle is
presumed to have caused or permitted the litter to be so thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped therefrom. (Ord. 05-2012, 3-13-2012)
6-12-5: BUILDING MATERIALS2:
(Rep. by Ord. 04-2019, 2-12-2019)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 182/449
6-12-6: STORAGE AND REMOVAL OF GARBAGE AND RUBBISH:
A. Removal And Disposal Required: All garbage and rubbish must be removed from the places where the same shall accumulate, and be
disposed of in such a manner as provided herein. It shall be unlawful for an owner of property to fail to cause all garbage and rubbish to be
removed from said property on a regular basis, so as not to create a public nuisance.
B. Storage Of Garbage And Rubbish:
1. Storage Requirements: Garbage and rubbish stored for prompt removal from the property shall be stored in closed containers located on the
property. In the event the size of an item of garbage or rubbish exceeds the size of the container intended for storage of garbage and
rubbish, the item(s) may be stored on the property in a location so as not to create a public nuisance. Any oversize item of garbage or
rubbish stored outside of a closed container shall be promptly removed from the property, as required in subsection A of this section.
2. Containers:
a. The container used for storage of garbage and rubbish shall be a receptacle of a solid and durable grade of metal or plastic provided with
a tightly fitting cover, or a plastic bag of adequate weight and strength to resist tearing.
b. The container shall be covered or sealed at all times except when depositing garbage or rubbish.
c. The container shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition so as to promote insect, pest and rodent control, and prevent attracting
wild or stray animals.
d. Each container may be located adjacent to the street or sidewalk only for pick up by the licensed hauler, and only for a period of twenty
four (24) hours from the time of pick up.
e. Except for purposes of pick up, no container shall be stored in a front yard adjacent to a street.
C. Frequency And Methods Of Removal:
1. All garbage and rubbish accumulated pursuant to this section shall be removed from the property at least once every two (2) weeks.
2. Removal may be accomplished in the following manner:
a. Commercial hauler licensed to operate in the Town.
b. A person may haul or dispose of his/her own garbage and/or rubbish provided the health, safety and welfare of the public is not
endangered and that no items of garbage and/or rubbish are scattered or thrown onto any street, alley, sidewalk, public or private property.
D. Burning Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any garbage and/or rubbish in any incinerator, stove, fireplace, furnace or by any
other means. (Ord. 751, 5-23-2001)
6-12-7: OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS:
A. Prohibited: It is unlawful and a public nuisance for any person to deposit or store on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public right-of-way, any
debris, lumber, sand, gravel, dirt, rocks, brick, or any other construction or landscaping materials of any type, or any dumpster, container, or
other material or substance.
B. Permit - Dumpster: Upon proper application filed with the Town Clerk's Office, a permit may be issued to allow the temporary placement of a
dumpster or similar container on a street, alley or other public right-of-way as specifically designated in the permit. No such dumpster or similar
container shall be placed on any sidewalk or in such a manner as to block traffic, pedestrians or in such a manner as to create a safety hazard.
C. Permit - Landscape Materials: Upon proper application filed with the Town Clerk's Office, a permit may be issued to allow the temporary
placement of landscape materials, to include, but not be limited to soil, mulch, rock, gravel, on a street, alley or other public right-of-way as
specifically designated in the permit. No such items shall be placed on any sidewalk or in such a manner as to block traffic, pedestrians or in
such a manner as to create a safety hazard.
D. Authorized Items: A permit shall be issued only where the items authorized are necessary for landscaping, construction, alteration or repair of
adjoining property, and shall be limited to sixty (60) days in any consecutive twelve (12) month period, unless the Town Clerk grants one (1) 60-
day extension prior to the expiration of the permit.
E. Violations: Violations of this section are noncriminal. Upon conviction, the penalties in subsection 1-4-4A of this Code shall apply. (Ord. 25-2019,
8-27-2019)
6-12-8: COMPOST PILES:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 183/449
A. Compost Piles Permitted: The owner of any property may maintain compost piles that are separated areas containing plant refuse materials and
soil maintained to facilitate decomposition and produce organic material to be used as a soil conditioner.
B. Nuisance Conditions Prohibited: No owner of property who maintains a compost pile shall fail to prevent a compost pile from becoming a
nuisance by putrefaction or attracting insects, rodents or other animals. No owner of property shall permit a compost pile to become a health or
safety hazard.
C. Violations: Violations of this section may be subject to prosecution in the Municipal Court and/or abatement procedures pursuant to sections 6-
12-11 and 6-12-12 of this chapter. (Ord. 751, 5-23-2001)
6-12-9: ENFORCEMENT:
A. Summons And Complaint: Upon a violation of this chapter, an officer may issue the owner a summons and complaint to appear in the Erie
Municipal Court.
B. Violations: The provisions of this chapter are designated as noncriminal violations. Upon conviction, penalties set forth at subsection 1-4-4A of
this Code shall apply. (Ord. 05-2012, 3-13-2012)
6-12-10: ABATEMENT; DUTY OF OFFICERS, RIGHT TO ENTER PROPERTY:
The Chief of Police, or designee, or other such person as may be designated by the Town Administrator, shall ascertain and cause all public
nuisances declared to be such by this or any other provisions of this Code to be abated. If practicable, such officers may initially request the owner
or occupant for permission to enter private property not then open to the public for purposes of inspection and abatement enforcement. Otherwise,
unless an emergency is found to exist, resulting in exigent circumstances, such officer shall obtain a search warrant as provided for in rule 241,
Colorado Municipal Court Rules of Procedure. (Ord. 05-2012, 3-13-2012)
6-12-11: ABATEMENT; NOTICE AND ORDER TO ABATE, ABATEMENT, RECOVERY OF COSTS:
A. Whenever the Town Administrator determines that a nuisance exists on or in any property, under this chapter, the Town Administrator may
provide written notice in the manner provided in subsection C of this section.
B. Written notice of any nuisance, shall:
1. Include the property address;
2. Describe the violation(s);
3. Include a correction order allowing ten (10) days, or less time where warranted at the discretion of the town administrator, to make necessary
repairs and improvements to abate the nuisance;
4. Inform the owner, occupant of the right to appeal pursuant to this chapter;
5. Include a statement of the town's right to abate the nuisance and file a lien in accordance with this section.
C. Service of the written abatement notice shall be by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the owner as reflected on the records of the county
clerk's office. Besides service by mail, the officer may, if practicable, provide a copy of the abatement notice by hand delivery to the owner, or
by posting such notice on the subject property, or by other means reasonably calculated to provide notice.
D. It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any property, in or upon which any nuisance may be found, to abate the same within the time
specified in the abatement notice. Timely filing of an appeal from the abatement notice under this section shall extend the time for abatement
until a final ruling on the appeal is issued. In addition to any other available sanction or relief, if such owner or occupant neglects or refuses to
comply with the requirements of such order within the time specified, he or she commits a violation of this chapter.
E. The town administrator, or designee, shall be duly authorized to abate any nuisance specified in this chapter, which shall include authority to
engage the necessary assistance and incur necessary expense therefor.
F. The expense incurred by the town in abating any nuisance as provided herein may be recovered by proper action from the owner or occupant of
such property.
G. The town administrator shall certify to the town clerk the costs incurred in the abatement of the nuisance, including administrative costs and
attorney fees and five percent (5%) for inspection and other incidental costs in connection therewith.
H. Notice of assessment; appeal of charges:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 184/449
1. Upon receipt of the statement of charges, the town clerk shall mail to the owner of record of the subject property a notice, stating the amount
and grounds for the charges; the deadline for payment of the assessment, and that in the event such payment is not made, the town will
assess the charges against the property; that any objection to the proposed assessment must be made in writing and filed with the town
clerk's office within fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice of assessment. Upon the expiration of the fourteen (14) day period, if the town
clerk receives no objections, and if payment in full has not been received, the town clerk shall certify such charges to the clerk to the county
treasurer who shall collect the assessment together with a ten percent (10%) penalty for cost of collection, in the same manner as other
taxes are collected.
2. If the property owner files timely appeal with the town clerk, the town clerk shall refer the matter to a hearing officer appointed by the town
administrator.
3. Upon conclusion of administrative review, the hearing officer shall determine, in writing, whether the charges are proper. The appellant shall
have the burden of proof, by a preponderance of the evidence. The hearing officer shall affirm, cancel or reduce the charges. The written
ruling of the hearing officer shall be provided to the town clerk and the property owner.
4. The hearing officer may reduce or cancel a proposed assessment if it is determined that any of the following did not conform to the
provisions of this section:
a. Any required notice to correct the subject violations; or
b. The work performed in abating the nuisance; or
c. The computation of charges.
5. If the hearing officer affirms the assessment, the owner shall pay the amount in full by the reasonable deadline established by the hearing
officer. In the event timely payment is not received, the town clerk may certify the charges to the clerk to the county treasurer as provided
herein.
I. In addition to the penal remedy and abatement procedure stated in this chapter, any violation of this chapter is a public nuisance, for which there
is no adequate remedy at law, and therefore any court of competent jurisdiction shall, upon the Town Attorney's application, enjoin the
nuisance, as defined in this chapter. Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the Town Attorney from seeking other appropriate legal or equitable
relief from any court of competent jurisdiction. In addition, the owner of any property constituting a nuisance shall be liable to the Town, jointly
and severally with every person creating or maintaining the nuisance, for the Town's reasonable expense incurred in abating the nuisance and
the Town Attorney may commence and prosecute to final judgment an action at law in any court of competent jurisdiction to collect such
expenses. As used in this section, court of competent jurisdiction includes, without limitation, the Erie Municipal Court, which insofar as
practicable, shall consider and determine applications for legal or equitable relief according to the procedures otherwise applicable to
proceedings in Colorado District Courts. (Ord. 05-2012, 3-13-2012)
6-12-12: EMERGENCY ABATEMENT:
A. Whenever the Town Administrator finds that a nuisance exists under this chapter, and places the public health, safety or welfare in immediate
danger, the Town Administrator may issue an emergency abatement order, which shall comply with subsection 6-12-11B of this chapter, except
that the emergency abatement order shall:
1. Allow a time less than ten (10) days, as is reasonable in the circumstances, to abate the nuisance;
2. State that, if the nuisance remains unabated at the end of the reasonable time given, the Town Administrator will cause abatement of the
nuisance according to subsection 6-12-11E of this chapter; and
3. State that, due to the emergency need for abatement, a timely appeal, according to subsection 6-12-11H2 of this chapter may be heard after
the abatement.
B. Timely filing of an appeal from the emergency abatement order shall not extend the time for abatement.
C. If the nuisance remains unabated at the end of the reasonable time given, the Town Administrator shall cause abatement of the nuisance
according to subsection 6-12-11E of this chapter.
D. If the Hearing Officer, upon a timely and proper appeal, finds that the emergency abatement order is unjustified, the Town Clerk shall not certify
and the Town shall not recover abatement costs as a charge or lien against the property. (Ord. 05-2012, 3-13-2012)
6-12-13: MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Every owner, developer, tenant, homeowner's association or special district that has assumed landscape maintenance responsibility shall keep
all landscaping in a well-maintained and healthy growing condition, which shall include the following, at a minimum:
1. Mowing, irrigating, weeding, fertilizing, pruning, and other maintenance appropriate for the type of plant materials in the property.
2. Removal of trash, litter, weeds.
3. Treating plant materials that exhibit evidence of insect, pest or disease damage.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 185/449
4. Removing dead or dying plants or shrubs.
5. Removing dead plant materials, including trees.
6. Replenishing natural landscape materials such as mulch, which no longer cover the area in which they were originally deposited so as to
achieve full coverage.
7. Repairing, replacing or maintaining related structural features, including without limitation reflecting pools, outdoor artwork, screening walls,
retaining walls, fences, benches or other street furniture elements, if readily seen from an adjoining street, sidewalk or Town-maintained trail,
park, landscape or open space area.
8. Any other action reasonably necessary to maintain landscaping.
B. Maintenance responsibility shall include public right-of-way landscaping up to the curb or edge of the street or roadway adjacent to said
property. (Ord. 04-2019, 2-12-2019)
Chapter 13
LAWN GRASSES, WEEDS AND BRUSH
6-13-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public health, safety and welfare, and preserve neighborhood landscape and native environments, by
regulating the type and height of weeds including nonnative herbaceous and woody vegetation and noxious weeds that are allowed in the town,
and to specify limitations of these restrictions on certain areas of the town, in private properties, parks, riparian areas along ditches and streams,
open space, and stream rights of way, that should be allowed to remain in a natural appearing state. (Ord. 754, 7-10-2001)
6-13-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
AGGRESSIVE EXOTIC SPECIES: Aggressive nonnative grasses and other herbaceous plants, deleterious to native plant communities, and
ornamental landscapes, not otherwise listed as weeds, including, but not limited to, creeping bellflower (Campanula rapuncuoides), Japanese
knotweed (Reynoutria japonica), Grossheimia macrocephala, sweetclovers (Melilotus officinale and M. albus), wild carrot (Daucus carota), and
smooth brome (Bromus inermis).
BACKYARD WILDLIFE HABITAT CERTIFICATION: A certification from the Colorado department of natural resources or the national wildlife
federation backyard habitat (.) program or schoolyard habitat () program of having the necessary restored native vegetation and physical
elements to function as a wildlife habitat and excluding aggressive exotic species and other weed species through a regular annual maintenance
program.
BRUSH: Nonnative shrubs and trees which self-propagate and are not part of a planned and maintained landscape of either an ornamental or
native preserved or restored type including, but not limited to, such exotic species as Russian olive (Elaeagnus angustifolia), salt-cedar (Tamarix
ramosissma), Siberian or Chinese elm (Ulmus pumila or siberica) and tree of heaven (Ailanthus altissima). The term "self-propagate" shall mean
the ability to spread beyond the original plant through seed or underground roots in a manner which permits invasion of adjacent areas not
intended for this type of vegetation. The term "brush" includes "brush pile", which shall mean an accumulation of dead branches from shrubs, trees
or weeds.
CONVERTED PASTURE: An area which has been plowed and seeded to exotic agriculturally developed pasture species including, but not limited
to, crested wheatgrass (Agropyron cristatum), smooth brome (Bromus inermis), meadow fescue (Festuca pratensis), timothy (Phleum pratense),
orchardgrass (Dactylis glomerata), or alfalfa (Medicago sativa), or an area which is currently dominated by bare soil or exotic weeds due to heavy
grazing pressure and the loss of native vegetation.
DETENTION OR RETENTION PONDS: Those flood control structures designed and installed in drainages and open space areas for the purpose
of flood flow reduction.
DITCH: A manmade or natural channel for water conveyance and its maintenance and access easements on either side.
HAY MEADOW: An area which has been plowed and seeded to exotic agriculturally developed hay production species including, but not limited to,
smooth brome (Bromus inermis), meadow fescue (Festuca pratensis), or alfalfa (Medicago sativa).
LAWN GRASSES: Species of grass developed for and commonly used as turf including Kentucky bluegrass (Poa pratensis), perennial rye grass
(Lolium perenne), chewing fescue (Festuca rubra), fairway crested wheatgrass (Agropyron cristatum), buffalo grass (Buchloe dactyloides), blue
grama (Bouteloua or Chondrosum gracile), and salt grass (Distichlis stricta).
NATIVE TURF GRASSES: Native species of grass developed for and commonly used as turf including buffalo grass, blue grama, and inland salt
grass.
NATURAL AREA CERTIFICATION: An area certified by the Colorado department of natural resources as an area of one-fourth (1/4) acre or
greater having the necessary characteristics to be registered as a natural area and excluding aggressive exotic species and other weed species
through a regular annual maintenance program.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 186/449
OPEN SPACE AREA: Real property zoned as open space, or designated transition, or designated on plats as open space, or other such
undeveloped real property in single, common or joint ownership.
ORNAMENTAL GRASSES: Exotic and native grasses which are commercially available for use in maintained home landscapes as listed in the
"Guidelines Of Potential Native And Ornamental Grasses" adopted by the town of Erie, as revised, but not including exotic species typical of
improved hay meadows or pastures such as smooth brome (Bromus inermis), orchard grass (Daytylis glomerata), timothy (Phleum pratense), or
meadow fescue (Festuca pratensis).
OWNER: The fee owner of record, an agent or representative of the fee owner, any person entitled by tenancy or lease to possession of the
premises, or the occupant.
PRAIRIE: A parcel of historically unplowed native vegetation or a parcel certified by the town of Erie which is designed, restored, and vigorously
maintained to be true to approved native community design or certified as a preexisting native plant community consisting of grasses and
associated wildflowers native to the region and including, but not limited to, short grass prairie up to twelve inches (12") tall, midgrass prairie up to
eighteen inches (18") tall, and tall grass prairie over eighteen inches (18") tall, and excluding aggressive exotic species and other weed species
through a regular annual maintenance program. "Historically unplowed native vegetation" shall mean an area of essentially undisturbed soil, by
either agriculture or other development, and retaining significant cover by local native vegetation, which is under active maintenance for weed and
aggressive exotic species and brush control.
PROPERTY: The area of the owner's lot or tract of land, improved or vacant, and the area to the center of the alley adjacent to the lot or tract of
land, and the sidewalk, parking area, curb, and gutter adjacent to said lot or tract or land.
STATE OF COLORADO NOXIOUS WEED LIST: Those weeds as are identified by the commissioner of the state of Colorado department of
agriculture or his or her designee on the state noxious weed list prepared in accordance with the requirements of the "Colorado noxious weed act",
Colorado Revised Statutes section 35-5.5-101 et seq.
TOWN ADMINISTRATOR: The town administrator or the designated representative of the town administrator.
WEED OR WEEDS: Aggressive nonnative grasses and other herbaceous plants, deleterious to native plant communities, ornamental landscapes,
and agricultural areas including, but not limited to, redroot pigweed (Amaranthus retrofexus), common ragweed (Ambrosia artemisifolia), giant
ragweed (Ambrosia trifida), wild oats (Avena fatua), wild mustards (Brassica hirta, B. kaber, B. niger, B. rapa), knapweeds (Centaurea maculosa,
C. repens, C. diffusa), prickly lettuce (Lactuca seriola), curly dock (Rumex crispus), buckhorn plantain (Plantago lanceolata), buffalo burr (Solanum
rostratum), shepherd's purse (Thlaspi arvense), cocklebur (Xanthium strumaruim), and all weed species on the Colorado noxious weed list as
defined in this section, including all new or old synonyms, but does not include other nonlisted plants in flower or vegetable gardens; small plots of
wheat, barley, oats, or rye; actively grazed pastures; and planned and maintained shrubs and woody plants on private and public lands.
XERISCAPE: A landscape certified by the town of Erie which is designed, planted, and vigorously maintained to be true to approved design and
excluding aggressive exotic species and other weed species through a regular annual maintenance program. (Ord. 754, 7-10-2001; amd. Ord. 30-
2008, 10-14-2008)
6-13-3: GROWTH OR ACCUMULATION OF WEEDS AND BRUSH:
A. It shall be deemed a public nuisance and unlawful to permit or maintain on any property any growth or accumulation of weeds to a height
greater than twelve inches (12"). (Ord. 754, 7-10-2001; amd. Ord. 30-2008, 10-14-2008)
B. It shall be deemed a public nuisance and unlawful to permit or maintain on any property the growth of species on the Colorado noxious weed
list on such property regardless of height.
C. It shall be deemed a public nuisance and unlawful to permit or maintain on any property any growth or accumulation of brush. (Ord. 754, 7-10-
2001)
6-13-4: HEIGHT OF GRASSES RESTRICTED1:
A. Exotic Grasses: It shall be deemed a public nuisance and unlawful to permit or maintain the growth of aggressive exotic species of grasses
including, but not limited to, smooth brome (Bromus inermis), meadow fescue (Festuca pratensis), timothy (Phleum pratense), orchard grass
(Dactylis glomerata), alfalfa (Medicago sativa), in excess of twelve inches (12") in height on any part of any property, unless said parcel is an
actively grazed pasture or annually mowed hay meadow. (Ord. 754, 7-10-2001; amd. Ord. 30-2008, 10-14-2008)
B. Lawn Grasses: It shall be deemed a public nuisance and unlawful to permit or maintain the growth of lawn grasses in excess of six inches (6")
in height on any residentially zoned or landscaped property. (Ord. 30-2008, 10-14-2008)
6-13-5: VARIANCES:
A. Community Open Spaces, Ditches, Ponds And Certified Areas:
1. Any owner of any property that is a community open space area, ditch, detention or detention pond area or has been granted a certified
backyard wildlife habitat, a certified school yard habitat, a certified Xeriscape, or a certified restored native prairie may maintain growth of
approved native or ornamental grasses in excess of twelve inches (12") in height.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 187/449
2. Approved ornamental and native grasses may be allowed to grow to full height. The town administrator may request mowing such grasses to
reduce fire hazard when declared by a relevant competent authority. (Ord. 30-2008, 10-14-2008)
3. Weeds, noxious weeds, and brush must be controlled on all property including community open space areas, ditches, detention or detention
pond areas, certified backyard wildlife habitats, schoolyard habitats, certified xeriscapes, certified restored native landscapes or prairies, and
certified historically unplowed vegetation as required by this chapter. (Ord. 754, 7-10-2001)
B. Grasses In Landscaped Flower Or Shrub Beds: It is lawful for any owner to maintain approved ornamental and native grasses in a well
maintained landscape. Said grasses may be allowed to grow to full height. All weeds, including noxious weeds, aggressive exotic species, hay
meadow and converted pasture grasses, and brush must be controlled throughout as required by this chapter. (Ord. 30-2008, 10-14-2008)
6-13-6: ENFORCEMENT; AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
A. Any Erie police officer, code enforcement officer, or the town administrator, is authorized and empowered to examine or cause to be examined
every premises suspected to contain unlawful height and/or accumulation of weeds and brush for purposes of enforcement of this chapter
and/or abatement. If violations are found to exist, the officer may issue the owner a summons and complaint to appear in the Erie municipal
court. Compliance with the requirements of this chapter prior to the court appearance may be considered in mitigation.
B. If practicable, such officer may initially request the owner for permission to enter private property not then open to the public for purposes of
inspection. Otherwise, unless an emergency is found to exist resulting in exigent circumstances, such officer shall obtain a search warrant as
provided for in rule 241, municipal court rules of procedure, as amended. (Ord. 754, 7-10-2001)
6-13-7: ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
A. Whenever the town administrator, or designee determines that a nuisance exists on or in any property, under this chapter, the town
administrator, or designee, may provide written notice in the manner provided in subsection C of this section.
B. Written notice of any nuisance, shall:
1. Include the property address;
2. Describe the violation(s);
3. Include a correction order allowing ten (10) days, or less time where warranted at the discretion of the town administrator, or designee, to
make necessary repairs and improvements to abate the nuisance;
4. Inform the owner, occupant of the right to appeal pursuant to this chapter;
5. Include a statement of the town's right to abate the nuisance and file a lien in accordance with this section.
C. Service of the written abatement notice shall be by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the owner as reflected on the records of the county
clerk's office. Besides service by mail, the officer may, if practicable, provide a copy of the abatement notice by hand delivery to the owner, or
by posting such notice on the subject property, or by other means reasonably calculated to provide notice.
D. It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any property, in or upon which any nuisance may be found, to abate the same within the time
specified in the abatement notice. Timely filing of an appeal from the abatement notice under this section shall extend the time for abatement
until a final ruling on the appeal is issued. In addition to any other available sanction or relief, if such owner or occupant neglects or refuses to
comply with the requirements of such order within the time specified, he or she commits a violation of this chapter.
E. The town administrator, or designee, shall be duly authorized to abate any nuisance specified in this chapter, which shall include authority to
engage the necessary assistance and incur necessary expense therefor.
F. The expense incurred by the town in abating any nuisance as provided herein may be recovered by proper action from the owner or occupant of
such property.
G. The town administrator, or designee, shall certify to the town clerk the costs incurred in the abatement of the nuisance, including administrative
costs and attorney fees and five percent (5%) for inspection and other incidental costs in connection therewith.
H. Notice of assessment; appeal of charges:
1. Upon receipt of the statement of charges, the town clerk shall mail to the owner of record of the subject property a notice, stating the amount
and grounds for the charges; the deadline for payment of the assessment, and that in the event such payment is not made, the town will
assess the charges against the property; that any objection to the proposed assessment must be made in writing and filed with the town
clerk's office within fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice of assessment. Upon the expiration of the fourteen (14) day period, if the town
clerk receives no objections, and if payment in full has not been received, the town clerk shall certify such charges to the clerk to the county
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 188/449
treasurer who shall collect the assessment together with a ten percent (10%) penalty for cost of collection, in the same manner as other
taxes are collected.
2. If the property owner files timely appeal with the town clerk, the town clerk shall refer the matter to a hearing officer appointed by the town
administrator.
3. Upon conclusion of administrative review, the hearing officer shall determine, in writing, whether the charges are proper. The appellant shall
have the burden of proof, by a preponderance of the evidence. The hearing officer shall affirm, cancel or reduce the charges. The written
ruling of the hearing officer shall be provided to the town clerk and the property owner.
4. The hearing officer may reduce or cancel a proposed assessment if it is determined that any of the following did not conform to the
provisions of this section:
a. Any required notice to correct the subject violations; or
b. The work performed in abating the nuisance; or
c. The computation of charges.
5. If the hearing officer affirms the assessment, the owner shall pay the amount in full by the reasonable deadline established by the hearing
officer. In the event timely payment is not received, the town clerk may certify the charges to the clerk to the county treasurer as provided
herein.
I. In addition to the penal remedy and abatement procedure stated in this chapter, any violation of this chapter is a public nuisance, for which there
is no adequate remedy at law, and therefore any court of competent jurisdiction shall, upon the town attorney's application, enjoin the nuisance,
as defined in this chapter. Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the town attorney from seeking other appropriate legal or equitable relief from
any court of competent jurisdiction. In addition, the owner of any property constituting a nuisance shall be liable to the town, jointly and
severally with every person creating or maintaining the nuisance, for the town's reasonable expense incurred in abating the nuisance and the
town attorney may commence and prosecute to final judgment an action at law in any court of competent jurisdiction to collect such expenses.
As used in this section, court of competent jurisdiction includes, without limitation, the Erie municipal court, which insofar as practicable, shall
consider and determine applications for legal or equitable relief according to the procedures otherwise applicable to proceedings in Colorado
district courts. (Ord. 08-2012, 3-13-2012)
Title 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
7-1-1: ADOPTION OF STREET DEVELOPMENT POLICIES, STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
The street development policies, standards and specifications for the town, which policies, standards and specifications contain the following
provisions, are incorporated herein by reference. The street development policies, standards and specifications are on file in the office of the town
clerk for public inspection. (Ord. 256, 4-26-1973; amd. 2004 Code)
A. Article 1, The Town Street System: This article designates the authority, jurisdiction and purposes of these regulations and provides for the
classification of the streets in the town.
B. Article 2, Town Street Development: This article establishes the general planning, design and construction criteria for new streets within the
town and outlines procedures for the inspection, testing and acceptance of new streets for maintenance. In addition, this article provides for
encroachment and overload permits and sets forth bonding requirements prior to new street construction.
C. Article 3, Street Standards: This article establishes the detailed design criteria to be used in the design of new roads and streets within the town
in regard to layout, sight distance, curvature, vertical alignment, geometric cross sections and structural cross sections. Specific requirements
for drainage structures, curb and gutter, sidewalks, paving, bridges, traffic control devices and guardrails are also detailed in this article.
D. Article 4, Specifications: This article establishes the specifications for earthwork, subbase and base course material and paving. In addition, the
procedures for sampling, testing and approval of materials are detailed in this article.
E. Article 5, Definition Of Terms: The definitions of terms and the construction of the same as used in these regulations are given in this article.
F. Article 6, Drawings And Graphs: This article provides graphic representation of typical sections and specific design charts to be used in the
design of new roads and streets within the town.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 189/449
G. Article 7, Administrative Provisions: This article provides administrative provisions relative to variances from these regulations, the repeal of
previously applicable ordinances, and the statement of severability of the provisions of these regulations. (Ord. 256, 4-26-1973)
7-1-2: STREET AND SIDEWALK GRADES:
A. Datum Established: The following described points are hereby established as the datum or plane or bench mark from which the elevations and
grades of streets and sidewalks in the town shall be determined.
The upper surface of a stone marked "B.M.", situated on the south front of the town hall, the elevation of said datum, plane or bench mark
being four thousand nine hundred sixty eight and seven-hundredths feet (4,968.07') above the ocean.
Also, the iron floor in the doorway of the store in Odd Fellows Hall, the elevation of which is four thousand nine hundred seventy one and sixtyfive-
hundredths feet (4,971.65') above the ocean.
B. Determination Of Street And Sidewalk Grades:
1. Streets: The grades of the several streets of the town shall be the grade at the centerline of said streets, and the grade between all points
shall be in a uniform direct line between each two (2) points so given, ascending, descending, or level as the case may be.
2. Sidewalks: The grades of the sidewalks along the several streets shall be the grades at the building or lot line of the property adjacent to
such sidewalks, and the grade between all points when elevations are given shall be in a uniform direct line between such points, ascending,
descending or level as the case may be, except when otherwise especially provided. (1928 Code, part II)
C. Profile References: The elevations indicated in the profiles shall be from said established datum, plane or bench mark, and to determine the
elevation or grade of any street or sidewalk where the grade may be established, reference must be made to the profiles of such streets and
sidewalks on file in the office of the town clerk. (1928 Code, part II; amd. 2004 Code)
D. Grades Of Specific Streets And Sidewalks:
1. Kattell Avenue: The grades in the center of Kattell Avenue at the intersections with the following streets shall be as follows:

7-1-3: RIGHT OF WAY WORK:
A. Permit Requirements:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 190/449
1. Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person or entity, other than those persons or entities under contract with the town, to perform
work within the right of way, street, sidewalk, curb, gutter, curbwalk, alley or other public place without having first obtained a right of way
permit from the department of public works.
2. Application For Permit: Application for the required right of way permit shall be made on the permit application form as provided by the
authorized representative of the town. The completed application shall recite specifically and shall illustrate by sketch or plan the exact
location, depth, extent, nature and purpose of the work desired to be made, the purpose for which the work is requested, and the duration of
the time required for the work.
3. Permit Fee: No right of way permit will be issued until such time as the applicant for such right of way permit has paid the required fee, as
provided in section 2-10-4 of this code, to the town. Persons and entities (and their subcontractors) that have a franchise agreement with the
town will not be charged for the right of way permit, although a right of way permit shall still be required prior to performance of the work.
4. Qualified Applicants: Any person or entity properly licensed pursuant to the provisions of the town ordinances is eligible to apply for a right of
way permit.
5. Issuance Of Permit: The right of way permit shall be issued once the applicant has met all of the application requirements of the town and
the applicable town ordinance requirements addressing the proposed work. Any person or entity specifically authorized to perform the
proposed work pursuant to the terms of an ordinance, resolution or contract of the board of trustees shall be recognized as possessing a
right of way permit based on the ordinance, resolution, or contract to complete said work and will not be required to obtain a right of way
permit as required herein.
6. Conditions Of Permit:
a. The right of way permit shall only be valid for the specific project as set forth in the application and defined and specified on the right of
way permit.
b. A copy of the required right of way permit will be kept at the work site and presented to the authorized representative of the town as
requested.
c. All work completed pursuant to the right of way permit shall meet the requirements of the town design and construction standards.
d. As a requirement of the right of way permit, no trenches or excavations will be backfilled until such trench or excavation is inspected and
approved by the authorized representative of the town. The person or entity holding the right of way permit shall contact the town
representative, notify the town of the starting date of the work to be done pursuant to the right of way permit, and shall schedule for such
inspections as are required herein.
7. Records Kept: The authorized representative of the town shall keep a record of all applications for right of way permits and right of way
permits issued.
8. Licensed Permittees; Bond And/Or Insurance: All persons or entities applying for a right of way permit must be licensed pursuant to town
ordinances and must provide proof of the insurance and/or bonding as may be required by the town ordinances to the town clerk.
B. Street Obstructions: It shall be unlawful for any person or entity during the course of the proposed work to obstruct more than the space of one
town block and one traffic intersection at the same time in any one street. The time availability requirements for such obstruction shall be
scheduled by the holder of the right of way permit in advance with the authorized representative of the town.
C. Restoration And Repairs:
1. All restoration and repairs shall be made in accordance with the standards and specifications for design and construction of public
improvements.
2. In the event of settlement or subsidence of a particular excavation or part thereof, the person or entity having performed the excavation shall
be responsible for fully repairing such settlement or subsidence at his sole expense.
D. Liability For Damage Or Injury: Any person who undertakes work pursuant to a right of way permit issued under the provisions of this section, or
performs work under contract with the town or by permission obtained from the town board of trustees shall be fully liable and responsible for
any and all damage or injury to persons, animals, objects and property caused by such work. (Ord. 22-2010, 9-14-2010)
7-1-4: MAINTENANCE OF SIDEWALKS AND CROSSINGS:
A. Sidewalks: The owner of any lot in the town shall grade and keep in repair the sidewalks adjoining his respective lot in such manner and at such
times as the board of trustees may direct, and in case said owner fails to perform such work within thirty (30) days after notice or publication by
the director of public works or his designee the work may be done by the town under the direction of the director of public works or his designee
and the cost shall be assessed against the said lot to be collected as other town taxes.
B. Crossings: Whenever any owner of any lot in the town shall maintain a place for the crossing of any of the sidewalks of the town with any
vehicle, such owner shall have the same kept clear of all dirt, filth or rubbish and keep the same in such repair as will ensure at all times a
good, safe and dry crossing for pedestrians, and said crossing shall conform to the grades and level of the sidewalks on each side of said
crossing. (1928 Code, part II; amd. 2004 Code)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 191/449
Chapter 2
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT PERMIT REQUIREMENTS (PIP)
7-2-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter is known as the TOWN OF ERIE PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT PERMIT ORDINANCE. (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-2: PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted to ensure that proper installation of any public improvement is accomplished in accordance with town specifications and
regulations. (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, excavate, convert, or demolish
any public improvements or common facilities regulated by the town "Construction Standards and Specifications" and this chapter, without first
obtaining a public improvement permit (PIP) from the town. (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Applicants for public improvement permits shall complete and submit an application in writing on a form furnished by the town for that purpose.
The applicant must also submit two (2) sets of plans with the application, as per section 7-2-5 of this chapter. As a minimum each application shall:
A. Identify and describe the work to be covered by the permit being requested.
B. Provide the legal description and street address or similar description that will readily identify the land where the work will be completed.
C. Indicate the type of work or improvement intended.
D. Be accompanied by a set of plans, diagrams, computations and specifications, and other data required in this chapter and any other regulations
concerning construction standards. Construction drawings and specifications will be signed and sealed by a valid licensed state of Colorado
professional engineer.
E. Submit completed PIP worksheet which includes quantities of the work to be performed.
F. Be signed by the owner(s) or his/her legally authorized agent.
G. Contain an estimated project start and completion date.
H. Any other information as may be required by the town. (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-5: PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
A. Submittal: Plans, engineering specifications, diagrams and other data shall be submitted in at least two (2) full sets at the time of application for
a PIP. The plans, etc., submitted shall have been prepared and designed by a registered professional engineer licensed to practice in the state.
Plans and specifications shall be drawn to scale and shall have sufficient clarity to indicate the location, nature, and extent of the work
proposed and show in detail that they conform to town "Construction Standards and Specifications", all relevant laws, ordinances, rules, and
regulations. All plans and specifications will be prepared in accordance with standards of the industry. All construction plans will be checked for
conformance with town construction standards and specifications prior to acceptance and the issuance of a PIP to the applicant. One set will
be returned if changes are required or recommended. Engineering design will remain the responsibility of the professional design engineer
used by the applicant.
B. Acceptance: Upon final acceptance of the plans by the town, a minimum of three (3) sets of plans in a twenty four inch by thirty six inch
(24" x 36") form will be submitted to the town. The plans shall be signed and sealed by the registered professional engineer responsible for the
design. The plans submitted shall have been prepared and designed by a registered professional engineer licensed to practice in the state, and
a signature block for the town shall appear on the plans in accordance with the town standards and specifications. Upon issuance of a PIP, a
minimum of one of the plan sets shall be signed and returned to the applicant, and two (2) plan sets will remain on file with the town. The
contractor must keep at least one set of plans on the project site for the duration of the project. Should circumstances warrant a change to the
accepted plans, approval to make such changes must be obtained in writing from the town. It will be the duty of the permit holder to ensure the
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 192/449
changes have been recorded and resubmitted to the town on as built drawings, which are in compliance with town "Construction Standards
and Specifications". (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-6: PERMIT FEES:
The fees for a PIP shall be as set forth in section 2-10-4 of this code. These fees shall be calculated on a cumulative basis and shall be paid in full
at the time the plans and specifications have been accepted by the town and a PIP is issued. A PIP shall be required for all public improvement
construction in a public right of way or in a public easement. However, the fee for installation of certain public utilities, i.e., underground electrical,
gas, telephone, cable TV, etc., or construction of town capital improvement projects, may be waived by the town or governed by agreement with
the town. (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-7: EXPIRATION OF APPLICATION REVIEW; EXTENSIONS:
Applications for which no PIP is issued within one hundred eighty (180) days of the date of application shall expire, and any plans or data
submitted for review shall be destroyed or retained by the town, at its discretion, or will be returned to the applicant upon request. If the applicant
makes a written request to extend the application review, the town may extend the life of the application for a further one hundred eighty (180)
days. No application shall be extended more than once. If no action is taken by the applicant to pursue PIP beyond the submittal of the application
after the expiration of the extension, a new application shall be required of the applicant to renew action by the town. Furthermore, should it be
deemed necessary for the town to hire a private consulting firm for the plan review, the applicant shall pay these additional costs. (Ord. 802, 1-14-
2003)
7-2-8: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
The town will review the application, plans, specifications, and any other data filed by the applicant for a PIP. Various departments may verify
compliance. If the town finds that the work described in an application is complete and in accordance with the town "Construction Standards and
Specifications" and other pertinent laws, and a permit fee has been paid, a permit will be issued to the applicant. These accepted plans may not be
modified or altered without authorization from the town, and all work will be completed as per the accepted plans. The issuing of a permit based
upon plans, specifications or other data will not prevent the town from requiring the correction of errors in those plans, which were not corrected at
the time of application. In such cases, the town may, at its discretion, stop construction until such corrections, which are necessary, have been
made. (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-9: EXPIRATION OF PERMIT:
Every PIP issued by the town shall expire if the work authorized by the PIP is substantially completed. "Substantially completed" shall mean that all
public improvements are operable as determined by an inspection by the town. If it is determined that the project is delayed, abandoned, or work
has stopped for no apparent reason, the project shall cease, and a new permit will be required to complete the project. The new permit will require
a fee of twenty five percent (25%) of the original permit price, provided no changes to the accepted plans have been made. Should the accepted
approved plans be changed, a new PIP permit and fees are required. In no case shall an extension of a PIP cause a site to be left in such a state
as to create a hazard or nuisance. (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-10: WORKING WITHOUT A PERMIT; INVESTIGATION FEES:
Any work performed, which is not covered by an issued PIP, shall cease upon written notice of the town. An investigation fee shall be levied which
is equal to the amount of the PIP fee, plus any fees required for investigation time. These cumulative fees shall be collected whether or not a
proper PIP is issued after the investigation. The payment of such investigation fees shall not exempt any person from compliance with all other
provisions of this chapter nor from any other penalty prescribed by law. (Ord. 802, 1-14-2003)
7-2-11: INSPECTIONS:
A. Inspection Required; Notice: All construction work for which a PIP is required shall be subject to inspection by the town, and special types of
construction shall be required to have continuous inspections by special inspectors. It is the responsibility of the applicant or designated
representatives of the applicant to notify the town that the work performed is ready for inspection. Every request for inspection shall be filed at
least three (3) days before inspection is desired, unless an early inspection is made necessary by prior agreement with the town. An inspection
request shall be made in writing or by telephone call to the appropriate town employee, at the option of the town and on a case by case basis.
The person requesting inspection shall provide access to the site and work to be inspected by the town.
B. Defective Work: The town shall have the authority to halt construction when the accepted plans and/or town regulations governing construction
have not been adhered to, or the work is otherwise defective. The town shall give the applicant written notice of the deficiencies to be corrected
and the time frame in which the corrections are expected to be completed, and may order further construction to cease until all deficiencies are
corrected. If the deficiencies are not corrected by the time frame specified, the town may evoke enforcement options authorized by this chapter,
and/or any performance guarantees under which the work is being performed.
C. Final Inspection: The procedure for final inspection and acceptance will be by mutual agreement between the town and the applicant, or as
specified in any contract documents or as provided by applicable town regulations.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
