water service authorized by the permit is not completed within one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of such permit. Any person desiring
to extend a permit beyond one hundred eighty (180) days shall apply for an extension of the permit, at which time the person shall pay the
town's minimum water service charge on a monthly basis until the water service is completed. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-8: WATER TAPS:
A. Water Taps Required:
1. For each water meter, a separate water tap must be purchased from the Town and all required tap fees paid to the Town, except as
specifically set forth herein. Individual units within apartment buildings shall not be treated as unattached water using units and shall be
served by one tap. Commercial buildings consisting of multiple individual tenants, whether or not units are individually owned, and
condominiums and townhomes with individually owned units, may have either: a) vaults with manifolds and separate service lines for each
unit; or b) a common water tap to the units within the building as a single water using unit, upon the written election of the owner. Such
election shall be referenced on the site plan and an agreement regarding the owner's election shall be recorded with the property. (Ord. 23-
2019, 8-13-2019)
2. No person(s) may enlarge or change the type of use for which water was originally taken and used from the Town water system without
making application and receiving written consent from the Town.
B. Denial Of Service Allowed: The Town reserves the right to deny any request for a water tap if it finds that it does not have sufficient water to
serve the demand for said tap.
C. Size Of Tap: No water tap and connection less than three-fourths inch (3/4") in size shall be permitted. The tap or connection size shall be
determined by the latest Building Code adopted by the Town1.
D. Public Buildings: No tap fee shall be charged to new public buildings owned by the Town. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
E. Public Parks And Open Space: No tap fee shall be charged for irrigation of new public parks and open space owned by the Town. (Ord. 23-
2019, 8-13-2019)
F. Fire Control Prevention:
1. Water for automatic fire control protection systems shall only be provided to properties which are connected to the Town's water system
pursuant to the terms of this chapter.
2. In the event a person desires or is required to provide automatic fire control protection for emergency service only which requires a tap larger
than four inches (4"), a separate tap shall be required.
3. Under no circumstances shall water from said service be utilized for any purpose other than fire control protection.
4. No tap fee shall be charged for an automatic fire control protection system, regardless of the size.
5. Under this provision, the user shall be required to pay the full cost of installation of the service, including all pipes, valves, boxes, and tap
construction.
G. Taps Outside Corporate Limits: No water taps shall be made outside the corporate limits of the Town, nor shall any water be furnished from the
Town water system to any person or property outside said corporate limits, except by special written agreement with the Town Board, under
such conditions as the Town Board may deem proper. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-9: WATER RIGHTS DEDICATIONS:
A. Intent And Purpose: It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to require the payment of fees in lieu of water dedication for all uses except the
irrigation of parks and open space. For parks and open space, a person may elect to either pay such fees or dedicate water rights to the Town.
Any payment of fees in lieu of water dedication or dedication of water rights required for the irrigation of parks and open space shall be
sufficient to satisfy any new or additional demand for Town water service resulting from the extension of water service, or any change in land
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 210/449
use, within or outside the limits of the Town, which will require new or additional water supply from the Town, and thereby to assure an
adequate and stable supply of water to all Town water users, to ensure the financial stability of the Town water utility, and to promote the
general welfare of the public. However, water dedication or payment of fees in lieu of water dedication shall not be required for irrigation of new
public parks and open space owned by the Town or for new public buildings owned by the Town. (Ord. 23-2019, 8-13-2019)
B. Dedication Required:
1. From and after the effective date hereof, any person who seeks approval of any of the following:
a. An extension of water service;
b. Subdivision; (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
c. Any change in land use, within or outside the limits of the Town, if such change in land use will increase the demand for Town water
service shall comply with this section by paying fees in lieu of water dedication for all uses except the irrigation of parks and open space.
For parks and open space, a person may elect to either pay such fees or dedicate water rights for the irrigation of parks and open space in
accordance with this chapter. Wastewater from in house or in building uses shall either be treated by the Town's Municipal wastewater
treatment facilities or other wastewater treatment facilities of equal efficiency which provide similar return flow patterns. If wastewater from
in house or in building uses will not be treated by the Town's Municipal wastewater treatment facilities or other wastewater treatment
facilities of equal efficiency and which provide similar return flow patterns, the Town shall increase the fee in lieu of water dedication
requirement so that, after the payment of such fees, the water rights to be purchased by the Town will produce an amount of deliverable
and fully consumable water per year for each SFE which is sufficient to ensure an adequate supply of water to satisfy the proposed use or
uses. However, water dedication or payment of fees in lieu of water dedication shall not be required for irrigation of new public parks and
open space owned by the Town or for new public buildings owned by the Town. (Ord. 23-2019, 8-13-2019)
2. Any person who elects to dedicate water rights to the Town for irrigation of parks and open space pursuant to this chapter, shall designate,
on forms to be prescribed by the Town, all water rights proposed to be dedicated to the Town and shall provide a legal description of the land
for which an extension of water service is requested or for which approval of subdivision or a change in land use is sought and, in addition,
shall provide a water and sewer demand analysis in conformance with subsection C of this section. The form shall be accompanied by a
historical use affidavit; except, that if the total number of acre feet is greater than fifteen (15) acre feet, the Town may, in its discretion,
require, in addition to the historical use affidavit, an engineering report prepared at said person's expense by an engineer experienced in
water rights matters, which report is determined by the Town to sufficiently analyze the historical use of the water right(s) proposed for
dedication to the Town.
3. Thereafter, the Town shall make a determination as to whether or not the water rights are sufficient to satisfy the requirements of this
subsection. In making such determination, the Town shall consult with person(s) knowledgeable in water rights matters.
4. The Town shall have the right to make a redetermination of the water rights dedicated to the Town for the irrigation of parks and open space
in the event that revisions to the proposed extension of water service, subdivision, or change in land use are made subsequent to the
determination set forth in subsection B3 of this section.
5. The dedication requirement shall be satisfied by the person seeking approval of the extension of water service, subdivision or a change in
land use, whether or not that person will be the ultimate user of the Town water service.
6. All costs and expenses to dedicate water rights to the Town to satisfy the requirements of this subsection, or to dedicate water rights which
the Town has otherwise accepted in accordance with subsection E of this section, shall be paid by the person required to dedicate water
rights to the Town pursuant to this chapter or his successors or assigns. All costs and expenses necessary to change such water rights so
they can be diverted and used by the Town for Municipal use shall be paid by the person required to dedicate water rights to the Town
pursuant to this section, or his successors or assigns, by payment of all required water court transfer fees and administrative fees. All such
fees shall be paid prior to approval of an extension of water service, subdivision or change in land use. Said fees shall be paid pursuant to a
fee agreement with the Town.
7. Any person required to pay the Town fees in lieu of water dedication, as defined above, shall convey to the Town all nontributary and not
nontributary ground water underlying the land to be served. Said ground water shall be in addition to any water dedication hereunder, and no
credit shall be given to said water for dedication purposes.
C. Water And Sewer Demand Analysis:
1. Any person required to pay the Town fees in lieu of water dedication shall include with the subdivision submittal, or the request for extension
of water service or change in land use, a written analysis sufficient to allow the Town to fully evaluate the probable water demand and
consumption and the sewer service requirements for all uses of the property to be developed, except single-family residential use that meets
the definition of a "single-family equivalent unit (SFE)" in section 8-1-3 of this chapter. Said water demand analysis shall be based upon the
specific development plan proposed by such annexor, developer or owner. The analysis shall include the entire property and shall specify the
use of all land in the property. Water demands and consumption shall be estimated separately for all use categories except property which is
platted and developed for single-family residential use that meets the definition of an SFE in section 8-1-3 of this chapter (e.g., single-family
residential units that do not meet the definition of an SFE in section 8-1-3 of this chapter: multi-family residential, commercial, office,
industrial, parks, open space or others), and irrigation demands and consumptive use shall be set forth separately for each use category
which is applicable to the property.
2. The Town may elect to provide its own analysis, if, in its judgment, the Town has sufficient information and experience with other similar
developments to adequately evaluate the probable water demands and consumption and the sewer service requirements for the property. If
the Town and the developer or owner agree on applicable criteria for the property, the Town may advise such person that he is not required
to submit the written analysis provided for in subsection C1 of this section.
D. Dedication Of Rights For Park, Open Space Or Recreation Use:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 211/449
1. If any person required to pay the Town fees in lieu of water dedication also dedicates land to the Town pursuant to this Code, and such land
is to be used for park, irrigated open space or recreation uses, such person shall also comply with the provisions of this section, including the
dedication of water rights pursuant to this chapter or payment of fees in lieu of water dedication sufficient to irrigate said land, as determined
by the Town.
2. Where the Town Board enters into an agreement to accept cash in lieu of in kind land dedication for parks, open space or recreation uses,
and the Town is unable to specifically determine the irrigation demand for the public project for which the cash is contributed from a specific
Town construction plan, master plan or otherwise, the amount of water right dedication, or cash in lieu of water right dedication, at the Town
Board's discretion, which shall be required to meet the requirements of subsection D1 of this section shall be equal to the amount required to
irrigate eighty percent (80%) of the land area which otherwise would have been required for in kind land dedication by this Code.
E. Procedure:
1. Subsections E2, E3, E4 and E5 of this section apply only to lands which are annexed to the Town after the effective date hereof.
2. The Town shall include in any annexation, subdivision, development or similar agreements, provisions addressing whether or not there is any
commitment on behalf of the Town to provide water or sewer service.
3. At the time of annexation, the annexor shall elect to do one or more of the following: a) offer for dedication to the Town all water rights
appurtenant to the property to be annexed; b) offer for dedication to the Town water rights which are not appurtenant to the property to be
annexed; or c) not to offer for dedication to the Town all water rights appurtenant to the property to be annexed. The Town may, in its
discretion, and using the criteria set forth in this section, consider and accept for dedication water rights offered by the annexor which are not
appurtenant to the property to be annexed. The Town shall determine whether any such water rights in items a or b of this subsection offered
to the Town for dedication will be accepted, rejected or accepted in part by the Town for dedication.
4. In the event the annexor elects not to offer for dedication to the Town all water rights appurtenant to the property to be annexed which the
Town desires to acquire, the Town shall provide in the annexation, subdivision, development and other similar agreements that: a) there is no
commitment by the Town at the time of approval of the annexation to provide water or sewer service to the property; or b) the annexor,
developer or owner shall not be entitled to provide cash in lieu payments to the Town until after such time as all appurtenant water rights
have been offered to the Town for dedication. If the developer later elects to offer all such appurtenant water rights and the Town accepts
them for dedication, the timing and extent of any commitment to provide water or sewer service shall be limited by the completion of any
necessary water court proceedings by the Town. If any water rights offered to the Town for dedication exceed the amount required by this
policy, subsection H of this section shall apply. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
5. a. The Town shall evaluate any water rights offered to the Town for dedication. The Town shall determine whether said water rights are to be
accepted based upon the following criteria: priority date, historical point of diversion, location of historical use, historical yield, historical
consumptive use, the contribution to historical consumptive use of other water rights or sources of water supply, future use of the land
historically irrigated, including future irrigation, considerations with respect to title, anticipated difficulties with transferring the water rights to
appropriate points of diversion, places of storage and Municipal uses, the Town's contractual obligations and arrangements, expected needs
of the Town and of the Town's Municipal water supply system, composition of the Town's water rights portfolio at the time of the proposed
annexation, and any other appropriate factors. For purposes of this Code, it is assumed that units of the Colorado Big Thompson Project
(CBT units) have a firm annual yield of one-half (0.5) acre foot per unit. (Ord. 13-A-2006, 4-11-2006)
b. Any water court transfer fees or administrative fees shall be paid not later than the time of approval of the final plat(s) to which the water
right dedication is applicable.
6. The Town reserves the right, in its sole discretion, to accept, reject or accept in part any water rights proposed for dedication to the Town.
7. No water taps shall be issued by the Town unless sufficient water right dedications and/or fees in lieu payments have been accepted by the
Town to provide sufficient water supply for the demands projected for such taps in accordance with the terms of this section.
8. No extension of water service, including any new or additional water service, shall be furnished until there has been full compliance with the
provisions of this section, unless the Town Board determines by resolution or written agreement that one or more of the exceptions set forth
in subsection J of this section apply.
9. The Town reserves the right to review projected water usage and actual water usage within a project at any time to confirm the adequacy of
the water demand projections made by the annexor, developer or owner, and to require additional water rights dedication and/or cash in lieu
payments based on actual water usage.
10. All costs and expenses related to the dedication of water rights to the Town shall be borne by the person required to dedicate water rights to
the Town pursuant to this section.
11. In the event the water rights offered to the Town for dedication provide raw water credits in excess of those required by this policy, such
excess water rights shall be offered for sale to the Town at current fair market value. The Town may enter into a written agreement to
purchase all or part of any such excess water rights and, in the event the Town does not then purchase all of such excess water rights, the
Town may require the annexor, developer or owner to grant to the Town a right of first refusal to purchase such excess water rights in the
future, pursuant to the provisions of subsection H of this section.
12. All determinations provided for herein shall be made by the Town in the exercise of its reasonable judgment and shall be consistent with
this section.
13. All dedications of water rights to the Town hereunder shall be effected by delivering to the Town sufficient warranty deeds, stock certificates
with appropriate stock assignments, accompanied by satisfactory dry up covenants, or by written approval by the northern Colorado water
conservancy district of the transfer of any allotment contracts, as is appropriate to the particular transaction. All title documents shall be
subject to approval by the Town's Attorneys. No water right dedication shall be considered completed until the Town has accepted sufficient
documents transferring title to the Town. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 212/449
F. Fees In Lieu Of Dedication: The Town shall require fees in lieu of water dedication to satisfy all dedication requirements for all uses on lands
annexed to the Town; which are provided water service by the Town except, that a person may elect to dedicate water rights for the irrigation of
parks and open space in accordance with the requirements of this section, or as may be provided in an intergovernmental agreement. When
the Town determines the amounts of fees in lieu of water dedication, the amounts of fees shall include the cost of units in the Colorado Big
Thompson Project (CBT units) necessary to satisfy the dedication requirement, determined as of the date of actual payment by the developer
or owner, which value shall include any transaction costs, interest and all other costs incurred or to be incurred by the Town in acquiring water
rights for the Town's system as set forth in section 2-10-6 of this Code. The firm annual yield of a CBT unit for purposes of this chapter is onehalf
(0.5) acre foot per unit. All determinations required by this section shall be made by the Town in its sole judgment. However, water
dedication or payment of fees in lieu of water dedication shall not be required for irrigation of new public parks and open space owned by the
Town or for new public buildings owned by the Town. (Ord. 23-2019, 8-13-2019)
G. Agricultural And Open Space Property: If the owner of any property proposed to be annexed or subdivided, or on which the land use is
proposed to be changed resulting in an increased demand for Town water service, desires to retain the land, or any portion thereof, in
agricultural production or as open space prior to development, he may, pursuant to written agreement with the Town, be permitted to lease
back, on an annual basis and for irrigation, aesthetic and recreational purposes only, all or part of the water rights dedicated to the Town
pursuant to this chapter. The terms of any such leases shall be at fair market value, as determined by the Town, and on such other terms and
conditions as are determined by the Town. Said leases shall provide that in the event any portion of the land for which the water is leased is
platted during the term of the lease, the Town may cancel the lease, in whole or in part, to the extent any portion of the leased water is
determined by the Town to be necessary for water service to the property so platted.
H. Option To Purchase Or Right Of First Refusal:
1. Option To Purchase:
a. Option Granted: Prior to any extension of water service, any person required to comply with the provisions of this section shall also grant
to the Town the option for one year to purchase any and all water rights which are appurtenant to the land to be subdivided, or on which
the land use is proposed to be changed, but which are in excess of the dedication requirements of this section. The option may be
exercised by the Town at any time within the period of one year following the date of the grant to the Town with regard to any or all of the
water rights subject to the grant.
b. Price:
(1) The option price shall be that price agreed upon by the parties. If the parties cannot agree upon an option price within thirty (30) days
after notice of the Town's intent to exercise its option is received by the owner, appraisal at the Town's expense will establish the price
that reflects the fair market value of the water right(s).
(2) The appraisal shall be conducted by one appraiser appointed by the Town, one appraiser appointed by the owner of the water rights,
and a third appraiser who shall be appointed by both parties. The average of the three (3) appraisals shall be the option price. All three
(3) appraisers must have at least ten (10) years' experience in appraising water rights in Colorado.
2. Right Of First Refusal:
a. Grant Of Right: In addition to the grant to the Town of the option to purchase water rights as provided in subsection H1a of this section,
any person required to comply with the dedication requirements shall also grant to the Town a right of first refusal regarding any water
rights subject to said option to purchase. If the Town for any reason should choose not to exercise its option to purchase water rights as
provided in subsection H1a of this section, the Town shall have the right of first refusal in the event the water rights are to be sold
separately from the land, for a period of ten (10) years following the date of the grant to the Town.
b. Notice Period: If the owner of the water rights subject to the right of first refusal wishes to sell the water rights to a third party, he shall give
the Town at least ninety (90) days' prior written notice of his intention to effect a sale of the water rights by delivering to the Town an
acceptable bona fide written offer to purchase made by a third party. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
c. Exercise Of Right: During the ninety (90) day notice period provided for in subsection H2b of this section, the Town shall enjoy its right of
first refusal entitling it to purchase the water rights offered for sale on the same terms and conditions as contained in the acceptable bona
fide written offer. If, within ninety (90) days following notice by the owner of his intention to sell his water rights, the Town chooses to
exercise its right to purchase, then the Town shall so notify the owner in writing and shall proceed to closing on the terms and conditions
contained in the acceptable bona fide written offer by the third party. In the event that the Town determines not to exercise its right to
purchase the water rights offered for sale, the owner shall be free to sell the water rights to the third party; provided, however, that any
such sale to the third party shall be for a price which is at least equal to that price which was tendered to and refused by the Town, and on
terms and conditions which are no more favorable to the third party than those refused by the Town. (Ord. 13-A-2006, 4-11-2006)
I. Return Flows And Augmentation; Exchange Or Reuse Plans:
1. The Town shall have dominion and control of all water supplied through its water system, subject to reasonable use thereof by its customers
in compliance with applicable water service agreements, leases or licenses or the Town ordinances. Such dominion and control shall
continue without interruption as to all wastewater, return flows, runoff, sewage or tail water attributable to or originating in water supplied
through Town owned or controlled water rights or facilities.
2. The Town shall have the exclusive right to recapture such return flows or claim credit therefrom for reuse, successive use, exchange,
replacement, augmentation, substitute supply or any other lawful purposes, and the Town's dominion and control over water shall continue to
attach to all such return flows, regardless of form, even after they return to the ground water aquifers or the surface stream systems.
3. All return flows from water supplied through Town owned or controlled water rights or facilities remain the property of the Town.
J. Exceptions:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 213/449
1. This section does not apply to an extension of water service for which the dedication requirements have been previously satisfied.
2. The Town Board may determine that certain provisions of this section may be inapplicable to certain developments or portions of
developments, or the application of said chapter should be deferred in time or on certain conditions, if there is existing water service from a
water district or the Town believes all or part of the development would be better served by the water district, either temporarily or
permanently. Any such determinations shall be set out expressly in the annexation, development and other similar agreements relating to
water service. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-10: WATER CONSERVATION:
A. Conservation Procedures Adopted: The "Town of Erie water conservation program, enforcement response plan, policies, and procedures",
attached to Ordinance 810, on file in the Office of the Town Clerk and incorporated herein by this reference, are hereby adopted.
B. Conservation Program To Govern: The requirements for water conservation shall be governed by the "Town of Erie water conservation
program, enforcement response plan, policies, and procedures".
C. Application Of Program:
1. This conservation program applies only to water served by Town water systems. Any person irrigating with a well or any other means
allowed under subsection 8-1-6B of this chapter should post a sign with notification that the Town's water system is not used for irrigation.
2. In the event that undesirable conditions arise regarding the Town water system or water supply, the Town Board may elect to make the
"Town of Erie water conservation program, enforcement response plan, policies, and procedures" mandatory through a Town Board
resolution.
3. The requirements for water conservation are voluntary unless made mandatory through a Town Board resolution.
D. Emergency Water Restrictions: The Town Administrator may establish water usage hours and restrictions for the safety and welfare of the
Town. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-11: WASTE OF WATER:
A. Waste Of Water Prohibited: All waste of water from the Town water system is prohibited. A "waste of water" is defined, for purposes of this
chapter, as any use of water which is not applied to a beneficial use. A waste of water may be evidenced by the presence of outdoor irrigation
water on paved surfaces.
B. Leaks In Water Lines: Any leak(s) that occurs in a water line is to be repaired within ten (10) days of discovery of said leak, and the user will be
charged for any water that is lost as a result of water leaks on the water users' side of the water connection, and said water user will be
charged for any water passing through the meter whether actually used or not.
C. Notice Of Violation; Termination Of Service; Surcharge: Since waste of water may cause a situation of jeopardy to the Town during periods of
limited water availability, the Town may, by the Town Administrator or his or her duly authorized agent, give notice in writing to any water user
that the water use by that person constitutes an apparent waste of water, as the Town Administrator may reasonably determine, on a
comparative usage basis of general water use by persons in reasonably similar situations. After receipt of such written notice, if such waste of
water is not remedied and appropriately reduced, the Town Administrator, after appropriate hearing and consideration, may terminate the
offending person's water service, or may levy a monthly excess water use surcharge or fine, not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) in
any given month, on the water user. Any surcharge or fine as provided herein shall be in addition to any other penalties or violations as
permitted under section 8-1-19 of this chapter. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-12: HEALTH HAZARDS:
The Town Board shall refuse to provide water service for any use which would constitute a health hazard. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-13: WATER METERS:
A. Metered Water Required:
1. Water meters shall be installed to meter all water use from the Town's system as follows:
a. Every single-family detached residence, mobile home, industrial building and commercial building customer shall have a separate water
meter, subject to subsections A1b and A1c of this section.
b. All multi-family and single family attached units which are individually owned, including, but not limited to condominium complexes, duplex
residences and townhouses, and multi-unit commercial buildings whether or not units are individually owned, may have either: 1) a master
meter with one water tap; or 2) separate meters with either separate water taps or a vault and manifold with separate service lines to each
unit, and a meter for irrigation. However, the Town will not issue both a master meter and separate meters for individual units.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 214/449
c. All multi-family units with the same address, including without limitation apartment complexes, shall have one master meter. The Town will
not issue sub-meters for such units.
2. Any metering requirements not addressed above shall be determined by the Director of Public Works. (Ord. 23-2019, 8-13-2019)
B. Testing Meters: Each water meter shall be tested either by the Town or the manufacturer and shall be found to be correct and properly adjusted
prior to installation. If the test is made by the manufacturer, certification of the test and result will be furnished to the Town prior to installation.
C. Interfering With Or Bypassing Meters:
1. Interference Or Bypass Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any water user or for any other person other than an authorized employee of the
Town to tamper or interfere with any meter or meter seal. All meters must have immediate and unhampered access at all times. No act will
be performed by any person(s) that will alter the flow of water and/or accurate registration of the meter.
2. Violation; Discontinuance Of Service: A violation of this provision shall be cause for immediate discontinuance of water service to any water
user found to be in violation of this subsection, as well as subject the person or entity to those violations and penalties as set forth in section
8-1-19 of this chapter.
3. Appeals: In the event the Town immediately discontinues water service based upon a violation of this subsection, the person against whom
the violation is brought may appeal the discontinuance of water service to the Town Administrator by written request within five (5) days of
the discontinuance of the water service. Failure to make such a request for a hearing shall constitute a waiver of any right to appeal the
discontinuance of water service.
4. Additional Enforcement: Discontinuance of water service shall in no way limit the Town from enforcing the violations and penalties provisions
as set forth in section 8-1-19 of this chapter.
D. New Construction: A water meter is required to obtain water for construction unless a hydrant meter is obtained pursuant to subsection G of this
section for individual units. Upon installation of a water meter for construction purposes, the water meter will be considered permanent, and the
owner shall pay the current monthly billing. No jumpers or other activities of obtaining water illegally will be allowed.
E. Installation Of Meters; Specifications:
1. Installation By Town: All water meters shall be installed by the Town or its authorized agent.
2. Specifications: Meters, valves, service lines and all other materials used in the meter installation shall meet specifications outlined and
material standards approved by the Town.
3. Manner Of Installation: The method and manner in which installations are accomplished shall be subject to Town approval and shall meet
construction standards as approved by the Town.
4. Supervision And Inspection: All materials used and construction performed shall be under the supervision of the Public Works Director,
inspected and accepted by the Town prior to the water service becoming available. A seal will be placed on or near the meter indicating
acceptance by the Town.
F. Maintenance Required: All water meters and appurtenances shall be maintained by the Town, and shall be tested as reasonably necessary and
shall be kept in accurate working order at all times. If the Town tests a meter at the request of a property owner, and the meter is determined to
be accurate, the property owner shall pay the current fee for said testing.
G. Hydrant Meters: Any and all construction not addressed in subsection D of this section requiring Town water shall be controlled by the use of a
hydrant meter obtained from the Town pursuant to the following requirements:
1. Deposit Required: Prior to the assignment of a hydrant meter, a hydrant meter deposit is required as provided in section 2-10-4 of this Code.
The deposit shall be paid to the Town Finance Department which shall issue a receipt. When the receipt is presented to the Director of Public
Works, a hydrant meter will be issued with the proper location assignment. The deposit will be held until such time as the hydrant meter has
been returned and the water usage paid in full.
2. Charges:
a. User Charge: The charge for the Town water service shall be as provided in section 2-10-4 of this Code.
b. Rental Charge: Rental for the hydrant meter shall be in accordance with section 2-10-4 of this Code.
3. Liability For Damages: The person renting the meter will be responsible and liable for damages caused to the meter during its usage.
4. Reading And Inspecting Meters: Any meter rented from the Town shall be available for inspection and reading by Town employees at the
assigned hydrant during normal business hours, Monday through Friday. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-14: SERVICE CONNECTIONS:
A. Installation By Owner: It is the property owner's responsibility to excavate, backfill, and install the service line necessary to serve the property in
accordance with the Town's specifications and standards.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 215/449
B. Maintenance By Owner: The owner of any property having an existing connection or making a new connection to the Town water system shall
be responsible for the maintenance of the water service line from the curb stop interior meter or meter pit into the property, and shall keep this
line in good condition at his expense. The owner shall, at the owner's expense, at all times keep pipes, fixtures, and appliances on the water
using property tight and in good working order so as to prevent waste of water. Needed repairs will be completed within ten (10) days, or the
Town will complete the repairs and charge the property owner for all incurred expenses.
C. Excavation And Backfilling: All excavation and backfilling shall be in conformity with Town standards and specifications.
D. Extension Of Service Line:
1. Each property shall be served by its own service line, and no connection with the water system shall be made by extending the service line
from one property to another property.
2. In cases where service lines have been so extended from one property to a different property, the continued use shall be permitted only until
such time that water mains are constructed in the street in front of such property, at which time connection shall be made to the water main at
the expense of the property owner being so served by such an extension, and such an extended service will be discontinued.
E. Separate Connections Required: No water pipes shall be permitted to connect between one water using unit and another water using unit
except pursuant to and in accordance with this chapter. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-15: SUPPLYING WATER TO OTHERS:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person receiving water service from the Town to permit any other person to take or use water from said water service
for use on any property not approved in writing by the Town.
B. No person shall sell any quantity of water from any service connections attached to the Town water system. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
8-1-16: EXTENSION OF WATER MAINS:
A. Method Of Extension:
1. Any extension of a Town water main line necessary to supply water and water service where no water main line exists or is available, such
as a new subdivision, resubdivision, or territory which has been annexed by the Town, shall be done at the sole cost of the person requesting
said extension, except as agreed upon, in writing, with the Town, and shall be accomplished, made, done or performed by one of the
following methods at the option of the Town:
a. The person requesting water and water service shall pay in advance to the Town all such main line extension costs, and the Town shall
construct the facilities; or
b. The Town, at its discretion, may enter into a written agreement whereby the person requesting water and water services shall install, at
his/her expense, the necessary main line extensions under a contract let to the lowest acceptable bidder approved by the Town; or
c. The person requesting water and water service shall construct the necessary main line extensions with his/her own work force under terms
agreed to in writing by the Town.
2. Any of the above methods shall be made, accomplished and performed in accordance with reasonable plans, specifications, drawings,
engineering, and other requirements established, designated, and approved by the Town. All water system extensions shall be designed and
installed in accordance with water system standards and specifications as may be established by the Town from time to time.
B. Recovery Cost For Oversizing Water Mains: Any cost recoveries for the oversizing of water mains during new construction required by the
Town, shall be established by a written agreement with the Town.
C. Water Line And Appurtenances Are Town Property:
1. Property owners who have completed construction of water lines and appurtenances shall, before these water lines and appurtenances are
accepted by the Town for service, deed these water lines and appurtenances and all necessary easements to the Town free and clear of all
liens and encumbrances, properly described by certified survey, and furnish a financial guarantee in a form acceptable to the Town and
sufficient in amount to cover all maintenance for a period of two (2) years from the date of construction acceptance of the lines by the Town.
2. The Town shall have exclusive authority to determine additional uses to be made on any water distribution lines and/or other appurtenances
prior to acceptance, including, but not limited to, persons to whom taps will be issued, conditions under which taps will be made, rates to be
charged, conditions of service and use of taps.
D. Construction Of Main Lines: All plans and specifications relating to water lines, storage facilities, pumping facilities or other appurtenances to be
connected to the Town water system shall conform to the utility design standards established by the Town. Such plans and specifications shall
be submitted to the Town for review prior to construction. The cost of such review by the Town and its consultants shall be borne by the person
submitting such plans. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)

8-1-17: CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL:
A. Cross Connections Prohibited: Any cross connection between the Town's potable water system and any nonpotable water system shall be
prohibited. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
B. Backflow Prevention Assemblies:
1. Location And Compliance: Backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed in an accessible location to facilitate maintenance, testing and
repair. All backflow prevention assemblies shall comply with the Town's Cross-Connection Control Program and all Town standards, codes
and requirements. (Ord. 23-2019, 8-13-2019)
2. Inspections; Entry Powers: When it is necessary to make an inspection to enforce the provisions of this chapter, or when the Town has
reasonable cause to believe that there exists in a building or upon a premises a condition which is contrary to or in violation of this chapter, a
representative of the Town may enter the building or premises at reasonable times to inspect or perform the duties imposed by this chapter;
provided, that if such building or premises be occupied, identification credentials shall be presented to the occupant and entry requested. If
such building or premises is unoccupied, the Town representative shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons
having charge or control of the building or premises and request entry. If entry is refused, the Town shall have recourse to all legal remedies
to secure entry.
C. Violations; Discontinuance Of Water Service:
1. Failure to immediately cooperate in the installation, maintenance, testing or inspection of backflow prevention assemblies required by this
section shall be grounds for the discontinuance of water service to the premises or the requirement for an air gap separation from the public
potable water system.
2. Service of water to any premises may also be discontinued by the Town if unprotected cross connections exist on the premises.
3. When any defect is found in an installed backflow prevention assembly, or if backflow prevention assembly has been removed or bypassed,
the service may be discontinued. Service shall not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
4. Discontinuance of service may be summary, immediate, and without written notice whenever, in the judgment of the Public Works Director,
such action is necessary to protect the safety of the public potable water supply. (Ord. 23-2019, 8-13-2019)
8-1-18: FEES AND CHARGES2:
A. Tap Fees:
1. Fees Established: Tap fees shall be as set forth in section 2-10-6 of this Code. The Town Board shall have the right and authority to adjust
tap fees at any time pursuant to ordinance.
2. Out Of Town Service: For any water tap where the service requested is out of the Town limits, the fee will be two (2) times the fee charged in
the Town limits. This subsection may be modified by an intergovernmental agreement.
B. User Charges: Charges, fees, rents and/or rates shall be levied and assessed for water and water service at the following rates:
1. Service Rates:
a. Rates for Town water service shall be as set forth in section 2-10-4 of this Code. The Town Board shall have the right and authority to
adjust rates at any time pursuant to resolution.
b. Rates for water service provided outside the corporate limits of the Town shall be as set forth in section 2-10-4 of this Code.
2. Inoperable Meter:
a. If any meter fails to register water usage in any billing period, the service account shall be charged the average usage which occurred
during the corresponding billing period of the previous three (3) years, or a reasonable estimated usage when prior usage data is not
available, as determined by the Town Finance Department.
b. If a water meter remote reader indicates a water usage greater or less than usage indicated by the water meter, the water meter shall be
removed and tested. If the test results indicate that a water meter operates within reasonable limits as certified by the manufacturer and
established by the Public Works Department, the meter reading shall be used to calculate water usage to be billed for the billing period in
which it is discovered the water meter remote reader malfunctioned.
c. If a situation regarding charges arises and it is a result of a malfunctioning water meter or remote water meter reader and is not addressed
by this chapter or other resolution adopted by the Town Board, then the Town Administrator shall approve or modify and approve the
recommendation for water usage to be charged.
C. Water Enterprise Fund: All fees, rates, rents, and charges for water shall be deposited and expended from the Erie Water Enterprise Fund. The
revenue from said fund shall be allocated as the Town Board deems necessary from time to time.
D. Past Due Accounts; Discontinuance Of Service; Restoration Of Service; Liens:
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 217/449
1. Billing And Past Due Accounts: Water usage is billed to the property owner or property manager of a service address, at the end of a billing
period, for water usage during the billing period. A service account is considered past due when the billing for the current period reflects an
unpaid balance from previous billing period(s).
2. Notice Of Past Due Accounts:
a. Holders of interest, as shown on the Town Finance Department records, of past due service accounts shall be notified by first class mail.
Notification shall include date and time water is scheduled to be shut off, amount of penalty assessments, amount of notification fee and
actions necessary to avoid penalties and discontinuation of service.
b. The Town shall physically post notification to premises at least twenty four (24) hours prior to scheduled shutoff for nonpayment. A
notification fee will be added to the past due balance.
c. The failure of any such person to receive notification of impending shutoff shall not affect the validity of any actions taken under this
subsection and shall not relieve any person from obligations imposed on him or her by this subsection.
3. Shutoff Of Service:
a. The Town shall discontinue water service for nonpayment, at or after the specification date and time. When payment of a past due balance
is not received by ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on the scheduled shutoff date, a shutoff fee will be added to the past due balance to cover costs
to the Town in activating shutoff procedures.
b. Whenever it is necessary to make a shutoff of water service from inside a user's building or premises, a Town representative may enter
such building or premises, but shall present proper credentials and request entry. If such building or premises is unoccupied, the
representative shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of the building or premises
and request entry. If such entry is refused, the Town representative shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry.
4. Restoration Of Service: Water service which has been shut off for nonpayment shall be restored when the total past due balance, plus all
assessments, including interest, notification fees, attorney fees and court costs have been paid in full.
5. Exigent Circumstances; Continuance Of Service: The Town Administrator may approve the continuation of water service to a customer who
can verify exigent circumstances. The approval shall include a written agreement for payment of past due balances, assessments and fees.
6. Liens For Rates And Charges: All water rates, charges and rents shall be a charge and lien upon the premises to which water is delivered,
from the date the same becomes due and until paid, and the owner of every building, premises, lot or house shall be liable for all water
delivered to or taken and used upon his or her premises, which lien and liability may be enforced by the Town by action at law or suit to
enforce the lien. In case the tenant in possession of the premises or building pays the water rent, charges, or rates, it shall not relieve his or
her landlord from such obligation and lien.
7. Certification To County Treasurer: If such water rates, charges and rents remain unpaid after a thirty (30) day demand for payment of the
same has been made, such water rates, charges and rents may be certified by the Town Clerk to the County Treasurer to be placed upon the
tax list for the current year to be collected in the same manner as other taxes are collected with a ten percent (10%) penalty to defray the
cost of collection.
E. Responsibility For Other Charges: The payment of fees, charges, surcharges and/or rates imposed by this chapter shall not relieve the person
paying the same from the payment of any other taxes hereinafter imposed by the Town, it being the intent of this chapter that said fees,
charges, surcharges and/or rates prescribed by the various sections of this chapter shall be cumulative except where otherwise specifically
provided.
F. Recovery Actions: The Town shall have the right to recover all sums due to the Town under the terms of this chapter and shall seek such
recovery by discontinuance of service, lien(s) against property and/or judgment and execution thereon through civil action in any court of
competent jurisdiction. Such remedy shall be cumulative with all other remedies herein for the enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-
2005)
G. Water Rates And Water Tap Fees For Nonpotable Water: As of March 22, 2016, the Town imposes certain water rates and water tap fees for
the provision of nonpotable water. The water rates for nonpotable water are set forth in section 2-10-4 of this Code, and the water tap fees for
nonpotable water are set forth in section 2-10-6 of this Code. As with all other water tap fees and water service rates, pursuant to subsections
A1 and B1a of this section, respectively, the Town of Erie Board of Trustees shall have the right and authority to adjust tap fees by appropriate
action at any time. (Ord. 12-2016, 4-19-2016)
8-1-19: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. General Penalty: Whenever in this chapter an act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or wherever in this chapter the
doing of an act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be
punishable as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code, except where any different provision is made elsewhere in this chapter.
B. Separate Offense: Each day any violation of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
C. Court Costs: The Municipal Court Judge is empowered in his or her discretion to assess court costs of up to and including one hundred dollars
($100.00) against any defendant who pleads guilty or nolo contendere or who enters a plea agreement or who, after trial, is found guilty of
violating this chapter.

D. Recovery Of Costs: The Town shall have the right to recover all sums due, by the terms of this chapter, by judgment, and execution thereon, in
a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction. Such remedy shall be cumulative with all other remedies provided herein for the
enforcement of this chapter.
E. Additional Remedies: The remedies and penalties set forth in this chapter are nonexclusive in that the Town may take any lawful action, either in
law or in equity, to protect its property or its rights, powers, privileges or immunities created under this chapter, or those of its citizens, which
may include, but is not limited to, injunctions or civil actions for damages. (Ord. 32-2005, 9-13-2005)
Chapter 2
SANITARY SEWER SERVICE
8-2-1: TITLES:
Titles of sections, when and wherever the same may appear throughout this chapter, are used for convenience only and shall have no relevancy
and/or effect upon the terms, provisions, and conditions herein or of the construction or interpretation of same. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-2: PURPOSE:
It is necessary for the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the Town to regulate the collection of the wastewater and treatment thereof to
provide for maximum public benefit. This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for users of the Town's publicly owned treatment works (POTW)
and enables the Town to comply with applicable State and Federal laws and regulations. The objectives of this chapter are:
A. To prevent the introduction of pollutants into publicly owned treatment works (POTW) which would interfere with the operations of the system or
contaminate the resulting sludge;
B. To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW wastewater system which will pass through the system, inadequately treated, into
receiving waters or the atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the system;
C. To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewaters and sludges from the system;
D. To provide for the equitable distribution among users of the cost of the POTW; and
E. To provide for and promote the general health, safety, and welfare of the citizens residing within the Town.
This chapter provides for the regulation of users of the POTW through the issuance of permits, authorizes monitoring and enforcement
activities, requires user reporting, and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from programs established
herein.
This chapter shall apply to persons in the Town, and to persons outside the Town who are, by contract or agreement with the Town, users of the
Town POTW. Except as otherwise provided herein, the Director of Public Works shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-3: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever in this chapter the words hereinafter defined or construed in this section are used, they shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be
deemed to have the following meanings:
OWNER: Any person owning real property within the Town.
POTW: Publicly owned treatment works.
PERSON: Shall include any individual, partnership, association, organization, company, district or corporation.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface and ground waters are not intentionally admitted; including the
pipe or conduit system and appurtenances, for the collection, transportation, pumping, and treatment of sewage. This definition shall also include
the terms sanitary sewer service, sewer system, and sewer.
SERVICE LINE: A sewer line intended for discharging wastewater into the town's collection system and commencing at a structure or facility and
terminating at a sewer main.
SEWAGE: Also defined as wastewater.
SEWER MAIN LINE SYSTEM: That portion of the collection and transportation of wastewater to the POTW and which has been installed for the
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 219/449
express purpose of allowing service connections to be made thereto.
TOWN: The town of Erie, Colorado. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-4: CONNECTION REQUIRED:
No person shall operate, own, manage, maintain, control or possess a sewer system of any type, including, but not limited to, an individual septic
system or a central collection and treatment system, for the purpose or with the effect of providing sanitary sewer service to any property within the
town of Erie without first entering into an agreement therefor with the town of Erie in the manner provided by, through, and under the laws of the
state of Colorado and the ordinances of the town. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
A. The owner of every house, building, or structure used for human occupancy, employment, or recreation, situated within the town is hereby
required, at their expense, to install suitable toilet facilities in accordance with the plumbing code, as adopted in this code, and to connect such
facilities with the POTW or a treatment plant with a valid NPDES permit in accordance with the provisions herein within thirty (30) days after the
date of official notice to do so, provided that a sanitary sewer main is within one hundred feet (100') of the owner's property line subject to
subsection C of this section. No persons shall discharge, or allow to be discharged, any wastewater except as follows:
1. By a direct service connection to a town sewer main, which connection has been authorized by the director of public works; or
2. By transporting in a safe and sanitary manner to a disposal site approved by public health officials and capable of accepting the type of
wastes involved; or
3. By a service connection to a treatment plant with a valid NPDES permit where such connection is approved by the director of public works.
(Ord. 18-2008, 5-27-2008)
B. No person shall contribute or cause to be contributed, directly or indirectly, into the POTW any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with
the operation or performance of the POTW. These general prohibitions apply to all users of a POTW, whether or not the user is subject to
categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
C. At such time as the town's sanitary sewer becomes available within one hundred feet (100') of the property line of property located within the
town and served by a private septic system, cesspool, privy or similar private disposal facilities ("private sewage disposal system") the owner
may be required to connect with the town's sanitary sewer in accordance with this code within thirty (30) days after written notice from the
director of public works is served on the owner. Use of any private sewage disposal system for existing premises may continue notwithstanding
the provisions of this section, until such time as said written notice is served, provided that such system complies with all the requirements of
the state and the county, is maintained in good working order, and does not represent a threat to public health or safety. If the existing private
sewage disposal system fails, the owner must within thirty (30) days connect to the town's sanitary sewer main located within one hundred feet
(100') of the property. In all situations in which a property is connected to the town's sanitary sewer system which property was previously
served by a private sewage disposal system, the private sewage disposal system shall be emptied, cleaned and filled with suitable material
within thirty (30) days after the connection to the town's sanitary sewer is completed. (Ord. 18-2008, 5-27-2008)
8-2-5: APPLICATION PROCEDURES AND PERMIT REQUIRED:
A. Written Application Required: Owners desiring sanitary sewer service within the town of Erie shall make written application to the town of Erie,
setting forth the name, postal address of the owner, the legal description of the property for which the service is desired, the purpose or
purposes for which the service will be used, and such other facts as are necessary to determine the purpose, extent, and nature of use of the
town's sewer system. Persons required to obtain an industrial waste discharge permit pursuant to town ordinances and regulations must submit
an approved permit from the state of Colorado with said application. Payment of all applicable sewer tap fees shall be made at the time of said
application. Applications shall be made only in the name of, and for, the owners of the real property seeking such service.
B. Permit Required:
1. Upon compliance with all applicable sewer use regulations of the town of Erie and approval of the application, the town shall endorse the
application as approved and return it to the applicant, which shall serve as a sewer permit. A permit authorizes the sewer tap installation and
the provision of sanitary sewer service. The issuance of the permit shall not be construed to be a permit for, or approval of, any violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter or of any other ordinance of the town.
2. The issuance of a permit based upon plans, specifications and other data shall not prevent the town from thereafter requiring the correction
of errors in said plans, specifications and other data, or from preventing installation operations or use of sanitary sewer service being carried
on under when there is a violation hereunder.
3. Every permit issued by the town under the provisions of this chapter shall expire by limitation and become null and void if the sewer tap is
not completed and sanitary sewer service authorized by the permit is not commenced within one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of
endorsement of such permit. If no extension is requested as provided below, one-half (1/2) of the original tap fee paid shall be refunded to the
applicant upon expiration of the permit.
4. Any permittee holding an unexpired permit may apply for an extension of the time within which he may commence work under that permit
when the permittee is unable to commence work within the time required by this chapter for good and satisfactory reasons. The town may
extend the time for action by the permittee for a period not exceeding one hundred eighty (180) days upon written request by the permittee
showing that circumstances beyond the control of the permittee have prevented action from being taken. No permit shall be extended more
than once. In order to renew action on a permit after expiration, the permittee shall pay a new full tap fee.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 220/449
C. Case By Case Basis:
1. The town of Erie will consider the issuance of sewer taps on a case by case basis based upon physical capacity at its treatment plant and
the treatment plant's legal capacity based upon its state and federal permits and compliance with all terms and conditions in said permits.
The town may require a detailed effluent study by a professional engineer prior to issuance of a sewer tap.
2. The town of Erie reserves the right to deny any request for a sewer tap if it finds that it does not have physical or treatment capacity to
provide adequate collection and treatment for the generated flows from said tap, or if service for said tap will result in violation of any of the
town's state and federal permits or any state or federal laws. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-6: SERVICE LINES AND CONNECTIONS:
A. Installation By Owner: It is the property owner's responsibility to excavate, backfill, and install the service line necessary to serve the property in
accordance with the town of Erie's specifications and standards. There will be no sump pumps discharged into the sanitary sewer system.
B. Maintenance By Owner: The owner of any property having an existing connection or making a new connection to the town sewer system shall
be responsible for the maintenance of the sewer service line and shall keep said line in good condition at owner's expense. The owner shall, at
owner's expense, at all times keep pipes, fixtures, and appliances on any property using the town of Erie's sanitary sewer system tight and in
good working order.
1. As a condition of receiving sanitary sewer service from the town of Erie, it shall be understood that leakage from service lines is strictly
prohibited.
2. Any leak(s) that occurs in a sewer service line is to be repaired within forty eight (48) hours of discovery of said leak. If such leakage is not
so repaired, the town shall discontinue sewer service to the property and shall disconnect water service to the property if the property
receives water service from the town. Water and sewer service will not be resumed until said leak is properly repaired and the
discontinuance and reconnection fees set forth in title 2, chapter 10 of this code are paid in full.
C. Excavation And Backfilling: All excavation and backfilling shall be in conformity with town of Erie standards and specifications.
D. Extension Of Service Line Prohibited: Each property shall be served by its own service line, and no connection with the sewer system shall be
made by extending the service line from one property to another property. In cases where service lines have been so extended from one
property to a different property the continued use shall be permitted only until such time that sewer mains are laid in the street in front of such
property, at which time connection shall be made to the sewer main at the expense of the property owner being so served by such an extension
and such an extended service will be discontinued.
E. Service Connections Outside Of Town:
1. No sewer taps shall be made outside the corporate limits of the town of Erie nor shall any sanitary sewer service be furnished from the town
sewer system to any person or property outside said corporate limits, except by special written agreement from the town of Erie board of
trustees.
2. No sewer taps and/or promises or agreements for sewer taps shall be made to any out of town property owners in lieu of payment of money
for easements, rights of way or access routes for any service or transmission lines without first having the town attorney review every aspect
and alternative.
F. Size Of Connection: No sewer tap and connection less than four inches (4") in size shall be permitted. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-7: SUPPLYING SANITARY SEWER SERVICE TO OTHERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person or property receiving sanitary sewer service from the town of Erie to permit any other person or property to use
said service on any property without first obtaining the prior written approval of the town for such use on such specific property, which approval
may be withheld in the sole discretion of the town of Erie. No person shall sell any sanitary sewer capacity from any service connections attached
to the town sewer system. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-8: SEWER MAIN EXTENSIONS/LIFT STATIONS:
A. Method Of Extension: Any extension of a sewer main line and construction of appurtenant facilities, including, but not limited to, lift stations
necessary to supply sanitary sewer service to an area within the corporate limits of the town of Erie, such as a new subdivision, resubdivision
or territory which has been annexed by the town, shall be done at the sole cost of the person requesting said extension, except as agreed in
writing with the town of Erie, and shall be accomplished, made, done or performed by one of the following methods at the option of the town of
Erie:
1. The person requesting such sanitary sewer service shall advance to the town of Erie all costs for such main line extension and appurtenant
facilities and the town shall construct said extensions and facilities; or
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 221/449
2. The town, at its discretion, may enter into a written agreement whereby the person requesting such sanitary sewer services shall install at
said person's own expense the necessary main extensions and appurtenant facilities under a contract let to an acceptable contractor
approved by the town of Erie.
3. The person requesting such sanitary sewer service shall construct the necessary main line extensions and appurtenant facilities with the
person's own work force under terms agreed to in writing by the town of Erie.
Any of the above methods shall be made, accomplished and performed in accordance with plans, specifications, drawings, engineering, and
other requirements established, designated, and accepted by the town of Erie. All sanitary sewer system extensions and appurtenant
facilities shall be designed and installed in accordance with sanitary sewer system construction standards and specifications as established
by the town of Erie.
B. Oversizing: If the main line required to be extended to serve a subdivision or person is smaller than the size line the town wishes installed for
sound future planning, the subdivision or individual shall bear the cost for the required oversizing, and repayment by other line users will follow
as set forth by resolution or agreement.
C. Sewer Main Lines And Appurtenances To Become Town Property:
1. Customers, applicants, property owners, landowners, subdividers or developers who have completed construction of sanitary sewer main
lines and appurtenances shall before such lines and appurtenances are accepted by the town of Erie for service, deed such lines and
appurtenances and all necessary easements to the town of Erie free and clear of all liens and encumbrances, properly described by certified
survey; and shall furnish a bond, sufficient in amount, to cover warranty for a period of two (2) years from the date of acceptance of such
lines by the town of Erie.
2. The town of Erie shall have exclusive authority in determining additional uses made on any sanitary sewer lines and/or other appurtenances
prior to deeding, to include, but not limited to, such things as who will be allowed to tap on, conditions under which taps will be made, rates to
be charged, conditions of service and use of taps.
D. Design Of Main Lines: All plans and specifications relating to sewer lines, lift stations, pumping facilities or other appurtenances to be connected
to the town sanitary sewer system shall conform to the utility design standards established by the town of Erie. Such plans and specifications
shall be submitted to the town of Erie for review prior to construction. The cost of such review by the town of Erie and its consultants shall be
borne by the applicant and shall be paid prior to any review or, in the event any costs not covered by the review fee occur, the applicant will pay
this additional cost prior to obtaining a decision from the town of Erie.
E. Conformance To Town Standards: As a condition for receiving sanitary sewer service from the town of Erie, an applicant for such service shall
not develop his land or property without first complying with all town subdivision requirements, and other applicable town ordinances.
F. Sale Of Land Restricted: No developer, property owner or subdivider shall offer for sale any land within the corporate limits of the town of Erie
with the implication, written or otherwise, that sanitary sewer service is available from the town sanitary sewer system unless and until the
conditions of this chapter reclamation have been fulfilled to the satisfaction of the town of Erie.
G. Health Hazards: The Erie board of trustees shall refuse to provide sanitary sewer service for any use which would constitute a health hazard to
the town of Erie, county or counties and/or state.
H. Change Of Use Of Sewer Tap Prohibited: No person(s) may enlarge or extend in any manner the type of use for which a sewer tap was
originally issued by the town of Erie or by its predecessor, the Erie water and sanitation district, without making application and receiving written
consent from the town of Erie. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-9: SEWER TAP FEES:
A. For each unattached dwelling unit, a separate sewer tap must be purchased from the town and all required tap fees paid to the town. All multifamily
units, including, but not limited to, apartment units, townhouse units, duplex units and condominium units, shall not be treated as
unattached dwellings. (Ord. 10-2013, 3-12-2013)
B. The tap fee shall be based upon the water tap size from the town. Said fees are set forth in title 2, chapter 10 of this code.
C. Sewer tap fees for any properties that do not receive water service from the town shall be established on a case by case basis.
D. For any tap where the service requested is out of the town limits for which the town grants a sewer tap permit, the fee shall be two (2) times the
fee as set forth in title 2, chapter 10 of this code. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-10: SANITARY SEWER CHARGES:
A. Monthly Sanitary Sewer Charges: Sanitary sewer service charges shall be levied and assessed on a monthly basis at the rates set forth in title
2, chapter 10 of this code.
10/28/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=477 222/449
B. Rates Outside Corporate Limits: All sewer customers receiving service outside the town limits shall pay two (2) times the rate stated in title 2,
chapter 10 of this code.
C. Discontinuance And Proration Of Service Charges: The service charges are effective for all sewer service upon commencement of said service.
These minimum monthly charges shall not be prorated for any fractional part of a calendar month, and any property using the town's sewer
service shall be charged the minimum service charge even though no use of the sewer system has been made, unless the property owner
requests a physical discontinuance of sewer service at the property owner's expense by using an appropriate request form. Mere vacancy shall
not constitute a physical discontinuance.
D. Reevaluation Of Sewer Service Charges: The town shall have the right to reevaluate the service charged to any sewer tap at any time and shall
have the right and authority to make the necessary adjustments in charges. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)
8-2-11: UNPAID BILLS; A LIEN AND DISCONTINUANCE:
A. Delinquent Fees Constitute Lien: The owner(s) of any property for which the town provides sewer services shall have the right to designate
whether the sewer service charges shall be in the name of a tenant or in the name of the property owner. This right shall be solely for the
convenience of the property owner and shall not affect the property owner's liability for the full payment of the fees, charges and taxes accruing
to the property for the sewer services. It shall not be the responsibility of the Town to collect any fee, charge and/or tax accruing to any property
by a tenant, but such responsibility shall remain with the property owner. Regardless of whether the charges are in the name of the tenant or
the property owner, it shall be the responsibility of the owner(s) of the property to pay such charges, fees and/or tax. All unpaid sewer charges,
fees and/or taxes shall be a lien upon the property and/or unit to or for which sewer service was supplied from the time when said charges, fees
and/or taxes become due and shall be a penalty bearing charge and lien against said property and/or unit until such charges, and/or fees are
paid in full and/or such lien(s) are enforced by law. The Town Clerk may certify delinquent service charges to the Treasurer of Boulder County
or Weld County, and such charges shall be collected in the same manner as though they were a part of the taxes on such property.
Alternatively, the Town shall be entitled to judgment through civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction against the consumer, or any
owner or occupant of any real property served, for the amount of said delinquency and the costs and expenses of such proceeding, including
attorney fees. Such remedy shall be cumulative with the enforcement of this chapter.
B. Billing/Delinquency: All sewer charges, rates, and/or fees shall be considered delinquent after the last business day of the month. An additional
charge of interest on any balance of any fee, rate and/or charge shall be assessed monthly as established by title 2, chapter 10 of this Code on
the first business day of the following month. The Town of Erie shall have all billing statements posted and mailed no later than twenty five (25)
working days after the first of each month. To the extent possible, the sewer billing statements shall be included with the Town's water billing
statements.
C. Discontinuance Of Water And Sewer Service: Any unpaid portion of any sewer charges, rates and/or fees which remain unpaid after
delinquency date of any month shall result in discontinuance of Town provided water and sewer service to that property. A fee will be assessed
to shut off water service in accordance with title 2, chapter 10 of this Code and an additional fee will be assessed to discontinue the sewer
service in accordance with title 2, chapter 10 of this Code. Any unpaid portion, plus an additional reconnect fee for water and reactivation fee
for sewer shall be paid in full before water and sewer service is resumed. Sewer service will not be reactivated without concurrent reconnection
of water service. (Ord. 21-2005, 4-12-2005)

8-2-13: GENERAL PENALTY FOR VIOLATIONS; CONTINUING VIOLATIONS; ENFORCEMENT:
A. Whenever in this chapter an act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or wherever in this chapter the doing of an act is
required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of
not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment not exceeding one year or both such fine and imprisonment, except where
any different provision is made elsewhere in this chapter.
B. Each day any violation of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
C. The Municipal Court Judge is empowered in his or her discretion to assess court costs of up to and including one hundred dollars ($100.00)
against any defendant who pleads guilty or nolo contendere or who enters a plea agreement or who, after trial, is found guilty of a chapter
violation.
D. The Town shall have the right to recover all sums due by the terms of this chapter by judgment and execution thereon in a civil action in any
court of competent jurisdiction. Such remedy shall be cumulative with all other remedies provided herein for the enforcement of this chapter.
E. The remedies and penalties set forth in this chapter are nonexclusive in that the Town may take any lawful action, either in law or in equity, to
protect its property or its rights, powers, privileges or immunities created under this chapter, or those of its citizens, which may include, but is
